name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I declare the 2019-2020 session of the European Parliament open.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on "The balance between women and men in nominations for economic and monetary positions at EU level" (2019/2614(RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank President Tajani for his letter, which the Council received last week. I can assure you that we are committed to promoting gender balance. This is an important issue and the gender balance among the top staff of EU official financial bodies is also a key issue for the Council. At the same time, the selection procedures are based on rules that we have to respect. The Council has always acted – and will continue to act – in line with all the relevant provisions of EU law as regards its role in appointments. I would also expect all the other institutions involved to act within the legal framework and to do their utmost to promote gender balance. Against this background, I was surprised that Parliament is raising this issue specifically with the Council. President Tajani’s letter refers to legal acts that regulate appointments to three EU legal organs. These three bodies are the Single Supervisory Board, the Banking Stakeholder Group within the European Banking Authority, and the Single Resolution Board. Please allow me to clarify that the Council is not involved in drawing up shortlists, nor in selecting successful candidates, for any of these three bodies. The shortlists for appointments to the Single Resolution Board are provided by the Commission. Candidates for the Single Supervisory Board are the responsibility of the European Central Bank. Subsequently, for both of these boards, the European Parliament decides on the successful contenders. The Council’s role is limited to formally approving the selection made by Parliament. As regards appointments to the European Banking Authority, the Council has no role to play at all. Regarding the selection of members of the ECB Executive Board, the Council does indeed have a role in the selection procedure. I can assure you that we reiterate the importance of gender balance in each selection procedure and call on Member States to propose female candidates. I trust that all EU institutions involved in preparing shortlists and selecting candidates observe and respect the principle of gender balance and that they will continue to do so in the future. As the Presidency of the EU Council, Romania will continue to promote at European level the principle of gender balance, by facilitating debate on possible ways forward and advancing the legislative agenda, especially the negotiations on the directive on women on boards. Important progress in this area of action has already been achieved through the consistent efforts of both the Council and Parliament in relation to the work-life balance directive, on which we have been able to finalise negotiations. We are determined to make our contribution to mainstreaming gender balance on the EU agenda in order to ensure a fair and equitable environment in our societies and within our labour markets.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission, including Vice-President Dombrovskis and Commissioner Moscovici, who are in Brussels this morning at the Ecofin Council, I would like to thank you for this opportunity to exchange views on gender balance in the EU financial bodies. President Juncker replied yesterday to the letter sent by President Tajani on this matter.  First of all, let me emphasise that this Commission is fully committed to the principle of gender balance and has taken decisive action in this regard. 39.6% of middle and senior management is now female, up from 30% in November 2014. The number of female Directors-General has increased from 14% to 30%, from five to 12. The number of female deputy Directors- General has increased from 8% to 42% – it means from just three to 20. We also agree that women continue to be particularly under-represented in executive positions in the field of banking and financial services. Women only account for about 15% of private executives. The under-representation of women can also be observed in the public sector entities in this field. Women rarely make up more than a third of the governing bodies of most national central banks. The under-representation of women can be observed in a similar way in the applications for positions in EU agencies active in this field. On average, there are four to five times more male candidates than female candidates.  On the specific cases you are debating today, I would like to stress that it follows from Article 283/2 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union that the Commission plays no role in the appointment of a new member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank.  As regards the European Banking Authority, the Commission’s role is limited to assisting the Board of Supervisors in relation to the appointment of the chairperson of the European Banking Authority. For the Single Resolution Board, currently chaired by a woman, the Commission is indeed entrusted with providing the European Parliament with a shortlist of candidates for the positions of chair, vice-chair and other members of the board. In line with the relevant regulation establishing the board, appointments are to be based on merit, skills, knowledge of banking and financial matters and on relevant expertise and experience. Moreover, in line with Article 56/4 of that Regulation, candidates shall be chosen on the basis of an open selection procedure which must respect the principles of gender balance, experience and qualification.  The Commission is strongly in favour of supporting women with the necessary qualifications reaching top positions. We have taken this into account and rigorously respected the legal requirements in the selection procedures, and we have kept the European Parliament informed at all stages of the process. In the cases of the chair of the European Banking Authority and the position of board member of the Single Resolution Board, several candidates, including female candidates, failed to meet the eligibility criteria, often because they did not have the required minimum professional or senior management experience in the field of finance.  We look forward to continuing the cooperation with this House on this very important matter. In the cases where the Commission has a role in the process, the Commission will continue to pay close attention to the issue of gender balance when composing shortlist of candidates for the EU financial services agencies.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, I come in here a little panting, my coat is still next to me. So I have only heard half of what the European Commission said. The reason was quite simple: I was still managing my eight-year-old son's school on my phone via FaceTime. So that's what women in their professional lives face when they're trying to combine their job with life at home.  I think that is what we need to talk about in this debate. So don't have that tip of that iceberg and those three nominations that are now on the agenda, which some groups now think need to be shut down. I would also like to remind you that the same groups that you are about to hear, especially the Italian representatives from those groups, when we had an excellently qualified Irish woman for a position at the SSM, preferred to have their preference for an Italian man.  In other words, this debate is, unfortunately, a symbolic debate, unfortunately, because gender balance seems to affect certain groups when their nationality is not with the candidates. If that is the case, then the preference in practice secretly still goes to a man. So many people who will speak later in this debate have a big pile of butter on their heads.  Where do we start? As the European Commission has already said, the problem is that in these senior positions there is often too little of a pond of well-qualified women to choose from. It is our job, here in the European Parliament, to ensure that these women are there: in banks, in government, in politics, in business.  This starts with making it possible to combine work and private life. This starts with good childcare and that starts to lead by example especially with our sons and daughters. How is it that children aged five, six, seven years old in Kent are asked at school to sign a surgeon, a fireman and an astronaut, that more than fifty out of 60 children draw a man and is astonished when a female astronaut, a female surgeon and a firefighter enter that classroom.  So things are already going wrong there. There we must start by raising our children properly, to make that pond as big as possible, so that we no longer have to have this symbolic debate.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as has been said, the procedure, for heaven's sake, has been successful and we shall therefore vote for it. However, the problem is much more complex. In particular, as the Commissioner said, we are faced with an under-representation of women in all top positions and at all levels, but certainly in private companies and economic, financial and monetary institutions this under-representation is even greater. The problem is how this trend is reversed because, if there are no applications, I also understand that we cannot do anything else. For there to be applications, it is necessary to facilitate the careers of women, particularly in these institutions, girls must be told that you can study economics and have a decent career path, because if you say to them 'look, so if you do economic studies you will not be able to go on', then nothing happens and in the end we do not have the candidacies. I therefore call on the Commission not only to have the right attitudes, but also to promote it at European level, to ask the Member States to promote women's studies at European level in technical, economic and scientific subjects, if we then want to have the right applications.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The German state of Brandenburg has decided that the state parliament should be made up of equal numbers in the future. Let me give you an example. The rationale is that Parliament should be equally male and female, because that reflects the situation in society. Apart from the fact that 50% of the electorate is already female and can, of course, choose male or female Members, the challenge is that the proportion of women in politics is significantly lower than in society.  I have attended many party events, and the proportion of women has usually not been more than 15 or 20%. How, then, is such a joint list to be understood? Is that really fair? And where do we stop? Which marginal groups do we want to take into account in the future about the proportion of women? Do we want to keep all religions evenly considered? Do we want to include Christians, Buddhists, Muslims, atheists? And do we still have all minorities in mind? Do we want to be gay, queer, transgender, people with diabetes, with physical limitations, old, fat, young, thin – where are we going to draw the line?  Our democracy gives the electorate the opportunity to choose the person who best represents him. And we can also trust the citizens to do so, and the economy is no different. We should always choose the person who has the best qualifications and is best suited to a profession and to pursue a profession, regardless of gender – and I say this because I am a civil engineer by profession. When I started my studies 30 years ago, the proportion of women in this technical study was 15%, and 30 years later, nothing has changed. We simply have to recognise that men and women are different.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We heard in the previous statements, both from the Council and from the Commission, the usual excuses and explanations. If you shorten the whole reasoning, you could say that each party actually said: It is not our fault this.  And I think there is a serious circular reasoning here. If you listen carefully to the way in which the problem was described, it was briefly described in this way: since there are no women who have the necessary knowledge at a lower level, they never reach a higher level. That's where the problem is. It is the same explanation that we hear at airports when it is said that the aircraft is delayed because it is delayed. That's not an explanation. "Due to late incoming aircraft" is the usual explanation we get, and equally "late incoming" are the decisions on the gender balance.  This is not only a formal issue, it is also a substantive issue, because we know that the brains are a little different. My female colleagues sometimes say that if a man thinks – if a man thinks, it doesn't happen all the time that we do it – he does it in a slightly different way than a woman, with perhaps less overall perception. We also saw this during the crisis that began in 2008. The big banks, their entire management garrisons were obsessed with men and the decisions were systematically wrong. We would also have coped with that crisis much better if we had had a more even distribution between the sexes in the banks' decision-making bodies.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The new proposals by the European Commission and the Council for the top and already for the shortlists of leadership positions in the European financial institutions have simply fallen out of time. The time for only men to be proposed does not belong in the 21st century. Nor is it a question of men and women being different, as has just been said, but women have long since held leadership positions in the financial sector, in the scientific institutions, and they deserve to be involved on an equal footing. We, as a Parliament, have been working on this issue for years. The question is: how long will we stand idly by? And here I call on colleagues to be consistent now. This means that we are not appointing these people under European law for the time being, but are waiting for the Council and the Commission to find a negotiated solution to how these medieval conditions are changing in terms of designations.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, gender equality is a fundamental human right, but it seems to be dead when we come to economic and monetary issues, because women usually tend to disappear there. In the financial bodies, directors and executives of the European Union there are practically no women. There are 2 out of 25 on the Executive Board of the European Central Bank.  The Council says it has nothing to do with it when it comes to the governments they nod. The Commission says it has nothing to do with this when the European Commission presents the final list. And in the final lists there are rarely women, disappear, the governments of this European Union do not have women, as the Commissioner said, competent, with merit, with qualifications, with sufficient knowledge about banking areas. This isn't just an insult to women. It's an insult to everyone. It's an insult to the European Union and it's a disgrace. I sincerely hope that, as long as lists, appointments, only made up of men, this House, which claims to defend gender equality, will not let them pass, because they are an attack on democracy, equality and justice in the European Union.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Mr President, on Tuesday 26 February, the members of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs exchanged views with Mr Philip Lane, selected for the post of member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, Mr José Manuel Campa for the post of President of the European Banking Authority and Mr Sebastiano Laviola for the position of member of the Single Resolution Board. The observation is clear: as is often the case, women remain under-represented in the management positions of the banking and financial services sector. I am not surprised, considering that only 39% of management and management positions in European bodies are held by women. We like to discuss this topic, debate, I would even dare to say stir the wind, but when we have to act concretely, there are no longer many people, especially at the summit of the European Union itself, namely the Commission in Brussels. Of the 13 presidents of the European Commission who have succeeded each other, none have been a woman. Not a woman among the founding fathers of the European Union either. Out of 28 European Commissioners, there are only 9 women. Should we think that is normal? Out of 250 million women in Europe, is it so difficult to find 14 competent women? Of course I don't! All this is deliberate and nothing is being done to set an example at the top of the European institutions. When you see Mr Juncker's slip-ups, which we saw in front of the cameras ruffling the hair of a civil servant, Mrs Pernilla Sjolin, deputy head of protocol, one can ask questions. Is that the example we want to set? Is this the image of the woman that the Juncker Commission is wearing? Europeanists often point out that the Treaty of Rome was very far ahead by engraving in stone the principle of equal pay as early as 1957. Except that 60 years later, the facts are there: gender pay inequalities are still glaring in the EU, let alone in founding countries. So I say stop the declarations of intent, let's take concrete action!

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Once again, we are celebrating this Parliament's unhealthy obsession with gender. Once again, you show that you are completely detached from reality. The first speech has already shown that the average preschoooer has more reason than the average Member of this Parliament. You have clear evidence that women don't apply for certain positions or come forward in a minority, but you think you know better, but you know that women want, they can, they feel that women are fit for it -- you know better than themselves. You want to force them to pursue your deranged vision of gender equality, equality of everything with everything. Women are said to be half the electorate. You say , well, so what? Minors are also among the citizens of our countries. They do not have representation in parliaments – for twenty-one years you can stand as a candidate in most countries for parliament. And so what? Are these people persecuted? Is there any harm to them because they are not sitting in Parliament? We have 100 200 drivers in Parliament – including only two women. And so what? And we have the majority of translators. Let's put translators behind the wheel, and let's explain the deliberations to the drivers. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I think that all the women here today in the Chamber are really outraged.  Let's stand up together here today. I think it's incredible that you are saying this Parliament doesn't have any intelligence! I think it's unlikely you'll lash out at the women! I would like to ask you ... (The President interjects the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Vautmans, I would like to thank Mrs Vautmans for her work The blue card is not for an opinion, but for a question. And if you did not come to the question after 25 seconds, I have no hope that the question will be asked. You have 30 seconds for the blue card. I am very liberal about this. But with all due respect, the blue card is for a question, not a statement, even if you are so outraged. Very short: Finish the question, please!

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" question. – Can you please reiterate your contention that you think women are less suited to perform the same tasks as men? Because that's what I understood from your intervention.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I did not say that Parliament lacks intelligence, only reason. I do not know how it was with the translation. But these are two different things. And the facts show that women for some professions are better suited, and for some worse. Apparently they are better suited to the profession of translator than men, because we have an advantage of women and worse for the profession of driver, because we have fewer female drivers. Worse for managerial positions, and better for childcare, for example. Both sexes have different talents, and finally take note of this. Halo, Earth!

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: So, we have had the question. I also think that the reason for the questions is the same everywhere. That's why I only allow a blue card. You will have noticed that I have paid less attention than usual to speaking time. These were not bouts of generosity, but when Mrs de Lange spoke, I was distracted and left her a great deal of leash. That is why I thought I was balancing this a little between the groups. Nevertheless, we should now stick to the speaking times.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is no secret that we have a gender imbalance in the governing bodies of the European financial supervisory institutions and the central bank. This imbalance at European level is also due to the fact that there is an imbalance at national level in the governing bodies of national supervisory authorities and central banks, and therefore there is hardly any young female leaders available for the European level. That is why I would ask the Council to ensure that the promotion of women takes place in the national structures as well. That is why we must have this debate.  But what really bothers me here is the hypocrisy with which we are having this debate. The groups that are so excited here now would have had the great opportunity to reappoint a woman in the re-appointment of a woman, namely the central supervisory mechanism, and it is precisely these groups that are so outraged here today who have chosen the man, even though they were equally qualified. As the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we have made it clear that, with equal qualifications, women have priority. And then there are letters written, emails where it says, one is qualified, and the other is a woman. If I may say so, I have never seen such a discriminatory process. In the private sector, this would have had legal consequences.  That is why I say to all my fellow Members that if we have the opportunity to put a woman into office, then please do so together and not have this mendacious discussion here in plenary.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, just over a year ago, on 8 March 2018, the President of this institution wrote to the European authorities, following the appointment of Mr de Guindos, and called for a short list of candidates or a minimum of three names in the future as part of appointments to the Central Bank to be made available to the European Parliament in a balance of time. This was not the case in this case at the time of the designation or with respect to the Philip Lane proposal. We call on the Council, the Central Bank and the Commission to join forces to ensure that in future appointments, instead of explaining that their role is limited, they will act to change the situation. There is a time when this situation is no longer acceptable and that moment has come. It is not normal for these financial institutions, nor do other institutions, to neglect the gender balance. I note the efforts made in the European Commission, but we have to change the situation. To do so, you must support the proposal so that, in the next Parliament, each Member State appoints a candidate and a candidate for the post of Commissioner, the only solution to ensure effective parity in the next Commission. Similarly, with regard to positions of responsibility in the economic and financial fields, where there is a shortlist, it must respect the gender balance. Sooner or later, Parliament will have to assume its responsibilities. I observe the singular and devious battle that the EPP is fighting to try to place the responsibility on the S and D group, on the pretext that at the time of selection, our group would not have chosen the proposed candidate. Of course, we are asking for equal opportunities, but that does not mean that we must always choose women. In this regard, we cannot accuse our group of any manoeuvres. On the other hand, I note that the EPP Group wants, for political purposes, to undermine the only appointments that will be on the agenda next Thursday, when it is an appointment that comes within the framework of an institute... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! We are debating today the gender balance in the nomination of three candidates for important positions in the economic and monetary institutions of the European Union. Our Parliament is only supposed to approve seats for the three candidates on the so-called 'shortlists'. The Group of European Conservatives and Reformists supports gender balance in the selection process, but would also like geographical balance to be maintained. All candidates come from western European countries – that is, the so-called 'old Union', and yet in Central and Eastern Europe there is no shortage of candidates with a lot of experience and competence for these positions. However, it should be borne in mind that all successful candidates are qualified to perform these functions. Therefore, I do not believe that gender is the only and sufficient competence in filling these positions. By the way, it is important to note that the European Commission is made up of twenty-eight Commissioners, including nineteen men and only nine women. After all, this is clear evidence of the lack of gender balance in this one of the most important bodies of the European Union. So shouldn't the Commission start with itself?

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, I think Mr Sośnierz has just proved beyond any doubt why we cannot possibly leave it to men to run the world. We’ve been having this debate for many years now and every time we hear the same argument, ‘this time the appointment of the male candidates should go ahead, but next time – really, really next time – we’ll have a gender—balanced ballot paper’. But we’ve been hearing this for many years and it is just not credible anymore. What is also interesting is that this is not about men being better than women or women better than men. It is a known fact that diverse teams perform better. We are talking about something very serious here. We’re talking about governance and oversight of the financial sector. So why do we settle for an inferior team rather than having the strongest possible team to oversee this sector? We’ve also heard some of our colleagues say that there are not enough qualified female candidates. Come on, people. We are living in the European Union with over 500 million citizens and you’re telling me there are not sufficient candidates. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, why does it matter that economics is dominated by men? Could it be related to the fact that men own the overwhelming volume of the world’s assets, with just eight men owning the same amount of wealth as the whole of half of the world? Conventional economics is dominated by the rational economic man, a man who arrives as a full-grown adult in the world of work and ignores the mother who raised him, the teachers who educated him, the people who nursed him back to health. Whenever women come into any sphere, they bring different perspectives and insights. We don’t have to argue about whether we’re better or worse. We only have to accept that my half of the human race deserves to be fully represented in all domains where power is exercised, including the economy. As a female economist, I’m tired of waiting for a world where women play an equal role in finance and economics. I will no longer collude in a process of uttering hypocritical words and then taking no action. I will not support any more men being appointed to the boards of the financial regulatory bodies until the shortlists include at least one woman.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, this question raises two problems: firstly, gender equality which is clearly not respected in supervisory agencies or the European Central Bank. But it also raises another, not less, issue, which is democratic scrutiny of these institutions. The agencies, and in particular the ECB, when they were set up, were to be politically neutral institutions with a technical function. But the truth is that they have been accumulating powers in the framework of supervision, within the framework of assistance programmes, and this has never been accompanied by the necessary democratic scrutiny. And let us be serious, the involvement of this Parliament in the choice of the top leaders of these institutions is nothing more than a front, a real democratic fantochada.  The lists of candidates who were supposed to be provided to us either have only one name or have no female presence and, in the only situation where we had access to a list of several candidates, the final choice did not even respect the decision that was taken here by this Parliament. The residual female presence in institutions is incomprehensible, it is intolerable, but it also reflects the opaque and undemocratic nature of these institutions that are now dominated by high finance and where there is no sincere will for any scrutiny.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, let us look at the following examples: European Central Bank: a woman on the Executive Committee among five men, and a woman in the General Council among twenty-nine men. European Banking Authority: all candidates to preside over it men. Single Resolution Board: all male candidates. Single Oversight Mechanism: President, One Man. Three European Supervisory Authorities: also president one man. It is clear that power structures are unequal and it is clear that there is a gender imbalance in banking and financial services, particularly in their executive positions, and it is also clear that one of the values of the European Union is gender equality and the gender perspective as a value and a horizontal principle. Equality means more democracy. Equality means safeguarding human rights. That is why it is very important to break stereotypes, which our colleague Mr Sosnierz has not understood. We must break stereotypes and co-edit against stereotypes and thus we will achieve a fairer society, an equal society also on the economic issue.  (She agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. " We have statistics on YouTube, what who is watching and you can easily see that the audience of political videos are 80-90 percent male, and not because the angry Sośnierz forbids women to watch videos on political topics, only women are not interested in politics. What are you going to do about it? Are you going to tell women to be interested in politics? (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: There was no question about that, Mr Sonierz.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "There was a question - I asked, what are you going to do about women not watching political videos on YouTube?"

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Sosnierz, it is a disgrace that you are taking a seat in this Parliament, in the house of European peace and values. That's my answer.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not want to waste a single second of my minute, but I must do so in order to express my shame and also my indignation at hearing such shamefully backward voices in this Parliament when they speak about women.  I want to say, however, that it is a defeat for us who close the legislature, once again, with the usual film. Parliament is asking, but the Commission – if you will admit it, Commissioner Jourová – and the Council do not feel us, faced with this huge absence of women in the financial institutions. And I have to say that what is at stake is not an abstract principle of fairness – which would be worth defending, because sometimes principles have their foundation, even if they are abstract – but it is a discourse of fairness and it is a discourse of general interest.  I believe that this is not an act of goodwill, we are not here to ask for this or a gesture of attention: it is a question of recognising that the presence of women is inclusive for the institutions, strengthens them, makes them more solid. I would just like to mention a study carried out by Consob (the controlling institution of the Stock Exchange in Italy), a study from which it is clear, scientifically, that companies that have women on boards are better able to withstand the crisis and have better results... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, let me begin with the strongest rejection of the words I have just heard that if men cannot be interpreters women cannot be chauffeurs. What kind of sexism and cheap machismo is this that we have to hear sometimes in this House, really.  On the issue that concerns us. Look, as my colleagues have said before, it cannot be that the European financial institutions are co-or her as men. At the European Central Bank this situation is very clear: two women of twenty-nine in their Governing Council. Now, in addition, Mrs Nouy and Mrs Lautenschl.ger, who held important positions, are going out and we are going to replace them with men.  We have asked the Council from the Committee on Economic And Affairs so many times to send us lists of paritarian candidates in order to have scope to choose which is disgraceful. And after what is happening in European society, with the mass mobilisation of women on 8 March, this is something that can no longer be tolerated. Therefore, if this Parliament wants to exercise its rights and if we all agree, what needs to be done this week is to block appointments and ask to be sent another proposal.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, Parliament has repeatedly taken the position that there are not enough women in the management positions in the economic and financial sectors and that every time there is a promise to rectify the situation next time. This isn't going to work. It is not a question of not having girls who train and women who are competent and leading in senior positions in the national economy, economics and both public and private finance or in financial supervision positions. The question is whether we will see this competence, whether people will be nominated and whether alternatives will be brought into this process that will promote gender equality, and then it is not just a question of equality, even though it is an important pillar. The question is quality: do we leave the resources and talents of half the nation unused in decision-making? I propose that, in future, we must move to the fact – as Parliament proposed with regard to commissioners- designated candidates – that each Member State should put forward both a woman and a man when appointments are made to these seats.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – Mr President, we will have to support or oppose the appointment of candidates to important positions in the European Union's economic and monetary policies during the vote on Thursday. And all the nominations submitted to Parliament are men. Women are really under-represented in banking and financial services institutions– only about 15%. Colleagues, it is hard to believe that in the 21st century we still have to fight and remind each time that one of the fundamental principles of the European Union, gender equality, must be implemented by appointing the heads of the Institutions of the European Union itself and the members of the boards. Ensuring the principle of gender equality in the positions in question is enshrined not only in the Treaties of the European Union, but also in at least three regulations defining the activities of the European Union's financial institutions. How can it be that the European Union itself is not complying with its own legislation? And that is why we in the European Parliament are demanding that gender balance be respected everywhere.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to say that I regret Mr Sosnierz's words. In this House can not be allowed. Commissioner, as rapporteur for gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament, I can only regret that the appointment to three senior positions in European institutions, such as the European Central Bank, has been awarded to three men. In a Europe where the values we stand for are those of equality and human rights, we cannot conceive how, when the time comes to put these same values into practice, we choose to ignore and perpetuate a culture led mainly by us men. The argument that these men were the most qualified no longer picks up. What is the point of flaging gender equality if, in the end, the people most qualified for these cases always end up being men?  So I ask: are there not women sufficiently qualified to take these positions? For when the end of this social stigma and the bet on women for senior leadership positions? The Union must lead this challenge and be at the forefront of gender equality. I urge not only my colleagues in the Committee on Economic Affairs to rethink their proposals but also the Member States themselves to promote more women's applications.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we have a debate here, and it is not the first, on gender equality. Gender equality is a necessity, it's not a fad, it's not a slogan. We are now talking about gender equality in economic institutions, but we have to recognise that there are shared responsibilities. Who is the Commissioners proposing, for example? They said we only have nine female commissioners. Member States! After hearing what the colleague said, I think we need to get back to the essential point, which is education. If we still have men in the European Parliament this century who consider them predestined, we are very low in terms of education and understanding of gender equality. That is why I believe, Commissioner, that, on the one hand, Parliament, the Commission and the Council must show transparency and good intentions in promoting women, because we have fewer Vice-Presidents than Vice-Presidents, for example, in our own Parliament. But at the same time, we need to think that, at home, the Member States will show the application of what we have. We have enough regulations for gender equality, and I ask you, how many women governors of national banks do we have? How many women do we have as vice-governors? How are we going to have candidates here? Colleagues, at home Member States must implement their gender equality policies.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, what has happened with these appointments to economic institutions of the Union proves that in matters of equality we do not hear the cry expressed by European women on 8 March. It grows every year, because we don't learn.  When we celebrated the 20th anniversary of the euro, only men spoke. Then I said the same thing wouldn't happen in twenty years, but we're on the wrong track.  Equality is fairer, more democratic, but it is also more profitable. We're do without talent, we're losing potentially excellent candidates. They exist, you have to think about them and propose them. It's smart, but it's also mandatory. That's why we have to block these appointments.  Last March 8th I received an image on my phone that said it all. Think of the professional race as an athletics track: on men's street there are no obstacles; in women's women appear washing machines, clotheslines, children, children's school appointments, household chores...  Our hundred meters are never free, they are full of fences. That's the first problem we have to solve. We need laws, self-criticism and commitment...  (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, as a firm believer that women are as capable – if not more capable, in many, many things – I find the idea of having to give extra assistance to women extremely patronising. The self-same people who say that there should be more women put forward and there should be artificial ways of pushing women into these roles they don’t currently hold – or at least not so many of them currently hold – are the same people who, were there more women in these roles than men, would be celebrating it as a great victory for the progress of liberation of women’s rights. They wouldn’t say: ‘Hang on, where’s the gender balance? We all work better as a team. Where are the men?’ They wouldn’t be saying that!  This is just another way of virtue—signalling. Women are good enough, intelligent enough, and in the modern world, educated enough, to take top positions without anyone here having to ruffle their hair saying: ‘Good girl, go on, go ahead yourselves’. They can do it without that kind of patronisation.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: – Mr President, my colleague, Sirpa Pietikäinen, gave an excellent speech above. It is certainly not a question of not have qualified women in Europe for economic posts and for the European Central Bank. They just can't be found or don't want to be found. Or is there really someone who could seriously claim that there are no qualified women in the Member States of the European Union for economic posts or for the European Central Bank? I would like to say that I strongly disagree with what Mr Sośnierz said. He spoke derogatoryly of women. At the same time, however, I have to say that, on the one hand, it is good to express this dissenting opinion, because in fact such a statement – although perhaps not in such a derogatory sense – is quite common in Europe, otherwise women would have been put on the posts and there would be many more of them, because there is competence – it is a question of attitudes.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Contrary to my other habits, I would like to say something about this now. I have listened carefully to this debate and I can sign the vast majority of what has been said here. I would like to refer to a victim that is very rarely seen in this debate, namely language. I am completely unhappy as to whether I am now being referred to by my Romanian colleague as a 'preedinte', as a 'voor tremor' or, as Mr Hannan always does, as 'Mr Deputy Speaker'. The English language actually had a nice term: "Chairman" or "Chairwoman". Over time, it has become a "chair person", and I could live with that. But in the meantime, the matter has become so acute that one is only referred to as a "chair". And I think instead of using "Chairperson", "Chairwoman" or "Chairman", depending on who is sitting in front, you have depersonalized the matter to such an extent that one only speaks of "Chair". So you've made a thing out of man. And I would like to say that I feel extremely uncomfortable about this without wanting to specifically address any colleague. (End of spontaneous speeches)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I don’t know if I would be making a mistake if I would dare to give you the title of ‘Mr’ President! Thank you for a very interesting debate. I will add a few comments.  We have enough very well qualified women in the financial sector. When speaking about sectors and a deficit, we see a deficit in relation to qualified women in the technology and IT sector, but for the financial sector, we do have enough highly qualified women. Out of 62% of university graduates who are women, we have a lot of very well qualified economists and financial experts. Indeed, we have surveys which say that it’s in companies and in the financial sector and in banks where there is diversity on boards, where there is balanced representation, where there is more balanced decision-making. These are surveys which took lessons from the financial crisis, which say clearly that men have more of a tendency to take irresponsible and dangerous excessively risky decisions. This is not my invention; this is what we see in the facts and from the data collected from many institutions and that’s why it’s good to have diversity on boards and to have this balanced decision-making. That’s why I think that it will be good if we work together for the future on the procedures which will guarantee better representation of women by means of fair competition. This is what I introduced already in the current version of the proposed women on boards directive, where we say the first stage in decision-making and in the selection process must look at the qualification, expertise and experience – the professional ability and capability to do the job – and then the person whose gender is under—represented should be given priority. I think that this is very fair and in fact, it is gender-neutral because it could be a man who gets priority one day. I think that we should look into these processes and make them more fair.  I have been doing this job of Gender Equality Commissioner for five years now and I have heard a lot of different myths and also lies. One of them, I heard today is that we are different. Of course we are different. We have different ways of thinking and that’s why we should have this balanced representation. We are different as individuals. I come from a totalitarian country. When I hear about equality, I am nervous because I lived in the regime which imposed equality. We are individuals. Our ability to do jobs differs and don’t tell me that we have a problem from a gender point of view. The second myth – speaking about the quota, which was introduced in this women on boards directive and which some of you called to be used in the process for the financial sector. I hear sometimes that under a quota system, a woman will end up replacing a fantastic, well-educated man. That’s not true. I want to be well understood. I plea for fair competition. This is necessary to follow under excessive risk-taking and the lessons learned after the financial crisis. I think it was Neelie Kroes who said that the financial crisis would not have come about if it had been the Lehman sisters, but it was the Lehman brothers, so that’s why we had the problem. The last two comments: we had a few minutes ago a lot of very beautiful young people around here. When stagiaires and students visit me, the young women do not speak about discrimination. They are just ready to go for it. We should also fulfil the task of encouraging and helping them to have higher self-confidence and to be ready to do demanding jobs because low self-confidence, according to many other surveys, is one of the barriers for women to going for these high jobs, and to break some kind of risk-avoidance feature, which we as women also sometimes have. Last comment on what we heard from Mr Sośnierz: yes, horrible things. I don’t agree with what I heard from Mr Sośnierz but, ladies and gentlemen, I was here yesterday and we had a debate about agriculture and about the protection of fish and animals and yesterday I heard that fish do not deserve our protection because they don’t have voting rights and they are not taxpayers! Today, speaking about women, I heard softer language, so thank you for that.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, to conclude, I would like to assure you once again that, as regards appointments to finance—related EU bodies, the Council is fully committed to promoting gender balance while acting strictly as required by EU law. I also hope that I have been able to clarify the Council’s role in these processes. Thank you very much, once again, for your attention.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The motions for resolutions to be submitted in accordance with Article 123(2) of the CRP will be announced at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. – It is undeniable that there is a lot of work to be done on gender equality in all EU Member States, even though we are generally in a much better situation than, for example, in numerous African and Asian countries. We, too, have a significantly lower number of women in many management positions, such as banking and financial sectors, than the number of men.  In order to achieve equality between women and men better in practical life, it is important to facilitate the coordination of work and family life. It is important to ensure a good standard and availability of childcare.  This debate also suggested the use of gender quotas as one of the means of achieving gender balance. I believe that quotas are the wrong way to correct imbalances, because even so-called positive discrimination is discrimination. In general, no one wants to be elected to a position or position because of their gender, but because of their own ability and qualifications. Each person has their own individual interests. Women and girls should be encouraged to apply to study in those fields and in those positions that interest them, including at a more demanding level. It is important that young people have role models that put this into account and show that women, too, can successfully progress to high positions and do even better in them than men.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate with the Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic, Peter Pellegrini, on the Future of Europe (2019/2515(RSP)). Prime Minister Pellegrini, thank you for coming. Commission President Juncker, friends, it is important for us to have a debate with the Slovak Prime Minister on the future of the European Union. The European Parliament, Mr Pellegrini, is the heart of democracy. We want to know, as well as the position of the Commission, as well as the position of the French Republic, the position of every Member State of the European Union. This is an open debate. As you know, for us, for the future, it is important to strengthen the position of the European Parliament. In terms of content, immigration is a key point. Parliament approved reform of the Dublin rules, and we have asked for a decision by the European Council, but at the same time we want to do more work in Africa. We want to invest more money in Africa. The other important point is social policy. We are strongly committed to combating youth unemployment. For this, we need to work in favour of the real economy, but at the same time we need to work against climate change. This is an important commitment for the European Parliament. We are talking about the future of the European Union during a time of difficulties. Today, Parliament will vote on China policy. This is important for us, and there are other important points on our agenda before the European elections. Brexit is one of the most important. Yesterday Prime Minister May was here. On this point, it is important for us to know the Slovak position. Prime Minister, thank you very much for coming. You have the floor.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic. – Mr President, I should like to thank you for the opportunity to take part in this debate about the future of Europe. It is a real honour and privilege for me to be here today, as this Democratic House represents all European citizens. Human history is driven by a desire to achieve ideals and create a better future. This is exactly what was at the birth of the European Union 60 years ago. It's what started with democratic changes 30 years ago in Czechoslovakia. We were driven by ideals of peace, prosperity and unity. The project of the European Union brought peace to Europe and it brought us stability, freedom and prosperity. It brought us success – even to smaller countries like Slovakia. Ladies and gentlemen, the Slovak journey back to advanced Europe began in 1989 with a desire for freedom, democracy, human rights, economic and technological progress. Fifteen years ago, we went back to where we always belonged – to western European and transatlantic value space through integration into the European Union and NATO. The subsequent Slovak story was extremely successful. But it wasn't always an easy and straightforward journey. We had to overcome an era of economic slump and transformation. We had to fight high unemployment, cope with the reconstruction of the banking sector and structural changes in our economy. We have built democratic institutions in a new Slovak statehood, we have also overcome a period of democratic crisis and we have mastered the demanding criteria for joining NATO and the European Union. Eu enlargement between 2004 and 2013 was a classic demonstration of a win-win process. The new Member States have gained the prospect of modernisation and growth, the old Member States have expanded the stability zone and won a larger single market. Slovakia is now a full member of the European family. We are among the countries with the highest GDP growth in the EU, we are a stable member of the euro area with relatively low unemployment and we have changed from an emigro country in recent years to a country where more people come before they leave. And the overall atmosphere in the country has changed. Our citizens are freer and richer, but also more demanding at the level of political life. We are using this potential to modernise our country. Slovakia has a strong civil society and a high level of media freedom. However, we ourselves are aware that there are areas in which we must add, for example in the quality of education, research and innovation potential, in the quality of state administration, or in reducing the space for corruption. But the Slovak story can be an inspiration to the European Union even in the current situation. Difficult challenges can be successfully overcome and major obstacles overcome, but this must be wanted. Already Milan Rastislav Štefánik, a great Slovak and European diplomat and one of the founders of the Czechoslovak Republic in 1918, our French general said: "For people of strong determination and endurance there is nothing that can be achive." And his legacy was followed after accession to the European Union, when there was a lot of work to be done. We have gone through the difficult process of joining Schengen and the euro area. We have never stopped on our way to integration, because we sincerely believe in the strength and correctness of the European idea. We consider a united Europe to be a natural space for our existence. I believe that there is no alternative for us. We confirmed this during the Slovak Presidency of the Council of the European Union, and the Bratislava Summit sent a clear signal of unity of the Union following the shock of the results of the British referendum. However, Slovakia, like the whole of Europe at present, is not entirely immun with attacks on the values of the European Union. Even in such an important area as freedom of speech. Any attacks on journalists provoke a legitimate public reaction, and we have seen this in Slovakia as well. This is a sign of the great maturity of our democracy and of our citizens. A few weeks ago, a year has passed since the murder of journalist Ján Kuciak and his partner Martina Kušnírová. The double murder of two young people has shaken the whole of Slovakia, both socially and politically. But I want to assure you that we all have only one goal: to track down and punish the perpetrators of this crime. I would also like to express my thanks to the European Parliament, including the Monitoring Group on the Rule of Law, for the cooperation that has been and often critical so far. I also thank Europol for its help in the investigation that has produced its results: the first defendants are already in custody and awaiting a fair trial. Today, for Slovakia, I can confirm that, even in these difficult times, we want to continue to belong to the group of most integrated countries in the European Union. We are ready to bear our adequate share of the burden of responsibility for the joint integration project, as well as to co-shape our European future. The election of the President of the Slovak Republic is about to take place. I believe that the citizens of Slovakia will demonstrate their maturity and choose a candidate with a clear pro-European direction.  And let me say that the party I represent, as a governing party, could not have built more of a pro-European candidate than the Vice-President of the European Commission, Maroš Šefčovič. I also consider this to be a signal of values both inside and outside the country. The success story of Slovakia is, a certain extent, defined by where we come from. Central Europe is a natural living environment for Slovakia, on the basis of our history, geography and culture. After all, regional political cooperation is the essence of EU success. Franco-German cooperation, Weimar, Benelux, the Baltics and even the Visegrád Group are bringing new initiatives and ideas and thus strengthening our Union. Slovakia currently holds the Presidency of the Visegrád Group. Our main objective is to bring a positive agenda to strengthen the EU. Of course, we are aware of differences, maybe even of criticism and comings, but in these challenging times we need to keep everyone on board, at the table, and we need to resolve our disputes through dialogue. The European Union is the product of a strong vision and the immense efforts of several generations. We are simply obliged to protect it, especially now that Europe and western democracies face dramatic new developments. We are surrounded by challenges coming from all directions, from both inside and outside Europe. We see growing Russian and Chinese aspirations, which require a strong and united EU response. We see this climate change as unpredictable economic, political and social impact on our lives. We see a new wave of technological revolution – Industry 4.0 – and Europe as we know it will survive only if it stays in the forefront of technological progress and innovation. That's what our governments need to become Governments 4.0. Moreover, we face many challenges from within Europe. Growing social differences are destroying the original social contract. We face a dramatic ageing of our societies. Regional socioeconomic disparities do not contribute to a feeling of unity: many people feel they are left behind. In this context, it is no surprise that mass immigration from countries outside the EU has been caused by new tensions and conflicts. We forget to talk to our citizens about Europe, about democracy and about our plans for the future. When they hear no answers from us, they turn around. Lack of communication can become a breeding ground for disinformation and fake news. One example was the British referendum in 2016. It is obvious that isolationism, protectionism and nationalism are not a solution. Our answer must not be fragmented into small national states with limited resources, but stronger unity of the EU as a global power. Honourable Members, as 17 of my colleagues have already, let me be brave and determined in presenting my vision of our common future: a vision of an attractive Union that citizens can trust and support. This remains a valid message from the Bratislava Summit: first, a which Union is united, prosperous and secure; and, second, and Union is globally relevant, and that Union is honest with its citizens, and a Union that cares about its own future. However, we need to find a common path to achieve our ideals. So my question is 'How are we going to get there?' First, we need to be united. 'Unity' was the word bridge often used by my colleagues who have already addressed this House, and they are completely right. Without unity among the Member States, we will become subject to the decisions of others. We can't be credible and successful in achieving our ideals if we're not going to overcome the last leftovers of the former east-west divide. We have to get rid of the stereotypes through which we perceive our differences. Here I would like to recall the words of the highly regarded Slovak politician Milan Hodža, who served as Prime Minister of Czechoslovakia from 1935 to 1938. Back in 1942, he wrote: 'European security cannot be built only in the West, it also requires central Europe, and the common democratic ideals and institutions of both provide hope for the future'. I believe that beyond the differences and geographical boundaries there are common interests. We need to communicate, try to understand one another, and perhaps go the extra mile on both sides. There are many positive examples of differences being overcome – name just two major examples, the rules on the posting of workers and on dual food quality. On the other hand, there is one major issue on which we have failed, on both sides, to communicate – namely, migration. We have to work out and work for everyone. Immigration must be manageable and migration should serve European interests. Yet, we can't preserve a political unity without achieving sufficient socioeconomic convergence and cohesion in the EU. In other words, we must use prosperity for the benefit of all. We must mitigate the negative consequences of globalisation and avoid tax avoidance by corporations. We have to make their pay taxes in the countries where they actually operate and generate their profits. We have to combat growing inequalities in society and redistribute wealth more efficiently. The introduction of a European minimum wage will be one way to create social solidarity. We government is committed to the European Pillar of Social Rights, which is to provide a strong social dimension in the European Union of the future. As well as advocates fair Labour mobility, which will allow our citizens and companies to seize the opportunities of the single market. We welcome the agreement to establish the European Labour Authority and we have already declared our intentions of hosting it in our capital.  Secondly, we need to be globally relevant. We need the EU, which plays an important global role, reflecting its economic power. We must take action to unify our forces and increase capacity building in defence. Slovakia strongly supports Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) on security and defence, while ensuring complementarities between the EU and NATO. Globally relevant means that we have uphold our long-term commitments. We are not an exclusive club. We want to be an inclusive community, open to those who meet the criteria and even those who once left. This is in our strategic interest, and otherwise somebody else will fill the vacuum around us. At the same time, "global" means having significant economic power, backed by a strong currency and based on free but fair international trade. The EU has been told to remain the champion in this regard. Thirdly, we need to be honest with our citizens. We can't promise our citizens and life without problems, hard work and challenges. The EU has no magic wand to solve all the problems. However, we can offer our citizens and credible vision of our future, and turn that vision into tangible deeds. We need to make our citizens – above all, young people – feel a sense of ownership. The EU is not some fictitious, distant 'Brussels'. We are the European Union. (Applause) We need to confront who tell us otherwise. Ignoring them or ridiculing them is not the solution. We need to challenge them by facts. The EU is now a large and strong community. It provides us with a collective identity because there is something about the EU that is also personal. But it doesn't take away our national or personal identity. Our unity must be a unity of values within the diversity of our national, regional and local cultures. Finally, we need to care about the future. Soon, in the run-up to the European elections, you, the European political parties, will have an opportunity to present a new, realistic vision of our Union. The European debate has become very lively and intense at many levels, political and civic, national and regional. My appreciation goes to President Macron, who has had a lot of discussions with his own vision of the future - and I agree with him. We can't be trapped in the status quo and give way to resignation. We have to renew our Union. It is up to us as leaders to find a common path and instruments that citizens can trust and support, because we need freedom, progress and protection in the European Union. We have to find a way of protecting the four freedoms that are at the core of EU integration. We need an EU-wide debate on what our strategy and aspirations should be for the middle of the century. The EU will certainly have a major transformation towards a climate neutral economy. We need a transition that is socially just towards our citizens and fair to our businesses. The important issue for the future development of the European economy is that of digitalisation and automation. On the one hand, there is a great concern that people will not have enough jobs because robots will replace them. On the other hand, there is great concern about the lack of skilled workers on the markets. Yet, in the future, we need even more highly skilled people. The best evidence of this is that countries with the highest number of robots per job, Germany, South Korea, Singapore, have the lowest unemployment rates. There are currently around 151 robots per 10,000 working places in Slovakia. This is more than half the European average and the highest level in Central and Eastern Europe. We are not afraid of technological change: we just need to adopt smart and responsible policies. If we want to be honest in our aspiration for the future, we must have the right tools, dry as the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). The current EU budget represents only 1% of EU gross national income. While focusing on the budget on new challenges, we don't want to give up on cohesion policy. Calls for its reduction in the next MFF reflect a wrong understanding of the role of cohesion policy. It is cohesion policy that helps rich and poor regions to converge, and contributes to growth even in economically difficult times. I mean, do we need to speak about our future, but how can we speak about the new MFF without having a clear vision of the European Union? I don't think it's the right approach to see the firstly what kind of budget we have and then decide what we can pay for out of it. I think we should do it next. First we have to see where we are like to be in the next five, seven, ten or fifteen years – what are our priorities – and then to decide how big and budget and what kind of budget we need for our priorities. That's the approach that I prefer over the current one. (Applause) On the subject of new technologies, we have to admit openly – and I'm not talking here about the European Parliament but rather generally – that, at European level, we are not able to keep pace with developments in this area. We're always behind. We are facing a digital revolution but we are not able to effect a revolution in the regulatory framework. We're always behind. We are trying to regulate something that people are already using, and sometimes we do so in drought and way that we are over-regulate everything, and then we find ourselves crying that we are not at the same level as the USA or Asia, where the innovation environment is growing up, while we are still divided with 27 or 28 different sets of regulations. So please, we need to consider some flexible regulatory framework, not to regulate every simple thing that is going on in our lives, because this is not the future in the digital revolution. We need to table only some basic rules and some kind of framework that is flexible enough, because we politicians are not able to act as fast as we need to act. That's why I mention the world. If we're talking about Industry 4.0, then we need to push our Member States to introduce 'Government 4.0', because what we have to have in some countries is more like Government 2.0 or maybe 3.0. I am not sure if we have a Government 4.0 anywhere reflecting the needs of the future. Honourable Members, the European elections are quickly approaching and we need to mobilise our forces to combat fake news, hybrid threats and cyber-propaganda. Make people feel the urgency! Talk to them about the importance of the EU for their everyday lives. Make them understand that election matter: that this is their only opportunity to steer the EU, and that they should not let others speak for them. There is a lot of work ahead of us. Let me finish my speech with the words of one of the founding fathers of European integration. Jean Monnet said: 'People only accept change when they are faced with necessity, and only recognise necessities when a crisis is upon them.' We must be brave and determined. We have to make changes and make the Union attractive to all: a Union able to learn from its past mistakes in order to prepare itself to embrace the future. Once again, we need a vision of an attractive Union that citizens can trust and support.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Commission President. Buongiorno, Mister President, Mister Prime Minister, dear Peter, I'll tell you a secret. I didn't sleep much last night, because of Mrs May, but long enough to be able to dream of Slovakia and Bratislava. For in negotiating yesterday with Mrs May, I thought of the European summit in Bratislava in September 2016, three months after the decision of the British people to leave the European Union. Your government, of which you were a member, and you have a great deal of merit in terms of the slovak Presidency's record, had accepted the idea of convening, for the first time in history, a European summit of 27. The Slovak government, like us, believed that Brexit was the past and that we had to prepare for the future of the European Union. This is what we did in Bratislava, adopting the so-called 'Bratislava Roadmap'. I have a good memory of this European Council, which came a few days after the State of the Union speech I gave in this Chamber. For the first time, and probably also the last, the 27 Prime Ministers welcomed the content of this speech. This had never happened before, it will never happen again, but I remember the Bratislava summit as a great moment in my little political life, since it ensured that we were able, with courage, determination, although sometimes on a senator's train, to move towards a European future which some had predicted at the time that it would never see the light of day again after the British decision. We agreed last night with the British government on the terms and consequences of Brexit. I said last night, or overnight, that this is the second chance, but there will not be a third. I would therefore like the Members of the British Parliament today to support the British and European approach, which has been agreed at European Union level, in the form of a common text. I wanted, Peter, to thank you, on behalf of the Commission, for all the support that the Slovak Government continues to give us. I am thinking in particular of the effort he made when it came to innovation by amending the directive on the secondment of workers. It was an important step. The same applies to the creation of the European Labour Authority. I also note, and this is not a point I am making, that the number of governments that want to host the European Labour Authority on their territory is higher than was the number of governments that, ab initio and spontaneously, had supported the Commission in its desire to create this authority, on the model of the Banking Authority. I am pleased to hear you say that you love the social pillar of the European Union. The more Prime Ministers say that, not only here, but also in the European Council and at the level of the Council of Ministers, the less isolated I feel at the level of the European Union. The Slovak Government has helped us a great deal to set up the social foundation at the Extraordinary European Council in Gothenburg, which, by the way, I say to those who keep claiming it, has expressed the need to introduce a minimum wage everywhere in Europe. This is not an idea that has been born in recent weeks, it is an idea that has animated us since this Commission took office, and I would like us to implement it as soon as possible. The same applies with regard to the creation of a minimum income in all the countries of the European Union. You talked about the fiscal framework for the next seven years, and rightly so, you said that we have to agree first on the policies and then on the means of funding the policies that have been decided. That is exactly what the Commission has done. The approach that we took is exactly what you wanted. You say that the need to maintain cohesion policy should not be overlooked. I am a strong supporter of cohesion policy, but in order to agree on this, we had to take into account, and you called for it a few moments ago, the policies of innovation and modernisation, digital policy or even the Europe of defence. We have done all of this, and if we had not reviewed the cohesion policy, which is still necessary, and the common agricultural policy, we would have reached a budgetary level of 1.41 per cent. Even your government, despite your enthusiasm, would never have accepted a budget of 1.41 per cent. So we had to make choices, and we made them. Slovakia currently holds the presidency of the Visegred Group. I would like you to take this opportunity to help put an end to this debate between Eastern Europeans, or rather central Europeans, and Western Europeans. Europe has to breathe with two lungs and everything must be done so that these two lungs do not collide in the same body.  We all have our contribution to make. We must not believe that it would be only the Commission, the European Parliament and a few Western European governments that would be responsible for this confrontation, which is sometimes ridiculous and which, in any case, is harmful. Use your presidency of the Visegred group to remedy this situation. You know, Slovakia, for the rest of us who come from the West and are no longer young, but who try to stay so, Slovakia is not a country like any other. I was thirteen years old at the time of the so-called Prague Spring, which is also the spring of Bratislava - I even believe that the first movements could have been observed in Slovakia. We pay special attention to this country, a love of experience and hope, and I would therefore like the Slovaks not to think that the rest of Europe does not like Slovakia, on the contrary, and I would like Slovakia to love the European Union more. Some elements of history that occurred after the two world wars are little known. Thus, the exiled government of Czechoslovakia at the time and other central European governments had already outlined a project for Europe, which they called a project for the European Union. At the end of this little-known document is a sentence that has always impressed me, moved even. These Central European countries, with their governments in exile, have concluded: "We would like the countries of Western Europe to one day join us in building the European Union." History has prevented you from coming out of its shadows, but as the Central Europeans were the first to dream of a peaceful Europe, it is our duty and our ardent obligation to continue the work that is ours.  (Applause)

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr Juncker, thank you for your words. Mr President-in-Office of the Government, welcome to the European Parliament and thank you for sharing your vision of Europe with us. From the Group of the European People's Party we thank you for the tone and language used. And we thank you for referring from the rostrum to the murder of journalist Ján Kuciak and his partner, although we don't think that's enough. Freedom of the press is one of the fundamental pillars of democracy and when a journalist is killed that tragedy affects all democracies. In Malta, no one has yet assumed any responsibility for Daphne Caruana's death. Something we deeply regret. In Slovakia, beyond Robert Fico's resignation, we also do not see great progress being made. You don't get to the end of the investigation. Why? What's keeping the investigation from coming to an end? More than that, we are concerned, and much, about the rhetoric of some members of your coalition or some presidential candidate. They continue to use hate speech against the opposition and hate speech against the press. What are you going to do about it? Are you truly committed to the fight against extremism and hate speech that some practice quite close to you? Mr President-in-Office of the Government, difficult times are coming for Europe. Brexit doesn't know where it's going to take us. The Transatlantic Alliance is regularly put into question. The Russian government is eager to weaken us, to see us fail, to divide us. There has been an unprecedented migration crisis since World War II.  These are problems that European states cannot take on on their own. These are problems for which we need greater unity and yet when we are in that circumstance, your Government seems to bet just the opposite. Your speech is one here, but then your government in your country does the opposite. We would like to know what your position really is: that of the speech we have heard or that of your Government in Slovakia? Are you committed to the process of further European integration? Are you committed to your country's membership in NATO? There are issues that concern us and that we think have not only not been clarified, but this morning they contradict the actions that your Government takes in your country. We, as a Group of the European People's Party, have this very clear: Europe must be built on the basis of concrete actions; Europe must be built from the base, from the simplicity of citizens and town halls, and not from elitism. The great discourses on Europe do not work if one in his own country has the worst managed agriculture in the European Union.  Europe must be built rigorously, seriously, with ambitious but also achievable proposals. National policy cannot be based on the confrontation with Brussels, the confrontation with Brussels, the political war against Brussels. Europopulism is as dangerous as nationalpopulism.
