And Europe must be built from within, taking into account the problems, but also from the outside, because there are ideological battles, Mr President of the Government, which, without happening on European soil, are also European battles, such as the one taking place in Venezuela, which is a battle for freedom and democracy and also today, unfortunately, for food.  His Government has not yet recognized Venezuela's interim president, Mr. Guaidó. In this sense it is placed in the same orbit as Russia, as Cuba or iran. That's to make you look at it, Mr. President of the Government. How long is it going to take, Mr Pellegrini, to stand on the side of the hungry town that the meds don't get to? Mr President-in-Office of the Government, it is true that the European dream deserves effort and unity on the part of all. Ambition must be regained, idealism regained, contact with citizens regained. Something we will be doing wrong, therefore, so that more and more citizens turn their eyes to anti-European and extremist movements every day. There is no doubt about it, Mr Pellegrini, nationalpopulism is the most serious threat looming today about the European Union's dream.  It is nationalpulism that is the greatest threat. All the others exist, but none of them are as corrosive to us as the one that comes from within. And either I am wrong, or the next parliamentary term we will have in this Parliament a large group of nationalpulists. That's why everyone, you from your responsibility—as President Juncker reminded you—and we, from ours, have to do whatever's in our power. And you as a Council are soon going to have a very important job, which is to propose to this Parliament a President of the Commission. I'd like you to leave here having reminded him that we have a commitment not to accept a candidate who has not previously been a candidate in the European elections, who is not endorsed by the vote of the citizens, who comes taxed and did not vote. In short, Mr President-in-Office of the Government, a new chapter of European history will open on 26 May, a chapter to be built with collaboration and with all the voices, the big and small, because the greatness of Europe is unity.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister, it was very inspiring to listen to you on your ideas about the future of Europe and what role Slovakia can play. Their country lies in the centre of Europe on the dividing line between East and West – for decades separated by the iron curtain and at the same time connected by the Danube, one of the most important lifelines of Europe. Since the reunification of our continent, Slovakia has undergone an astonishing development that some would not have trusted. The separation from the Czech Republic was peaceful and Slovakia, contrary to some forecasts, was able to develop very positively economically. Slovakia was the first Member State in the region to meet the convergence criteria for the introduction of the euro. This has also contributed to the remarkable economic recovery. These developments are extremely positive and your country has become an important factor in Europe on the right track. You proved this, not least with the EU Presidency two years ago.  But where there is a lot of light, there is also a lot of shadow. Unfortunately, the success has also magically attracted the moths, and for years there have been suspicions about the influence of the mafia and corrupt mechanisms, including in relation to European funds. The investigative journalist Jon Kuciak wanted to shed light on the dark and paid for it with his life. This horrific murder of him and his partner has awakened the European public, mobilised Slovak civil society and led to political consequences in your country. The European Parliament has set up a rule of law working group within the framework of the LIBE Committee, which deals in principle with these events, which do not only exist in your country. We will vote on it in the next plenary session. The balance sheet regarding your country is positive in many areas. Substantial progress has been made in investigating the murders, although the masterminds are still not really known. And it is positive to highlight cooperation with Europol, which is a real European added value.  However, there are still doubts as to whether you have really drawn lasting conclusions, both in terms of the independence of the judiciary and the freedom of the press. We urge you not to let up here and to support Parliament in its efforts to create a rule of law mechanism that allows for constant evaluation, irrespective of such tragic events. Prime Minister, this is not interference in your country's internal affairs. The rule of law serves above all the security needs of the people. No one wants to teach your country. It is about common rules and a common understanding of the law. Only in this way can East and West grow together.  In this context, President Juncker spoke today of the two lung wings of Europe. That is why it is also necessary to critically examine the role of Western countries. Here, too, there are some problems to be assessed. Too often, the East is seen as an extended workbench, where short-term profits can be made thanks to low wages and poor working conditions. This is by no means sustainable, neither for the East nor for the West. Nor is the brain drain caused by the growing labour migration. The creation of a European Labour Authority could regulate these imbalances. We support you in this endeavour, and if we do not seize this opportunity and others, such as the creation of a European unemployment insurance scheme, then we risk this Union falling apart. It is about sustainability and not just about short-term projects motivated by domestic politics.  The protection of our environment and the achievement of climate targets must not be put off. Climate change does not stop at national borders. The project concerns all of us, the East and the West. But we will only be able to win people over to sustainable change if this goes along with more fairness and social justice. This has long since been a matter of national competence. European action is necessary – determined and forward-looking. East and West will only grow together if common solutions are sought – basic social security, minimum wages and equal pay in the workplace, fair conditions in the digital sector, etc. A social Europe is the best putty for our continent, which is currently stirred up by stoked fears. You have already done a great deal. Prime Minister, Slovakia and you could make a much bigger contribution to this Afford.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group. – Mr President, Prime Minister, exactly 20 years ago, NATO first expanded after the end of the Cold War. Although Slovakia was not part of this enlargement, our civilisational anchoring took place not only in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, but also in the European Union. Unfortunately, recently, it has been openly questioned not only by various extremists, but also by part of the governing coalition. Undermining our strategic alliances and recklessly overtaking Russia are contrary to the interests of Slovakia and the European Union. If we want to be a credible partner for our allies, we need to be consistent. We must also be clear towards the public in Slovakia. Not to approach lies or to inducing fear just because of the higher popularity. Yes, it's easier for people to mobilize to negative emotions, but it's dangerous to mess with it. It can easily get out of lock and be destructive. Therefore, today, more than in the past, we must offer not only Slovakia, but also Europe a positive vision. A vision of a fair, safe and well-managed society. Places where people want to live, work, raise their children. I believe we can agree on such a vision. Today, however, it is necessary to move from words to actions. So that the judiciary, education, health, social services are functioning and that even the most vulnerable, children and adults with disabilities, can live a dignified life.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Pellegrini that it is a pleasure to see him here today. We have met a couple of times in the past year following the very dramatic events in your country, the murder of Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová, but I will come back to that in a minute. I was visiting your country as the Chair of the Rule of Law Monitoring Group, and I went to Slovakia with some critical questions, but it also made me feel that we have a special bond as Europeans. I have a special place in my heart for Slovakia and the Slovaks now. I very much agree with one thing you said, and I think that this is key: there is no Eastern Europe or Western Europe or Central Europe – there is only one Europe. It is about time for everybody to start feeling that, particularly in Western Europe, where they are still blind on one side.  I very much welcome your speech; it shows leadership in Europe. It was a very pro-European and ambitious speech, and it clarifies what ALDE also feels: the European Union needs to be much more than mere technocratic intergovernmental cooperation. In the world of today, we need a fully-fledged political union to give an answer to all the political challenges that we have, because that is the only way to remain a global leader. Your speech was excellent, but as we all know, true leadership is not in words – it is in actions. Like many countries in Europe and in the wider world, your country is witnessing deep divisions, and forces are pulling it in different directions. I just referred to my visit as the Chair of the Rule of Law Monitoring Group, and I have seen that there are many positive developments in Slovakia. I have seen that the institutions are strong and that civic engagement is extremely strong in Slovakia, and I commend the Slovak people for that. Many concerns remain, however, and new ones are also emerging.  I would urge you to show the same leadership in tackling these concerns, because in a sense you hold the key. You hold the key to the future of the European Union, and the choices that you make will determine not only the future of your country, but also that of the European Union as a whole. You can show which forces will prevail in the European Union.  You have a choice, and this will be a burden on your shoulders, I warn you. You are at the fork in the road. Do you want to join and strengthen the ranks of those who are wrecking the European Union, those who put short-term electoral gains, or even material gains, before the general interest – or worse, the ranks of those who are corrupt, even connected to organised crime? Or do you want to go down in history as a statesman, somebody courageous and wise in difficult times, who led his country forward, making it a role model for others, a leader in the Europe of the future. So do you choose the old Europe or the new Europe? I hope, and trust, that you will choose leadership for the future, and I shall be very specific. I would strongly recommend that you break ranks with Mr Fico, because he is the old Slovakia – you are the new Slovakia – and show the world that there is truly a new hand at the helm in Slovakia. You can also show them that the Visegrád Four is staunchly pro-European and not the vehicle of reactionary nationalist autocrats. It is very important that those guilty of the murder of Ján and Martina are brought to trial – not just those who actually carried out the murder and were arrested, but the brains behind it. That is crucial for trust in the Slovak authorities.  I also count on you to make sure that the nominations of nine Constitutional Court judges happen very shortly, because the Constitutional Court is effectively not operational. I would also urge you to reverse the changes to the media law, because in practice it means severe restrictions on freedom of speech. Finally, I would call on you next month to decide to extend to cooperation with Europol, and not just for the investigation into the murder of Ján and Martina, but also the other parts of the investigation that have been split off by the Ministry of Justice into corruption and fraud and all the other things. In other words, I have just put a burden on your shoulder and I am asking you to choose. I am counting on your wisdom. You can count on the European Parliament, and I can also pledge my personal commitment in the next period to working with you and with the civic forces in Slovakia to make sure that you can provide this leadership in the European Union.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister very much for joining this debate on the future of Europe. The future of Europe has lots of different, very important, aspects and the one I would like to focus on today is the issue of democracy. I think the way in which the European Union treats democratic deficits in the future is really decisive of how we’re moving forward. There is of course also advancing the democratic procedures inside the European Union – definitely – but the question right now is also how we deal with Member States who are turning the clock backwards on the rule of law, democracy and civil liberties.  Hungary might be the worst example in the whole picture, but we also see a lot of problems in other Member States. So we should really look around and not close our eyes to what’s happening in terms of media freedom, freedom of association and freedom of speech – all of those things which are very, very important. In Slovakia you have the situation where a journalist was murdered because of his investigation into corruption and fraud, and that is something which we need to deal with. We need to make sure it never happens again anywhere in the European Union.  So it’s really time that we address this issue, especially at the European Union level, because there are so many citizens out in the streets in Budapest, Warsaw and Bucharest who are asking the European Union to step up and to help them because their own governments won’t listen to them. So we need to get active on that. They are European citizens like all of us. But, instead of helping, at the European Union level we see too much infighting between parties – ‘is it your bad guys or my bad guy?’ – but we need to get beyond that so that we ensure the civil liberties and the rights of all European citizens.  For that, my group is suggesting that we set up an independent commission of experts to look into the situation of the rule of law and democracy in every single Member State all the time and is then able to give recommendations before it’s too late. It’s also a problem right now that we are only starting when things are too late. This commission would also be able to enact sanctions if necessary. Indeed, we also need to look at the European Union funds because, unfortunately, some governments use them to implement their personal pet projects, to favour certain people or to ensure favourable reporting. But the EU funds also do a lot of good. You’ve mentioned the Cohesion Funds, which are very important for many citizens. We have many Citizens’ Initiative projects going on. EU funds are important all over Europe. So we need to find a smart way to deal with that situation without cutting the support to our European citizens when we’re actually trying to hit the government and a specific action of the government. So for that we are suggesting that we ask the Commission to take over the distributing element of that whole so that the money still arrives with the citizens and for the benefit of the citizens without being used at the discretion of national government. This is certainly not the easiest answer – maybe cutting funds might be easier – but it’s one where we ensure that there remains a link between the EU institutions and citizens without allowing the governments to do whatever they want with that. Mr Prime Minister, you made a very interesting and comprehensive speech about all sorts of aspects, but you also underlined the issue of unity and understanding. I think that is very important indeed and we count on you to promote those ideas, also in the Council, which is being difficult and blocking a lot of initiatives that also come from this House.  We also count on you to implement all of those issues and promote democracy and the rule of law in Slovakia. The issue of press freedom has been mentioned. This is very important. Addressing fraud and corruption is not an easy task anywhere, but it needs to be done. There have been examples in Slovakia of how urgent that matter is. All of those issues are also very important for a well—functioning state that could put forward all of these reforms that you’ve been advocating, and of course especially also to continue the investigation into the murder of  Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová will be extremely important until the masterminds have been found. I think the help of Europol will be important in that.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Prime Minister, thank you for coming among us today, and I am very glad that there has been a voice from the countries of Central Europe and the Visegrad Four, because there are often very misconceptions about these countries, even here in the European Parliament. I believe that today's speech by the Prime Minister showed us that the attempt to demonise the countries of the Visegrad Four is simply not entirely based on the truth, and that these countries also have a lot to offer the European Union and want to present their vision for the future of Europe.  As the Prime Minister certainly knows, after the murder of Jan Kuciak and his partner, the European Parliament mourned with the Slovak people and strongly appealed for this case to be resolved as quickly as possible and justice to be served. It is certain that this case has significantly affected the functioning of the Slovak State and, unfortunately, its position externally. However, it must be seen that we have a representative of a sovereign state that is concerned with the situation and continues to take further steps to ensure that Slovakia's development fulfils the democratic values on which Slovakia was founded. The current Slovak government has prepared free lunches for primary school pupils, prepared a balanced budget for the first time in the country's history and radically increased salaries in public and state administration. Slovakia's economy is growing, unemployment is falling, and wages are rising relatively quickly. A record increase in the minimum wage is planned, which I consider to be a demonstration that Slovakia has not suffered and is dedicated to improving the quality of life on its territory at several levels. This, too, must therefore be taken into account if we want to see Slovakia, dear colleagues, in a comprehensive way.  Prime Minister, a year ago, I appealed from this place to my colleagues in the European Parliament to respect democratic control and the indivisibility of power and to let the Slovak authorities facing an extremely difficult situation act. I called for the debate on the death of Ján Kuciak to be conducted with respect to Slovakia and its democratic and independent institutions. I have also expressed my conviction that Slovakia deserves a helping hand if it asks for it and not a conviction. Your speech today assured me that this view was correct and Slovakia was, is and will be aware of the demands placed on it, and can deal with them with dignity.  However, we are now in a situation where the whole of the European Union needs a helping hand. So you, too, did not hesitate to come among us with your visions of helping Europe in a difficult hour. The debate on the future of the European Union must continue, which we should be aware of on the very day that another important Brexit vote is taking place in London. I believe that the biggest problems of the moment could be summed up in three points: the European Commission is too strong and, moreover, it is disconnected from the people, the European Parliament does not have a legislative initiative and the European Union is not democratic and social enough. In this we face the danger of climate change, which is manifested not only by extreme weather fluctuations, but also by shifting the natural strips that make previously fertile areas arid deserts. There is a loss of drinking water, animal species, melting glaciers changing the direction of ocean currents, which again affects the climate. The European Union itself simply needs to return its attention to European citizens. Now we are at the end of a five-year parliamentary term, with the European Union, or the new Commission, looking around for six months, talking for two years about nothing but migration, then another two years on Brexit, and the last six months commuting the agenda and preparing for elections. Citizens will be able to cancel the time change at the last minute and hope that it will take a few percent of the vote away from the nationalists. This is simply no longer the way to do politics for citizens. And let us face it, citizens are in the dark about the European Union and its work. European citizens' initiatives can also be proof of this. Since this instrument, many of us have promised to bridge the gap between the citizen and the European Union, but there has been bitter disappointment and calls for reform. However, even this did not work out here, as it seems that only a new restriction has been created that would allow people to participate in European democracy instead of eliminating existing problems. Prime Minister, thank you for meeting us, I wish you good luck and I firmly believe that this debate will not be about what Slovakia should do, but what we should do together as the whole of the European Union.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, today and here the main question to which we have to find an answer and we do not have much time for that work is why? Finding why the reality of the European Union is fundamentally different from that of the parents of the European Community is probably the only way to find an answer to the constantly plaguing question of what is happening to us and what is being done with us. Mr Prime Minister, the idea of a Europe of nations from which it began is being destroyed by the hands of irresponsible politicians by the European Union itself. So far, it has lost only Britain, the first and last warning to those who want to replace the Union of European States with a global Europe. There is no such and cannot be. As there is no global view of Lithuania, as is the absence of today's global Slovakia, mr. Peter Pellegrini, our guest, the Slovak, who today chairs the Visegrád group of countries, which offers a much more promising model for the future of the European Union than that proposed by the federalists. Globalism imposed on society is a capital hydrant that makes a profit for every land patch and profits at all costs, degrading states and burdening people. It is a policy that is designed to turn society into a workforce without a homeland, without conviction, and states without their loyal citizens. Mr. Prime Minister, I was, I am a citizen of Lithuania. I do not want and will never be a citizen of the European Union. I believe that poles, French, Germans or Catalans who have tried their leaders in Spain would also not want to renounce their nationality and citizenship. The current European Union, plagued by uncharted identity complexes, is a severe sick person – a sick person whose talk of democracy, solidarity, deeper integration will not be cured by any goldsmith. We need a good surgeon who, for health reasons, will detract from the festering arguments of genderism, multiculturalism and globalism. Politicians must stop oppressing people under the guise of democracy and the free market, must abandon their dogmas, supposedly the only right imposes on society, must stop lying, stop scaring. We need to negotiate, not manage. We need dialogue, not a new European Union based on confrontation.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, I warmly welcome the Prime Minister of Slovakia, Mr Pellegrini, to this Parliament. I certainly do not agree with his vision of the EU , as I would like to say in advance. His political color is not mine either. But still.  I greatly appreciate the fight against corruption that the Prime Minister is leading in his country. This is a very important step in slovakia's future. Slovakia is a member of the Visegrad Group, and even president at the moment. I would like to say that the visegrad countries' policy on migration can count on my support. It is the Visegrad Group that holds up a mirror to the EU, which shows the EU how it should be done. The EU is failing hopelessly in its approach to illegal migration. Instead of ensuring watertight borders, the EU is coming up with the loser's solution, which is to legalise illegal migration.  The EU says it stands for European values, but welcomes migrants who hate these values, welcomes migrants who despise these values and would prefer to introduce Sharia law into the EU as soon as possible. It is the Visegrad countries that are genuinely defending European values, standing for a Europe that defends its freedoms, its human rights. That is why I would like to express my support for Mr Pellegrini and the Slovak Government in their rejection of the UN migration pact.  In Slovakia, people are all too aware of the horrors of totalitarian domination based on a totalitarian ideology. Until 1989, the communist regime was under the suffering of the communist regime. They, the Slovaks, know what it's like to live in fear, to have to keep quiet about what you actually think and feel. Such totalitarian ideologies must not gain a foothold in Europe. That is why it is quite right that the Central European Member States should oppose the Islamisation of their country. A religion that at the same time claims absolute control over the political domain is thus a totalitarian ideology that is incompatible with everything the EU stands for, with all European values, with all European human rights, with all European freedoms.  I would add that there has often been talk here of fake news, including by Mr Pellegrini and also by various speakers. It is freedom of expression that is at the heart of our democracy. It is precisely by constantly calling for the treatment of fake news, but at the same time to cast itself as the one who decides on it and thereby smoling any criticism of policy, that is worthy of a dictatorship. That is why I am also warning Mr Pellegrini not to support the EU that is so dangerous to freedom of expression.  I call on the Commission to take an example to Slovakia to tackle corruption in its own ranks. To remove Mr Selmayr from office. To stop funneling billions to corrupt countries like Ukraine and to half of Africa, where corruption is the most common thing in the world. I call on the Commission to take an example of the resilience of the Visegrad countries to illegal migrants that are in no way adaptable to our societies. Let the EU close its borders, both between member states and with third countries, and let the EU reject the UN migration pact. That is why I call on the Commission to give the Member States' own identity the highest priority so that internal security can be put in order. This European Commission, which cannot act, must resign!

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I would like to thank the Prime Minister very warmly for his speech and start by thanking him for his unequivocal declaration and determination to investigate the murder of a Slovak journalist. These are things that we need to respond to for obvious reasons.  Three points are very important here. Firstly, the concern – expressed in the Prime Minister's speech – not to divide Europe into western and eastern europe, not to multiply mistrust. All the more so because a great many of the problems facing Europe stem not from the experience of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, but also from the threat to the stability of the euro area. Secondly, seeing regional integration as a component of wider integration. It is great that the Prime Minister mentioned the name of the forerunner of European integration, Milan Hodza.  Finally, the battle to oppose protectionism, the closure of the markets of rich European countries, including competitiveness at the expense of economic energy, especially that of the peoples of Central and Eastern Europe. These are indeed the spheres on which the future of the Union and its true development depend.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic. – Ladies and gentlemen, allow me to make a few comments on the topics you raised during your speeches. I would like to begin by thanking you very much for the words of support that you have addressed to the Slovak Republic. Also for the words of appreciation in those areas where the Slovak Republic has done a great deal of work and moved very forward. I want to assure you all that the government under my leadership will not in any way change our clear pro-European, our clear proseveroatlantic course. Although there may be opinions or some other views within the governing coalition on the matter, I want to guarantee that the government responsible for the foreign policy of the Slovak Republic will continue to act as I said. Slovakia belongs to the European Union, Slovakia has no room for its existence other than the European Union, and Slovakia is aware that, even in the field of security and defence, it will never be able to defend itself and always wants and will always be a responsible member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. And I would like to remind you that, thanks also to the excellent economic results of my country, as my colleague from the Czech Republic mentioned here, even though we are trying to raise people's quality of life and invest a huge amount of money in social measures, we are still able to find the resources to meet our commitment and meet 2% of gross domestic product expenditure on our defence and security as soon as possible, unlike many NATO member countries. This is also not the norm in other larger countries that are NATO member countries, let alone the quality and combat capabilities of their armies, which we can read about in the media. I want to assure you that nothing changes on this, and if my colleague from the Netherlands asked me which party I would choose, then I want to reassure her that I will choose the right one and I will always stand on the side of those ideas that I also raised in my speech, because I believe that they are the only right solution for my country. We touched several – and I expected it, because it is very fresh – and the tragic event concerning the murder of a journalist. I would like to remind you that, before this happened, Slovakia belonged to forgive me if I made a mischug, but we were 17th in the world in terms of freedom of speech and the press. I repeat the 17th, that is, if we have 28 Member States, you can imagine how many of them – and often many older democracies – have not reached and are below the level of freedom of speech and the press as recognised in the Slovak Republic. I want to emphasise this, because maybe little is known about it, and maybe you don't always know everything about it either. We are very sorry for the tragedy that has occurred, I want to assure you that we will do everything we can to send out a clear signal that we will never tolerate such things in Slovakia and that we will do everything we can to ensure that such crimes do not happen again, not only in Slovakia, but nowhere in the world, anywhere in Europe. And, colleague, I don't think you're going to comment on the resignation of the Prime Minister and the departure of some ministers in the way you did, that you said, "Well, the Prime Minister just resigned." The prime minister's resignation is a major political gesture and probably the highest the leader in the country can make. I want to assure you that we are doing everything we can to punish the culprits, and the perpetrators of the murder, along with the orderer, are most likely already in prison and will await a fair trial. Let us wish together that nowhere on European soil would such things happen any more. If we are talking about the fight against corruption, against the misuse of certain subsidy schemes and EU funds, I would like to assure you that here too, the Slovak Republic is taking many measures and things that may have happened in Slovakia, perhaps sometime in 2016, 2016, can no longer happen in 2018 or 2019, because we have already responded to the findings and measures. And I always appreciate very constructive discussions with the committee that comes or comes to Slovakia, where we can exchange information with each other and where we can say what we have already managed and identify areas where we still have work to do.  And Slovakia is a democratic country in which our parliamentary system is fully respected, where the power of government comes from parliament, where the government is accountable to the National Council and the coalition majority. I would remind you that, in the area of agro-subsidies, even if mistakes are made, Slovakia is the second eu-wide country after Estonia, with the lowest error rate of 0.5% of all agri-subsidies. Of course, they are very visible , but that does not mean that the whole system is dysfunctional, so I would ask you not to resort to flat-rate and from some partial problems the country as a whole every time you talk about the Slovak Republic. I will never allow myself to do that, and I have not allowed myself to say to your country, based on any specific events in one of your countries, that it looks like it everywhere and that those countries work that way. That wouldn't be fair, and that's why, as I he said, we must respect each other – and thank you for saying this to many – we must stop sharing west and east, we must stop sharing into large and small, we must stop sharing north and south, we must stop sharing with the rich and the poor. I am very pleased that my colleague, who was the first to speak, said at the end of the election and used the expression when the demands of both large and small will be heard. And I fully agree with you, colleague, because only then will the Union be able to function with one voice when both the big and the small listen to each other, because that unity in diversity is the key and the foundation on which the EU is built. Finally, let me say one more thing, because you have all mentioned that we need to move from words to deeds, and I fully agree with you, because unless the citizens of the European Union, Europeans feel that we are not only talking, but also really solving their daily problems, that we are not really dealing with pseudothemes that do not plague our citizens on a daily basis, but that we are dealing with precisely that. , which angers them every day and what they would need to solve, only then will we be able to maintain support, broad support for Europeans in the European Union project. Finally, Perhaps I would use an expression or phrase: the citizens of the European Union must first of all be able to rely on the European Union. The citizens of the European Union must first rely on the European Union, on being able to ensure their protection, their prosperity, their democratic values. First of all, the citizens of the European Union must rely on the European Union, only then must we do everything we can to ensure that everyone around us can rely on the European Union. First of all, the European Union and the whole project must be trusted by those who live in it, and only then can we deal with whether we are good enough to be able to rely on us and the whole world. But first we need to focus on things inside and do our homework at home.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, thank you very much for your presentation. I must say, first of all, that we have a great concern about the issues of the rule of law, corruption in Slovakia. And what I would like to see, so that the words you left here today, particularly with regard to the murder of Jan Kuciak and his companion and the investigation associated with him, was Slovakia, in the face of developments such as those we see today in Romania, or developments as we see in Malta, being able, if not through his Prime Minister , at least through his party, to make a clear denunciation of this situation. Because Slovakia can make a lot of progress from the point of view of prosperity, as I said, and from the point of view of integration into the European Union, but it will not really be a country with European values if these serious suspicions remain that the rule of law does not work and does not work seriously in Slovakia and does not work, in particular , by action of the Socialist Party and the European Socialist Party which is unable to denounce such crimes and activities at European level.

name: Babette WINTER
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-The-European Commissioner for his work It is encouraging that the Slovak Government wants to work on the unity of the European Union, and I am very grateful for what you have said here. You said, Prime Minister: we must overcome the division in the European Union, and that is not only, but also, an East-West divide. I say this as a Member of Parliament from Germany, from central Germany, which comes from an area that itself used to be a socialist GDR 30 years ago. In Germany, even 30 years after the peaceful revolution, we are witnessing how the great upheavals continue. We must – and here I appeal to you – make this even more important within the EU and acknowledge this tremendous achievement of building democracy after overcoming socialism. These social processes cannot be overcome by cohesion policy alone. It is also a question of recognition, including from the other states in the EU. You, as chairman of the Visegrid Group with a pro-European approach, can build these bridges; I appeal to you, I encourage you. You mentioned the Weimar Triangle, the german-French approaches, but also working in the Visegrid Group to ensure that there is a pro-European approach. I appeal to you to stand up for the many citizens in the Visegrid countries who are pro-European and against what has been said here, particularly on the right, about the EU.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: – Mr President, Mr Pellegrini, you described your vision of an attractive European Union. I would like to tell you that if Prime Minister May today gets her deal through the British Parliament, I don’t think we will have an attractive European Union. Britain was always an advocate for competition and now we are going towards harmonisation. Britain was always an advocate for safe responsibility for countries’ debts and now we are going towards socialisation. Britain was always in favour of subsidiarity and now we are going towards centralisation. My last hope for an attractive European Union is that the British Parliament today rejects the deal and opens the way towards a second referendum with the result that Britain stays in the European Union.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Mr President, Prime Minister Pellegrini, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his work and for the work he has I focus on the situation of Slovak citizens with a Romno background, i.e. Roma and Sinti. Segregation in education, housing, access to the labour market and health care are commonplace, for example in the village of Rankovce, where about 300 Slovak Roma live and have to get their water from two wells with hand pumps. According to the European Fundamental Rights Agency (FRA), 43% of schoolchildren with a Romno background in Slovakia have been subjected to anti-Gypsy insults in the last 12 months. More than half of the respondents feel discriminated against in the profession because of their membership of the minority. Unfortunately, we also have similar figures in Germany. It is sad – physical violence due to anti-Gypsy hatred is experienced in Slovakia by one in nine People in Rome or Romni. The proportion of young people from the minority without a job or training has risen sharply, while the figures for the majority population are stable. In addition, the attendance of children with a Romno background has increased in percentage terms in recent years, but is lagging behind that of the majority population in the order of magnitude. I attended a Roma high school in Kosice, where 90% of the pupils were Roma and the rest were difficult to educate from the majority population. What measures do you propose, Prime Minister, to combat the long-established anti-Gypsyism effectively? How do you intend to counteract the proven unequal treatment and exploitation of Slovak citizens with a Romno background?

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Prime Minister, welcome! Your party belongs to the Socialist Group and you have told us the right things about cohesion policies and the need to promote measures in favour of the social pillar. Can you explain to me on the refugee issue, which you did not mention, why you are pursuing a policy that is so close to Viktor Orbán's policy, if not similar? Viktor Orbán, in a few days' time, is talking about excluding him from his ranks even the European People's Party, which is much further to the right than your party.  As President-in-Office of the Visegrád countries, do you intend to help Parliament and the Commission to finally have this reform of asylum policies and a fair distribution of responsibilities among all European states in the refugee crisis? Or will you block, together with Orbán and Kaczyński, the single European refugee policy? You have told us many nice things about Europe and unity and democracy. But it's time to put it into practice on the refugee issue as well.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, Mr Pellegrini, this debate is about the future of Europe, but the blunt truth is that the EU only has a future if it learns to respect the wishes of people across Europe to maintain the sovereignty of their nations. In my country, that manifested itself in the glorious vote for Brexit. In Peterborough, where I’m based, more than 60% voted to leave. Until yesterday, the grand old men of the EU pretended to respect that, but last night, Mr Juncker himself warned the British people that unless the Brexit-in-name-only withdrawal agreement is accepted, there may be no Brexit at all. With a craven British Prime Minister sitting next to him like some lapdog, the EU’s top man sought to call the British people to heel. What arrogance! What conceit!  You should have let us go with good will. Instead, you have decided to make an example of us to frighten the others. The EU clearly has the measure of Mrs May, but the British people will never surrender to these imperial ambitions.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, I warmly welcome Mr Pellegrini to the European Parliament. We are pleased that you have come to talk to us about your views on the future of Europe and the European Union. I think the future is here and now. All of us and those who do not sit here make it up, and we all have a responsibility to it. You have made it clear what place for Slovakia you imagine in this European Union. I appreciate it, it was explained very clearly. Nevertheless, or perhaps that is precisely why I would like to appeal to you, Prime Minister, to think about this responsibility, european democracy, responsibility for European solidarity and responsibility for European security when presenting your positions and positions, whether in the European Union or in Slovakia. So that you can stand up to those of your colleagues and political partners in Slovakia who deliberately spread fictional lies about the European Union and who gamble with the trust of Slovak society towards the Union. I would like you to be able to comment on this and I wish you success in your further work for Slovakia.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, I also welcome you to the European Parliament, which has indeed been very active towards Slovakia in the last year. This was also reflected in the fact that we pushed for the creation of an international investigation team and we can already see the results, especially after the murders of Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová. And I believe this team will continue. This was also reflected in the fact that we acted on the basis of the Special Committee on Tax Fraud on the Bašternák or Kočner cases, and it is clear that only European cooperation and information sharing can prevent such fraud. This has also been reflected in the mandatory control of European money going to agriculture, which is one of our main competences. In this context, there is a specific situation in Slovakia where most of the support goes not to small farmers, as in the Union, but to large farmers. Therefore, substantial changes are needed, which I would also like to ask you to do. It is, first and foremost, a change in land adjustments, a compulsory scoring of payments, but above all in the control of the distribution of European resources, because it is not possible for the money-distributed government agency not to know who owns the land and who is doing its job on it. These changes are necessary not only to improve the situation of small farmers, but also to better control European resources.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, I congratulate you on your speech and your vision for the European Union. You are the 18th Prime Minister—Minister or Head of State to present his vision. I come from Romania. I am glad that Slovakia, a country that is not very far from my country, has such a vision and such a leader. You said that we need an attractive, united, prosperous, secure and honest Europe towards citizens. It's perfect, that's my point. But I want to ask you on time. You talked about the Cohesion Fund. Do you think, Prime Minister, that it is right to make cohesion funds conditional on the functioning of the rule of law? Is this provision in the treaty? What's your position? And the second question. Does it seem to you that it is honest with the citizens of Romania and Bulgaria for us to have a resolution in Parliament that these two countries be Schengen and in the Council there has been an opposition for years since 2011? Is it honesty towards citizens? Is it honest that we have for two countries the CVM, which is obsolete? There is no provision in the treaty - to have CVM. What do you think and how can we explain now, on the eve of the elections, in our countries? Behold, two colleagues here have nominated your country and my country, because we have people in the streets, but they have not said anything about France, where people have been on the streets for months.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic. – Mr President, let me respond to a few of those speeches, because I do not have the capacity to be able to respond to all of them at the end. I'll touch the agri-food. I fully agree with what the Member has said with regard to the control of these funds and, of course, the prevention of any defrauding. But I would like to ask all of you HERE - MEPs - what kind of system this is if, under the Brussels regulation, we distribute subsidies on the basis of managed hectares, regardless of whether someone is doing something about it or mowing grass only twice a year. How is it possible that we are forced to pay everyone a certain amount of European money across the board, without the possibility of cutting this money to those who do nothing on that land, do not employ anyone, produce nothing, do nothing, do nothing, ensure nothing or have no contribution to the self-sufficiency of Slovakia or Europe. How is this possible? Then it becomes not a real system for supporting agriculture, but it is a fight over subsidies, that is, a war, who will have on paper how many hectares, cut twice a year, sit at home and receive subsidies. This is flawed, and we need to change this so that we do not support from European money those who do nothing on European soil and only mow twice. They can do this without needing the resources of the European Union to do so. Secondly, my fellow Member from Romania: Slovakia has always clearly supported and will support that, if a country fulfils any conditions, that is to say, in this case, the conditions for joining Schengen, it is important that it is given a clear answer so that Romania and Bulgaria do not play a political game, but if they are technically ready then we should, of course, be absolutely clear about when and by what date Bulgaria and Romania will join Schengen. , already in view of the situation we are facing when the European Union's external borders need to be protected. I don't know what we're hesitant about and what the political games are. Likewise, the Union, somewhat by turning, should also treat the countries of the Western Balkans fairly, because we cannot endlessly tell them: 'do such a reform, change that, open such a chapter, I do not know what spros...'. Painful things have to be done by those countries. And by the time those countries tolerate this and by when the citizens will be able and willing to make such reforms, when they do not see the light at the end of the tunnel, and we are unable to answer them when they can become part of this, as we call it, an elite club. These are precisely the things where the Union makes a mistake and where it does not send out fundamental ideas around where necessary. So I wanted to comment now on these two things.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab Europe must be a community of destiny in order to survive, so as important as a sense of unity is a sense of respect for our individual experiences and for the character of the smaller communities we create, such as the community of nations, the community of destiny and the cultural community of the peoples of Central Europe. I would like to congratulate Slovakia on its defence and opposition to the Istanbul Gender Convention. On this issue, some countries have gone very far in defending their families, as have Bulgaria. And still a third of the European Union countries have an independent position on this issue. I would like to say that the position you are in is important not only for Slovakia and for the future of your families, but is important for the survival of a Europe as it is. Accepting, for example, those certain peoples who wish to remain faithful to the civilization of life and family is a matter of Europe's survival, including the survival of the cooperation of our states and peoples. Because when the identity of nations is outlawed, Europe will actually cease to exist.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Prime Minister, you have talked about the future of Europe. I would like to ask you how you rate Mr Orbán's policy in relation to the values on which the European Union is built. You spoke in conjunction with the Visegrad Four about the need for dialogue, you talked about the ineffectiveness of nationalism. Is Mr Orbán's nationalism and populism not a danger to Slovakia? Thank you for your reply.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Prime Minister, welcome to the European Parliament, I am glad that you have presented your vision for a common European Union. You had to count on facing criticism for investigating the murder of Ján Kuciak and his partner, because the killers were found, but not the ones who ordered the murder. Until the case is clarified, you must count on us not to consider this case closed, because freedom of speech is a condition for a functioning democracy in the Member States, but also in the European Union, and we must defend media freedom. Slovakia knows well that its place is in the European Union and in the euro area, and no one in your country can think of anything to change that. Euroscepticism is also not a good political agenda in Slovakia, while it is very blooming in many other countries. I wish Slovakia to obtain a European employment office, as it is called in short. I think that a seat in Slovakia would be a good example of cooperation on the territory of the European Union.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, welcome to the European Parliament. You spoke very nicely about the vision of the European Union. I am in favour of this, and I think that we will only have a common Europe if we all, every single Member State, pull together. In the end, it was talked about. As a negative example, my colleague from Romania has cited when we are preventing Romanians and Bulgarians from entering the Schengen area. I would just ask two questions: how can we pull together when Nordstream 2 is on the table? And my question is how are the individual prime ministers in the Council of the European Union occupying this position, because I think we are damaging some Member States. Another question is how the European Council is approaching the deploying of individual agencies, because we know how unfairly and against all the rules the Medicines Agency has been divided or allocated, and now a working agency is on the table. So if you could comment on this, then.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister Pellegrini, tonight is the meaningful vote on Brexit in the House of Commons. I personally don’t support Mrs May’s hard Brexit deal as it recognises her regrettable red lines to leave the EU single market and customs union, so it can never really deliver UK—EU frictionless trade.  Nevertheless, there is one part of the Withdrawal Agreement I do strongly agree with, which is its aspiration to keep the United Kingdom closely linked to the EU’s internal and external security arrangements. On internal security, I particularly fear now a security cliff edge if there’s a no-deal scenario, excluding the United Kingdom’s access to key EU databases and instruments such as the Schengen Information System (SIS) and the Anti-Counterfeiting Rapid Intelligence System (ACRIS) database. It’s also vital to keep the UK, post Brexit, close to the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) and the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) in the external security area.  The UK is a UN Security Council P5 member and a nuclear power. So how, Prime Minister Pellegrini, do you see, post Brexit, a way of keeping the United Kingdom closely linked into the EU security structures and, in particular, the Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO), which you mentioned in your speech?

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Dear! I have heard a dozen Heads of Government in this Chamber who have spoken about the future of Europe, and I must say that I have not found anything appalling or controversial in these speeches. Quite the opposite. There were compliments to the European institutions, to the European Parliament, to our activities. Unfortunately, however, I am concerned about the gap between the words that fall here and those that are being implemented in favour of national policy. This span, in my opinion, is unfortunately devastating. This applies to different political groups. What is important to me, on the other hand, is today's clear declaration of reducing these disparities, of reducing everything that does not fit into the debate on the values of the European Union. Do you see this problem? Do you also draw attention to how the Visegrad Group works to strengthen the European institutions? And does this strengthening not raise some doubts in the Lord from time to time?

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Mr Prime Minister, you mentioned 1989. That's when we saw a divided Europe. Today, however, we do not have a very united European union. Mr Juncker has called for attention to the dialogue within the Višegrad Quad. I would like to know what you see as a key specific of Central Europe and what should the conversation with the rest of Europe in particular be about?

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Prime Minister Pellegrini for being here and for making the case for a more social Europe. Wages, equal pay, unemployment schemes and decent jobs are of the essence to relaunch Europe. Best wishes to Mr Maroš Šefčovič, who is running for the Slovakian Presidency, and, of course, all support to your endeavours to clear out the murderer of the Slovakian journalists and to fight corruption against EU interests. But, just a question, as you’re about to hold the presidency of the Visegrád Group: what is its nature? What’s its purpose? What does it deliver? And, more importantly, you’ve heard a Member here saying that the purpose of the Visegrád Group is to close the external borders in order to prevent Sharia and Islamisation. Do you agree with that notorious infamy? Or do you disagree with that crap? Because we didn’t hear a word from you. You didn’t react when you heard that notorious infamy, which is absolutely unacceptable. Is that the purpose of the Visegrád Group, Prime Minister Pellegrini?

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the My answer, Prime Minister, is also a response to Emmanuel Macron, who has given us a great deal of attention and is stirring up. He said, like you, that we in the European Union need basic social security and a European minimum wage.  Now all of us know that the level of prosperity is crucial for social services. However, since the levels of prosperity in the EU are different, there can be no uniform minimum wages, no uniform basic security. Otherwise there would be unemployment. So there is only the possibility of redistribution. That is what we should say here, even if Mr Juncker feels happy that this is being done here. That gives a redistribution.  And then I would like to quote a sentence from Mr Macron: without the euro, which makes the whole eu strong, we could not resist the crises of financial capitalism. There is no more wrong sentence than this one. For the euro has not made the Euro-Union strong, it is weakening it, it is dividing it. The Eurounion is the weakest growing region in the global economy. That is the truth. Everything else is fake news.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Dear Prime Minister, my intervention will have two parts. The first part is that I expected you to present some vision, that you will show us, as prime minister of Slovakia, a sovereign country, that you want to reform the European Union and show us how you want to reform agricultural policy, for example. Are you sure you can determine where the agricultural subsidies will go?  And the second thing, Prime Minister, to which I would like an answer – several victims in Slovakia have been mentioned here. I'd like to remember Vlad Rybár. When we were in Slovakia, we were supposed to meet him. He is a farmer who had lucrative land near Bratislava. When we got there, the police told us he committed suicide. Now it turns out that Vlado Rybár was murdered. I would like to ask you whether you are also investigating these cases, whether you will really be paying attention to these reports of the European Parliament and whether members of the European Parliament are really a nuisance to you, as you commented on in the context of our visit to Slovakia.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic. – I am sorry, colleague, but I must respond to you immediately. Because I will not tolerate, although I am in the European Parliament, for a Member of the European Parliament to tell such false truths and lies. If you mentioned Mr. Fisher and you want to give the impression that he was murdered for plots and so on, then I will bring to your attention the statements of his own son, who said that Mr. Fisher is being abused by those who organize protests, that these people did not know him in his life, never met him, that his father was in trouble a long time ago and has been worried about some other things for months. and that he does not want anyone to associate his death, which is properly investigated and which shows that it was completely different from what you said, that he does not want his father to be drawn into such political games. So I would ask you, Member, not to draw conclusions and to talk about the Slovak Republic, something that is not at all true, because I will never allow myself to do so, and I have never allowed myself to do so in relation to the Czech Republic, even though you also have your own problems there. So I'm going to ask you for correctness, because only then will we be able to have a responsible debate. Yes. If you are talking about agro-subsidies, I have just spoken. Change is needed so that we do not support those who just have land on paper, do nothing on it, contribute to the self-sufficiency of the European Union and receive the same share of European money as those who loo and work there from morning to evening. And if Mrs Smolková asked me about Nord Stream 2: yes, here too, there has been a huge amount of talk about how we must and should help Ukraine. But this is an excellent case of how we can hurt her. The Slovak Republic has fulfilled its task and made technical changes in order to reverse the flow – and to this day, even this winter, we supply Ukraine through our transit pipeline towards Ukraine in order to guarantee their energy security. But there are countries that are also able to sell off this idea that we should take care of Ukraine and are willing to tolerate a bypass that, once they have arrived, it will be possible to bypass the whole of Ukraine. And I am very sorry that, even with the recent allocation of agencies, which you, Commissioner, referred to – there were two – and which everyone has made clear are to end up in one of the new countries of the European Union and should end up in one where there is no agency yet, they have both ended up in the old country, the Member State of the Union, and ended up in those countries where there are already agencies. And then it is difficult to talk about the fact that let us stop sharing the old and the new, the west and east, and the rich and the poor, when even such manifestations give a clear signal as it really is. And then what can citizens who live in that other part of the European Union think about it? I'm sorry, but I'll always be very open and very direct to you in answering the questions you're asking.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, Dear Prime Minister Pellegrini, thank you for your contribution to the important debate on the future of Europe. I am glad that your Slovakia can boast of good results. As you said yourself, it has not always been easy and the path was not easy, but Slovakia today is in every sense a more prosperable state than it was at the moment it became independent. Taking responsibility for their own destiny has brought prosperity and a better quality of life for Slovak citizens. Isn't that proof that independence was a good path for your country? But now you recommend further political integration and want to leave decisions about the fate of Slovaks to the bigger and stronger ones. It's basically a "more Europe" story. Behind the façade of solidarity, common values, fraternity and unity is a new process of making most political decisions at the European level in which smaller countries such as your Slovakia and my Croatia have a weaker opportunity to protect their interests. The concentration of political power in Brussels cannot possibly be in the interest of Zagreb or Bratislava.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: – Mr President, I, too, Prime Minister, undoubtedly have many problems of its own, such as mafia influence or massive corruption. However, most of these problems must be dealt with by our country itself. Namely, a government that will be created by free, general and secret elections. Therefore, although at home I am one of the harshest critics of Prime Minister Pellegrini and the Direction party from which he comes, here I want to defend himself against interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. I find it unacceptable for Mr Papadimoulis to train the Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic here. How come we allow ourselves to reject migrants? However, by interfering, I am not referring to the investigation into the murder of journalists that we have asked for, and I would also like to thank Sophie in 't VELD and Mrs Grässle for their involvement. If the European Union wants to do something so that there are no differences between west and east, between old and new, please. Let it comply with the rules that it has given, let it have the same standard for everyone, let it pay the same agri-food for all, so that it does not violate sanctions, such as Nord Stream 2, so that the European Commission, in particular, treats everyone equally, then there will be no differences either.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, thank you very much for your strong support for a social Europe and for standing up for the principle of national minimum wages, the importance of which President Juncker has just impressively emphasised here in this House. In Germany, it was the SPD that implemented the minimum wage, and East Germany benefited in particular. The Socialists and Democrats are now fighting alongside you for this principle in Europe.  Mr Juncker, however, the Conservatives are now taking the flag off the mark on this issue. The new CDU chairman Kramp-Karrenbauer spoke out clearly at the weekend against the principle of national minimum wages – we are in favour of this principle. I would also like to emphasise that, for me, respect for Fundamental European values, such as the rule of law, freedom of the press and freedom of expression, is of great importance.  They are currently in the important role of leading the Visegrid Group. I appeal to you, as an East German, as a Visegrid-German, to make this clear, particularly to Hungary and Poland. Together we fought and overcame socialism. Let us now stand up for this democracy, in this Europe in which we are strong.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, I also thank you for presenting a vision for Slovakia, a vision for Europe, and I agree that Slovakia wants to be a responsible partner in the European Union and that our success is linked precisely to our European integration and involvement in the North Atlantic structures. But I pause at the position that Slovakia wants to be part of all activities that are directed towards the tightening of unity or, as you have often said, to be at the core, part of the core of the European Union. However, are you really sure that our citizens want more Of the European Union in areas such as the European social pillar or a common European army? As a Slovak representative in this House, I consider it important to talk about the need to reduce the level of involvement of the Institutions of the European Union in the interests of subsidiarity. As President of the European Christian Political Movement, I offer a reform of the European Union in which we point out where the European institutions and legislation are beneficial and bring about the real development of Slovakia. It is crucial that we re-implement the vision of the founding fathers based on Judd-Christian values in the challenges facing today's Europe. I believe that Slovakia's fundamental values are also a strength of the European Union. Together, we honour responsibility and want to work for a future in which life is valued and society is fruitful so that it can bring peace and stability to future generations.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic. – Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, before I make any concluding remarks, let me answer one question that has been raised: what is Slovakia's role? What is the role of the V4 countries, but what should be the role of all the leaders, all 28 and 27 countries of the European Union? The main task, both mine and my colleagues, must be one thing: for people in our countries to live well. That is the only and clear goal with which we are taking over leadership and mandate, and that is all we have to get up with in the morning and fall asleep in the evening so that our citizens can live well and peacefully. Therefore, I always respect, if we are talking about someone and something, whether we have achieved this goal first, so that we can then engage in take-off and noble debates about some other things. How can you force the citizens of the European Union to discuss some pseudotheses unless they take out a paycheck or have a job, or as seniors who receive their pension here, live in a poverty zone. Let us first sort out these things, and then we can bring to our debates noble and big themes that, of course, belong to modern society, but unless we have the homework done, that Europeans will not be happy and well-lived, let us first do our part. And I am pleased that people are starting to live better in our region than they used to, that our region is thriving economically, both socially and culturally and socially, and I am reasonably proud of that.  And thank you for the words of support to all those who supported us and who also supported the Slovak Republic in some comments that already go beyond the powers of a particular Member, sometimes standards of decent behaviour. Finally, Mr President, colleagues, let me state that the European Union will remain a pillar of stability, freedom and prosperity for Slovakia, for us. Yes, I am aware of both our weaknesses and our mistakes and those of the European Union, but we want to tackle them together as part of the further construction of the European project. We have common challenges economically, socially, environmentally, here in these areas, let us please seek unity together. I reiterate technological developments, which are extremely important and where we must not stand behind other parts of the world.  If we are talking about cohesion, please let us not bring politics into it and whether or not someone wants to continue cohesion. Cohesion was created to help us close the major regional disparities not only between Member States, but also within the Member States. Cohesion is not supposed to be a hostage to political games. If we have to say with regret that the process of reducing regional disparities in the European Union has stalled, that is the appalling news that it has stalled, so to have a debate on what the future of cohesion should be is perverse. Ladies and gentlemen, cohesion must be there as long as the regional differences here are as pronounced as they are. In the meantime, we have a duty to eliminate these regional differences between parts of Europe, unless we eliminate them completely, and then we can discuss whether or not cohesion should still exist in our European area. Finally, let us all be as close as possible to the citizen, as close as possible to those people who will be deciding in a few months' time who will sit in these important chairs. And I want to assure you that, as Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic, I will do my best to ensure that Slovakia continues to be a positive voice and a constructive voice from Central Europe.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – While the European economy is growing for the seventh year in a while, the situation of workers, Europeans living on wages and salaries is not improving. They bear the brunt of the crisis, from rescuing banks to balancing state budgets. Taxes have risen, public services have increased, there has been less access to education, health care, unemployment benefits, support for the most vulnerable. Millions lost their jobs, and when they found a new employer, they often had to accept extremely unfaithful employment contracts. It's a mass scene that working people live below the living wage. Mass child poverty, vulnerability. Desperation is a breeding ground for extremists who are now conspiring to destroy the entire EU. Neither the state nor the economy reciprocated the sacrifice of taxpayers. In the long term, the information revolution threatens to bring down labour. We need a fundamental turnaround. The social market economy must be restored, incomes redistrebuted – for the benefit of workers. In addition to creating jobs, we must use the strength of the European Union to guarantee a minimum level of humane wages and pensions, support for families with children. We must eradicate child poverty throughout the EU. A European multi-tax should be levied on large companies to finance this. We must put an end to tax evasion, to the robbery of workers. A strong, close,united Europe can be nothing but a Europe of social rights!

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, before we proceed to the vote, I should like to draw the attention of this Parliament to the shameful injustice suffered by Nasrin Sotoudeh, the former Sakharov Prize winner, who was sentenced to four decades in prison and 148 lashes for defending women's rights in Iran, for having called in Iran for the abolition of the death penalty.  So I believe that this Parliament, Mr President, through your authoritative voice, through the authoritative voice of the President of this Parliament, must express an immediate opinion on an absolute condemnation of this shameful judgment that has taken place in Iran, and I believe that we should immediately call for the immediate and unreserved release of Nasrin Sotoudeh, because that is truly incredible!  Iran is once again becoming a bitter enemy of women's rights, and that is truly intolerable, Mr President.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Ms Picierno, we have taken note of your comments and will pass them to the President.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, apart from criminal law cases, there should be no justification for the lifting of parliamentary immunity. Jean-Marie Le Pen, on the other hand, has always voted in favour of his persecuted colleagues, because in this case it is a political persecution. If, on the pretext of an ideological dispute alone, you vote for the tenth time against Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity, it means that you find it normal that partisan elements interfere in the work of your assistants, that the European administration, by order, arrogates itself the right to take... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Ms Arnautu, we will move to the vote. We are not having a debate now.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: Madam President, I will be very quick. When speaking out, you should be precise and avoid any confusion. Mrs Hohlmeier herself has asked for the lifting of her parliamentary immunity for a banal history of a road accident and, therefore, I do not accept that everything should be mixed up.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you for that clarification.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, in this house we can hear every day great plans for Europe, further political integration, new common institutions, a large budget for ambitious programmes, the European army, the United States of Europe and so on. Big ideas, and in practice it looks like this: even in the third term of the European Parliament, in whose work members from Croatia will participate, our Croatian language will not be fully applied in the work of this institution. Extension of Article 159 The Rules of Procedure mean a further postponement of the full application of the Croatian, Irish and Maltese languages, explaining that even at the beginning of the next parliament there will be no capacity to provide a complete translation service. So how many centuries exactly does it take to secure these capacities? Unlike Ireland and Malta, the Republic of Croatia has one official language, Croatian, so with this decision Croats, with the silence of the Croatian Government, still remain second-class citizens in the European Union. Colleagues, let's see now how united we really are in diversity in this Parliament.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Ms Tomaševski, thank you for your point. I think there has been a great deal of advice on this issue.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, I was most interested in this: if you can check freight with satellites, why is there a problem doing that with the border in Northern Ireland? Surely we do not need to have a hard border in Northern Ireland if we can do it by having satellites. So if it works for other parts of the world, why not Northern Ireland? Is it singularly unable to use satellites? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am afraid, Mr Coburn, I don’t have the time to explain the ‘why’ of that just now because we are in the middle of votes, but I did hear your comment.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, we are voting on the first of a set of reports on the safety of Europeans, including, in this parliamentary session in Strasbourg, the report on the Internal Security Fund of the European Union.  And I think it is an occasion to remember that yesterday was the fifteenth birthday of the massacre with the greatest number of victims that recalls the history of the European Union: the terrorist massacre that took place in Spain on 11 March 2004.  And I therefore believe that it is a good occasion for us in the act of voting to send a message of infinite solidarity with the victims of terrorism and determination in the fight against all forms of terrorism and its threats.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr López Aguilar, your point is well supported.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I just wanted to ask, in accordance with Rule 59(3) of the Rules of Procedure, to vote first on the amendments, and also I would like to ask for a roll call vote on the procedure of this decision.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, very briefly, we’ve negotiated this for years. We’ve got a deal. Parliament got significance concessions. If any amendment passes, the deal falls, so I would object to the proposal by the GUE/NGL and suggest that we just vote directly on the deal.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all my fellow Members for the extraordinary cooperation that has led to the very broad adoption of this directive. Without this fundamental team game we would not have been able to achieve today a result that could have seemed difficult, if not unattainable.
