Ladies and gentlemen, it is only 11 months since the proposal was presented, and today we can finally say that we have given a concrete response to the demands of European farmers, producers and consumers that have been unheard for too long. This Parliament, Mr President, has done a little miracle, but it is only a first step. We must now make the most of what has been achieved and ensure that it is applied fully in our Member States. This is the Europe we want: a Europe that is supportive of the weakest companies and that protects our consumers, with transparent rules that ensure the quality of products and the sustainability of production processes. I very much hope that this direction can be followed in the future with the same commitment, the same seriousness and cooperation on the part of all.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I wish to present, on behalf of my Group, a request to proceed to the votes on the amendments, in accordance with Rule 59 of the Rules of Procedure, and to request that the vote be taken by roll call. I believe that the current text has some flaws, as denounced by several non—governmental organisations, and my Group has tabled amendments aimed at improving it. The amendments touch upon important issues: in particular, preserving the individual online collection systems; requesting the Commission to carry out real legislative follow—up in full observance of Article 11 of the Treaty; and allowing citizens’ initiatives to propose the modification of ongoing legislative proposals.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, in accordance with Article 59, paragraph 3, of the regulation, I ask that the amendments be put to a vote and I would like my application to be dealt with by roll call.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Madam President, I would like to move the following oral amendment: expresses its conviction that Russia’s membership in the Council of Europe is an important element of the present landscape of institutional relations in Europe; hopes that ways can be found to convince Russia of not abandoning its Council of Europe membership.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, it’s nice to be first. I welcome this important partnership agreement and commend the work done by the rapporteur, MEP Hautala and my colleague, Mr Franck Proust. The protection of forestry is an extremely important element in the overall protection of the environment and in slowing down climate change. The illegal timber trade has a devastating environmental effect and so I welcome this recommendation warmly as a step in the right direction for both the EU and Vietnam. The preservation of habitats and biodiversity can only be accomplished by working with third countries to ensure that not only does the EU not export illegal timber, but equally does not support the trade of imported illegal timber. I am hopeful that this Voluntary Partnership Agreement will achieve this, and I welcome the firm commitments given by Vietnam to set up the necessary structures to enforce the commitments included in this agreement.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, I’m in favour of this accord. It seems a perfectly sensible thing for the European Union to work with Vietnam on sustainability. But I’d ask Members just to stand back and contemplate the miracle that has made this report possible: that sees Vietnam exporting a sum equivalent to its GDP. In the mid—1980s, Vietnam was one of the poorest countries in the world. GDP was a little bit over USD 200. Now it has increased by 1 000% – by 2 000% if we measure by purchasing power parity. What an extraordinary thing, when we think of the lengths that the USA went to to stamp out communism by military means – spending a trillion dollars at today’s prices, losing 60 000 of its soldiers, 250 000 South Vietnamese, a million North Vietnamese – and it failed! Yet a couple of decades of free trade have led to the rule of law and the development of economic freedom in that country. It’s the same lesson every time. Let goods and services cross borders so that soldiers don’t have to.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, Britain is the EU’s largest importer of tropical timber by a significant margin. I support the voluntary partnership agreement with Vietnam as an important contribution in the fight against illegal logging, with governments, civil society and businesses working together. Sadly, across the world, up to half of all timber still comes from illegal sources. Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade (FLEGT) is a good thing, but the voluntary approach alone is not going to defeat the illegal timber trade. My view is that the UK and the EU need to go further with legislation banning all imports of illegal and destructively logged timber, coupled with more support to improve governance and stamp out corruption in timber producing countries. Illegal logging robs governments and communities of resources. It damages ecosystems, accelerates climate change and fuels conflict. We cannot afford to rest until the market for illegal timber in Europe is closed forever.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Yesterday's debate was very interesting, and during it I was able to speak on the first report, the first part. On the other hand, there was no time to comment on the latter very important issue, which is why today, for the sake of completeness, firstly, the most important, most controversial issue was the inclusion of dual nationals in the decisions on this report. I am very pleased that an agreement was reached on this issue at the end of 2018 and the consequence was today's vote. I will also draw attention to a very important issue concerning the data of persons with not only dual nationality, but also those who have so far e gone from those decisions that concern the register – the register, as if there were no, the criminal problems of different persons. For europe's security, the decisions that have been made today are, from my point of view, beneficial.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Madam President, from the outset I had denounced the Bulimic tendency of the Commission, which, together with the European Solidarity Corps, created a duplication of the European Voluntary Service. There was no doubt that this new program would seek to justify its existence by increasingly extending its prerogatives. Today, all this is confirmed. While the previous text was adopted just a few months ago, its scope is extended to humanitarian aid operations, being a citizen of a Member State is no longer a condition to participate, the budget is increased. Absurd, when you know that the program does not meet the expected success! What revolts me above all is the impossibility of carrying out these activities of solidarity in his own country. Brussels therefore invites solidarity, but as far away from home as possible, and we are told that activities must focus on solving the challenges faced by migrants. As we can see, this love of others leads to self-disregard. If it wasn't that bad, it would be laughable.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I believe that the Solidarity Corps has real potential to bring added European value to the social policies. It creates solidarity among young Europeans and allows for the personal growth of participants. It is particularly great that, since 2019, organisations from non-EU countries can participate in these projects. In the case of European Neighbourhood Policy countries, it becomes another element in the chain of contacts and people—to—people diplomacy. In addition to that, volunteering strengthens engagement and makes young people appreciate the non—material side of their work. I supported this report and I wish volunteering could become a part of life for other groups of citizens who want to get engaged in the issues of public interest, dedicating some hours per week to a cause that they really care about.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Today I would like to draw attention to three points. Firstly, in this 2018-2020 perspective, I am talking about a budget – we only have indicative, I stress, indicative thresholds for the distribution of funds. It is very important that they are made more complete. Secondly, we do not currently have adequate promotion of this important completely new programme. Thirdly, the use of dynamic means of communication – I think of these social networks – is essential today during the implementation of this project. Otherwise, this programme will be a half-success. And the last thing, very important. We are talking about young people here. We are talking about budget resources dedicated to them. A new strategy is needed for the younger generation in order to make it a real subject for all the programmes that we are currently trying to integrate into the European Solidarity Corps.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Solidarity Corps is not only a great initiative, but also a beautiful and noble idea. It has moral, ethical, humanitarian, charitable, educational qualities...  This is very important, because it gives an opportunity for self-realization, but also for improving professional qualifications. It supports the population, the regions, the countries, it gives the opportunity to participate – it will give the opportunity to participate up to three hundred and fifty thousand people.  It is therefore not surprising that the Innovation Institute in Vienna has rewarded this initiative and this project, which is why I supported this report.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report which created the European Solidarity Corps programme because, at a time of the rise of nationalism and xenophobia on our continent, all initiatives that strengthen active citizenship and the concept of solidarity must be supported.  However, since this programme is, from its inception, more than a mere voluntary programme and also covers support for mobility and volunteering projects in the professional context, through professional internships and contracts with structures that carry out actions in the social area, it is important to ensure that abuses of abuse are avoided in its practical implementation and that the European Solidarity Corps is not used by non-governmental organisations , by public bodies and public undertakings to obtain cheap labour.  Volunteering, which can, of course, improve young people's employment prospects, should not be seen as a substitute for decently paid employment as a way of perpetuarising job ties or as a substitute for policies to combat the scourge of youth unemployment in Europe.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I too was pleased to vote in favour of this report, and indeed the objectives of this important programme to promote solidarity as a value and enhance the engagement of young people. The European Solidarity Corps programme is a valuable pathway for young people to develop their skills, whether through an internship, traineeship or volunteering experience. The changes proposed, to increase the budget for the programme, will allow many more to benefit from it. I welcome particularly the emphasis to be placed on marginalised and disadvantaged young people. Four hundred and eighty Irish young people have already registered to take part and I hope to see many more do so from all backgrounds, including especially those in isolated rural regions and other disadvantaged areas on which the programme aims to focus particular attention.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we are talking about cyber security at a time when there are serious violations in certain Member States. Yesterday I asked the Commissioner, Mr Anship, to take a stand on the complaints I made, because the Greek Government is making preventive arrests of those who disagree with the sell-off of our Macedonia and our history, and has made preventive arrests in the Giannitsa region. And the Minister of Civil Protection said she knows their details because the police monitor Facebook and social media.  This is happening today in Greece and cases are being formed against those who disagree with the sell-off of Macedonia, those who disagree with the despicable agreement of the Prespas, those who participate in the rallies. The government processes their personal data and intervenes and sees what they stand for and what they say on social media. The Commission must take a position on this issue.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab On a very important cybersecurity issue, we have made up for lost time. I would remind you that the topic was taken up two years ago with good, as it turns out, result. I would remind you that an agreement was reached in December last year at the trilogue and as a result we were able to approve the document submitted in the ITRE Committee later in January this year. Today we voted it. I would point out that this permanent mandate for the agencies is important on one very important point. In addition to collecting data, in addition to all these expert activities, it was the first time that operational tasks could be carried out. I draw attention to this because, in cybersecurity in particular, the effectiveness of the ability to act, not just collect information, is indeed a key element in building security in cyberspace.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – In Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar an achta seo agus ghlacas páirt sa díospóireacht a bhí againn aréir agus molaim arís ár gcara agus ár rapóirtéir, Angelika Niebler, as an sárobair atéanta aici maidir leis an acht Gach lá cloisimid anois faoi fhogha cibir and ngach uile áit, cuid díobh déanta ag daoine aonair, cuid díobh ó chomhlachtaí caimiléireachta, agus cuid díobh, agus a lán díobh, ó thíortha cosúil leis an Rúis agus an Chóiré Thuaidh. Dá bhrí sin, tá sé an-tábhachtach go mbeimid ar an airdeall agus go ndéanfaimid gach rud chun é seo a chosc, agus cabhróidh an t-acht seo chun é sin a dhéanamh. Go háirithe, molaim an chumhacht atá á tabhairt do ENISA - d'fhéadfadh siad i bhfad níos mó a dhéanamh agus déanfaidh siad sin de bharr an achta seo, go háirithe mar a bhaineann le teastas agus mar sin de. Dá bhrí sin, is céim ar aghaidh an t-acht seo agus molaim é.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report because we know that in my country, where the price of milk is 28 cents, milk producers receive no more than the cost of production, whereas processors receive much more, which leaves the former in a position of particular weakness in relation to unfair commercial practices. Agricultural producers often do not have a bargaining power equivalent to that of the partners who buy their products.  Unfair trade practices throughout the food supply chain are so significant that the European Commission has had to intervene three times and it is time to really take the reins on this issue. For these reasons, this Commission proposal on unfair commercial practices corresponds to a strong and long-standing demand from the agricultural population and the conviction that farmers should be much better protected against these unfair abusive and commercial practices.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, in order to support our farmers, there must be an absolute ban on all unfair practices and not just specific practices as described in the report. All practices that are unfair must be stopped, as it is a given that producers earn only 20 % of the selling price of a agricultural product. Because in essence there is an obscene profit, on the part of food distribution companies, from the food chains which in practice exploit the producers themselves by blackmail, by lowering prices, they take cheques and in the end they do not pay and also the wholesalers, in essence, form such prices that the producers themselves make no profit. So an absolute ban on all unfair practices that are to the detriment of our farmers.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Payments after thirty days after delivery, unilateral cancellation of contracts, unilateral or retrospective changes to contract terms, demand payment for the delivery of goods, demand payment by the supplier for loss or deterioration of the goods, for storage, for promoting, for advertising, for displaying on shelves, also the obligation to accept without payment the return of unsold goods, to cover discounts, et cetera, et cetera – these are just some examples of commercial practices considered unfair. It's good that we do it. It is also good that within the framework of a directive, not a regulation, and thus giving Member States flexibility in making their own decisions. We must also bear in mind that there are always two parties to the agreement here, and of course if one applies unfair practices to the other, especially the weaker and the smaller, it is necessary to intervene, but also each case must be decided on a case-by-case basis.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour because I believe that the European citizens' initiative is a direct instrument of public, democratic and participatory participation. I actively participated in defending several of them, such as the right to water as a basic human right, which has finally not passed, or that of the "Minority Safe Pack, to protect the languages of national minorities, language rights and cultures. There is much to be improved, such as the deadline for collecting signatures which should be much longer, also the awareness campaigns and the proof is that there have been few initiatives approved since it came into force in 2011. The Commission shall make available to the public an online register enabling groups of organisers to manage their initiative during the process. Online registration should include an effective and easy public access website with general, clear, accurate and comprehensive information.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the European Citizens' Initiative is an expression of the principle of participatory democracy within the European Union and should be exercised in the most democratic, direct and absolute way, without bureaucracies. There is a contradiction here: with the European Initiative, citizens are calling on the Commission to take a legislative initiative. But who controls whether this citizens' legislative initiative is legitimate? The Commission. So here we have "John drinks and John buys". So, practically what's going on? The Commission itself checks whether the legislative initiative is correct, while the Initiative itself calls on the Commission to decide. I said that another body had to check the legitimacy of the Citizens' Initiative. In any case, we need a system that gives citizens the opportunity to fully exercise this right, which is the right to participatory democracy.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) was created as a tool for sharing power by making citizens active participants in legislation, but it is still inefficient and not a single legislative initiative of the Commission was based on an ECI. Sixty-three per cent of citizens have little or no knowledge of their rights under EU law. At the same time, thousands of lobbyists operate in Brussels and dominate in the EU policy process.  In this reality, it’s very difficult for EU citizens to make their voices heard and the reform of the ECI in a fact need. But, in my opinion, the current reform package makes it even more difficult for citizens to participate, for example, by eliminating individual online collection systems. We are in the 21st century and we need to have quick and easy digital ways to encourage civic engagement. But, of course, in general, I voted in favour.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Citizens' Initiative is not only an instrument of democracy, but it is also a mechanism for the un uniting of European citizens around ideas, around the issue, around a single objective, if only because at least seven citizens, at least seven countries, are needed to set up a Citizens' Committee. And, of course, then collecting a million signatures. Great thing. Further liberalisation and facilitation are, of course, needed. We have introduced more support from the European Commission for this, central signature collection and much more. But for me, it is very valuable that the European Parliament is currently sitting on the initiatives that will be tabled. And so it will be. I therefore support this report.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of the report modernising the European citizens' initiative because I believe that this instrument of participation and bringing citizens closer must be put more credible. This must bring this instrument together and not further divide the citizens. It needs to give more opportunities for participation through a Europe that has its differences, allowing the use of subscription collection platforms, both from the European Commission and independently, provided that they are recognised by competent authorities to prevent possible fraud.  The debate on these initiatives must be integrative and that it favours dialogue between all civil society actors, because this is the only way to reach consensus. It is also necessary to give time for the proposals to consolidate and can effectively reach a cohesive legislative process. This instrument must mirror the real will of citizens distributed throughout the territory of the Union so that it is not captive to the interests of a few, a single Member State or a financial interest.  For all this to happen, resources and tools must be allocated to embeit citizens so that they can seriously make use of this democratic instrument of the European Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I was taken aback by the spirit of hostility the rapporteur managed to impart on this report and it states that EU relations with Russia are based on deterrence and isolation. It gives many recommendations on how to limit cooperation with the Russian Federation and no recommendation on how to resume communication. It also undermines the credibility of the EU message by expressing mere beliefs, condemnations and accusations on the issues which have not even been investigated. Concerning the sanctions, the more effective they are at weakening the Russian economy, the more they undermine the EU’s bigger objective. First, because a weaker Russia would not be a better partner and second, sanctions marginalise pro—Western members of the Russian elite, meaning that we managed to lose the interlocutors we needed. Of course, the real challenge of the EU foreign policy is not Russia, as the report states. The real challenge of the group of European politicians, unlike some Members of this House who still profess confrontation and an overtly anti-Russian agenda with the hope to collect some votes, voted against.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Dear Colleagues, I agree with Mr Mamiekins's arguments and I would like to say that Russia is a country of strategic importance and position for much of Europe. It is the country bordering the most Member States of the European Union and has a common border with the Union of nearly 2 300 kilometers.  Denying her strategic partner status, in addition to being short-sighted, is also a strategic mistake. Such a thesis means a denial of 21st-century European real politics. No one benefits from coming out with political declarations soaked in the language of the edingist tone.  I would like to draw attention to paragraph 6, for example, which strongly condemns Russia's involvement in the Skripal case. This is a bold statement, given that Britain's special services have yet to give 100 per cent certainty about this claim even a year after this case. Do my colleagues who supported this text have more knowledge and information than the intelligence services? Lastly, we criticize investigative journalism in third countries, but did you know, dear colleagues, that broadcasts are being taken off national air in Bulgaria because they reveal the truth about corrupt practices in the country?

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, armed conflicts are rarely fought on well—defined battlefields, but in and around communities. Health, education, transport and employment opportunities all suffer. Women are in the middle of this, yet they are excluded in global work on preventing conflict, mediation and peace-building. Indeed, women have made up just 2% of mediators and 5% of witnesses or signatories to major peace processes in the last 30 years. This report, like UN Resolution 1325, rightly accepts that women experience conflicts differently from men. Take Kashmir, where 8 000 men are unaccounted for since 1989, leaving thousands of half-widows living in poverty, lacking property rights and unable to remarry, pellet guns blinding and maiming and the use of rape as a weapon of war. After 70 years we need some new approaches, and I hope that this report is a step in the right direction.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on a European regime for sanctioning human rights violations (2019/2580(RSP)).

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I very much agree with colleagues that human rights are under attack worldwide and on the need to continue to do all we can to prevent gross human rights violations. A major challenge for us is always to focus even more on the day—to—day implementation of our extensive toolbox and convince partners to deliver on existing commitments and obligations.  Our current EU human rights toolbox is already quite comprehensive, encompassing a strong multilateral and bilateral dimension. The Union will continue to denounce human rights violations and abuses wherever they are committed, to call on state and non-state actors to prevent them, and to seek justice and accountability. There is no doubt about that. It’s true that the global landscape is rapidly evolving and we need to ensure that the European Union is adequately equipped to remain a leader in the field of human rights. In this context, a targeted assessment is ongoing as to how a European Union horizontal human rights sanction regime might bring added value in our collective efforts to further realise human rights and prevent gross violations or abuses of human rights. Here the issue of the scope of a possible future regime will be particularly important and the need to define which type of violations would fall under such a regime. Should such a regime, for example, focus on gross and systematic human rights violations? Should it cover violations of international humanitarian law? Should it address corruption cases? Another important question is the interplay between such a potential regime and other existing EU sanctions regimes, but also regimes established at UN and national level. Human rights violations are already addressed in a number of geographical sanction regimes, for example, in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Iran and Myanmar. Here we should consider whether the potential of integrating human rights into geographical regimes has been fully exploited. Obviously, there are some existing gaps, since geographical sanction regimes by definition are limited in focus. Could a horizontal human rights sanction regime usefully fill such a gap and offer a more flexible approach? Last but not least, sanctions listings must be underpinned by robust, open—source evidence in order to be upheld in court. Listings are reviewed regularly and listed persons have the right to have their delisting requests considered. Respecting due process is an overarching principle underpinning all sanction regimes, but even more so in the context of a potential human rights regime. Given these multiple important issues, I am therefore pleased that expert discussions are taking place in the Council to look in detail at all these elements. Once the experts have finalised their discussions, more political discussions can take place. The creation of any new regime is a matter for the 28 Member States to agree by unanimity, as is the imposition of concrete sanctions. Thank you for your attention and your interest. I am looking forward to our discussion.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, sometimes a name means a lot. To name a European human rights violations sanctions regime after Sergei Magnitsky would send an unambiguous message to the human rights abusers in our closest neighbourhood that Europe is going to create serious consequences for them and around the world. Magnitsky stood up to the corruption of the Putin regime. The way in which the Russian Government tried to cover up his murder and exonerate the people involved became a symbol of impunity worldwide. That is why Magnitsky’s name speaks to people everywhere.  I believe that the repeated calls of this House to adopt a European Magnitsky Act mean creating a legal basis for imposing visa sanctions and asset freezes on human rights violators around the world. There should be no impunity for killers of Rohingya in Myanmar, the rapists in the Central African Republic or the killers of the Saudi journalist. We will once again urge the Commission and the European External Action Service (EEAS) to come up with a proposal for an EU Magnitsky Act before the end of the current parliamentary term. The Council has so far failed to act, but now this initiative is gaining momentum.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, in 2013, this Parliament adopted by an overwhelming majority the report "Corruption in the public and private sectors, impact on human rights in third countries" of which I was rapporteur, which says in paragraph 3: "It is of the opinion that the EU should follow the example of the United States of America with regard to the adoption of the 'Sergei Magnitsky Rule of Law Accountability Act' of 2012 and adopt similar legislation at the level of the as a symbolic and operational framework linking corruption and human rights violations; calls on the Council to establish a common EU-wide list of officials involved in the death of Sergei Magnitsky, the subsequent cover-up of the case and calls on the Commission to draw up an action plan to impose similar specific sanctions against third-country officials involved in serious human rights violations and judicial 'manipulation' against whistleblowers , journalists investigating corruption cases and human rights activists."  That is exactly what, six years later, is reinforced by the resolution which the European Parliament will vote tomorrow. The mechanism we specify has the name Magnitsky with him, because it originates in this assassination perpetrated in Putin's Russia, but has universal application wherever similar crimes occur. We list the basic criteria, requiring action and coherence from Member States to the application of sanctions, a crucial requirement at a time when many of our governments seem to be hostages to oligarchic, corrupt and human rights violatorgovernments, from Moscow to Beijing and from Rad to Washington in the Trump era. By the way, if those responsible for the murders of Daphne Caruana Galizia and Jan Kuciak and partner do not go to trial we should consider the application of such sanctions to those responsible for the cover-up in those countries of the European Union.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Milton Friedman argues that one of the great mistakes is to judge policies and programmes by their intentions rather than their results. From Ancient Greece’s Peloponnesian War, to modern-day Belarus, Iran, Myanmar, North Korea and Russia, evidence suggests that sanctions targeted at entire countries rarely achieve the intended foreign-policy objectives. Very often, collective punishments result in further collectivism. Innocent citizens in sanctioned countries become even more dependent on their domestic oppressors for the straight provision of basic goods in return for further encroachment on their political and social freedoms. As a free marketeer, I have always believed in individual responsibility. We should, therefore, promote a smarter sanctions policy to ensure that sanctions are both legally robust and effective against those individuals committing abuses around the world.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, it’s hard to believe that it’s been almost nine years since I first submitted amendments for a European Magnitsky Act, and the urgency for us of having an EU-wide smart mechanism to hold human rights violators individually to account has only become more pressing since then. Given that the UN Security Council and the UN generally is often paralysed and blocked by vetoes, the EU should show leadership and join the coalition of the willing – if you want to look at it that way – between the USA, the UK, Canada and the Baltic states, which already have ‘Magnitsky’ laws. Targeted human rights sanctions, including asset freezes, entry bans and also the calling out by name of perpetrators of the worst human rights violations, whether they be state or non-state actors, can make a huge difference, including in terms of differentiating between the punishment of individuals versus hitting entire populations. It is the elites who often participate in these human rights violations who enjoy buying real estate in Europe, sending their children to our top universities or going shopping in our wonderful capitals. We cannot allow such ‘business as usual’ to continue for the murderers of journalists or the rapists of women. When we talk about sanctions regimes, let us also look at ourselves critically because, despite sanctions being in place, Ali Mamlouk from Syria, on our blacklist, visited Italy, companies from the EU built the Kerch Strait Bridge, chemicals were exported from Belgium to Syria – and the list goes on. Clearly we’re only as credible as the weakest link in our own behaviour. Concluding, a horizontal human rights sanction regime is essential, but it can never replace the need to hold perpetrators to account through criminal prosecution in domestic and international courts. It is high time to end impunity and, if we adopt this regulation, it would also be a small step towards justice for Sergei Magnitsky.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the By creating an EU-wide sanctions mechanism against those responsible for human rights violations, we are sending a very clear signal that human rights violations must always be punished. Priority must always be given to prosecuting the perpetrators, but it must also be punished in cases where the perpetrators can evade prosecution. The EU has long applied personal sanctions. One of the first EU entry bans due to human rights violations was imposed in the context of the execution of Nigerian environmental activist Ken Saro-Wiwa in 1995. Today, it is important that we implement the application of entry bans and the freezing of accounts against perpetrators efficiently, transparently and in due process. It is therefore right that sanctions decisions can be challenged in court. It is necessary to have robust evidence, which is also available to the public. Civil society organisations can make an important contribution to making it more successful. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card question. – I want to raise the question as to why the Green Group would not support naming this legislation the ‘Magnitsky Act’ – not only because it has a symbolic meaning, which is obvious, but because it’s a way of defining why we need to have this legislation in place, and to send a signal to those who use criminality to make themselves rich at the expense of their own people. Why couldn’t your group support giving this legislation the proper name?

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. To your question, we also discussed at great length with all political groups in the Subcommittee on Human Rights. So, there is only one case in the world, namely the corresponding US law, which has the Magnitsky case in its title. All other laws that are just as well and very qualified and good, for example in Canada, have a technical terminology. I believe that Mr Preda is wrong to assume that he is saying that this law would be less important or less perceived if it did not have this title. And I very much regret that he did not mention in the committee meeting that, of course, in the text of the resolution we can refer ourselves to the Magnitsky case, which was very crucial in the whole development of such a kind of sanctions regime.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, while it is obviously vital to severely punish any violation of human rights, it is certainly not for the European Union to impose sanctions on them. You are brandishing this anathema against the States, and in particular the Member States, which do not approve of your migration policies or about gender ideology - I am obviously thinking of Poland, or Hungary. You are using this argument to try to bring down your political opponents, which is doubly reprehensible, firstly because you are exploiting the cause of human rights, however noble, for lowly political purposes, but also because by acting in this way, you are masking the real threats to European citizens, in particular that of radical Islamism, which, among other things, makes, among other things, , roll back women's rights. I could also mention the 372 victims of Islamic terrorism in France over the past 20 years. This is what really threatens human rights. And how can we not mention the European Court charged with ensuring that these same rights are respected - I mean the ECHR - which protects these terrorists, on the contrary. Recently, she even banned the expulsion of Kamel Daoudi, an Algerian terrorist stripped of his French nationality, now housed at the Princess's expense in Aurillac. It also prohibits the systematic search of visitors to prison, which led to the attack by another terrorist of two prison guards in Condé-sur-Sarthe last week. Your interference and those of supranational structures become unbearable and are dangerous for our fellow citizens.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, we are all well aware of the context of the draft resolution we are debating today. Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, the United Kingdom, Canada and the USA have their Magnitsky laws in action, enabling their governments to impose targeted sanctions on perpetrators and beneficiaries of serious human rights violations. We, the European Parliament, have repeatedly called for the establishment of an EU-wide equivalent. I am convinced that this has to be done at EU level, and without further postponement or delay. I call on High Representative Mogherini and I urge the Commission and the European External Action Service to bring forward a legislative proposal for an EU Magnitsky Act before – and I stress before – the end of the current parliamentary term. I firmly believe we have had enough of differing interpretation and differing implementation of the EU sanctions, and we should stop this practice.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, the European Union is now a major reference, if not the world's leading reference, with regard to the protection of human rights. In no other part of the world do we find the same degree of concern, vigilance and respect in the field of these rights.  Citizens and civil society organisations from all corners of the world go to the European Union when their human rights are called into question because they know that they will be heard and that they will, as far as possible, be defended. But this moral and political authority is only truly credible if it is accompanied by instruments that do not leave unpunished those who disrespect human rights and that erode the rule of law through corruption.  Political or institutional condemnation, being indispensable, is not, however, sufficient. Effective desuasion must go beyond diplomatic pressure and in many cases pass through sanctions.  That is why strengthening the European Union's sanctions regime, making them more consequential and more targeted, is a very important step towards consolidating the European Union as the outpost of the human rights cause in the world.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab Our human rights policy should be based on a few simple principles. First, fidelity to those who support our rights. Secondly, recognition for those who wish us peace. Thirdly, respect for those who protect those for whom we are particularly responsible– for example Christians in countries where they are at risk. At the heart of this policy should always be people – the right of people to live in peace and security, which is the basis of all human rights, and certainly not to animate political conflicts. Of course, Europe should intervene humanitarianly, it should respond to injustice, but always remembering that it is not about spreading some kind of political universalism, it is about defending specific people with an awareness of what our actions mean. We have the problem of Algeria today, perhaps tomorrow we will decide on it. Let us remember these principles.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Mr President, in my previous life and also as a Member of the European Parliament, I spent some 18 years working on sanctions against Zimbabwe, against the government in Zimbabwe. Those were so-called smart sanctions. Nevertheless, every February it was a battle in the Council between the European Member States to continue these sanctions for another year. When I listen to colleagues here, it seems as if it is easy to finally start a new European sanctions regime that focuses on individuals and makes the debate on country sanctions a little easier. It's not that simple! If we see that the Dutch Government took an initiative last November, very low profile, without publicising it, to get Member States on the same page to achieve such a regime of targeted sanctions, then we can see how difficult it is.  You can all now suggest that it is simple and that if we only give it one name, it will give extra rights. That's not true!

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr President, O human rights, what tartufferies are not committed in your name... Once again, we have to copy and paste an American law, the Magnitsky Act. Its sole purpose was to make Russian leaders threaten financial sanctions and traffic restrictions, in order to force them to accept foreign interference, particularly american interference, and ultimately to prevent Russia from regaining its regional position. Under the pretext of enforcing human rights all over the world and punishing leaders who do not comply, you wish to gain an influence that only certain Member States of the Union still have. Enough hypocrisy! You don't have to be a big cleric to guess that the leaders of certain countries will be spared when the Union's economy has more to lose than to gain from it. For, in truth, in the Union today, only profits are considered paramount. World leaders, depending on whether your countries are powerful or weak, the judgments of the Union will make you white or black.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Mr President, since 1990 when the democratic clause was first included in the European Union-Argentina Agreement, this is an essential element of the agreements which the European Union has signed with third countries. This democratic clause is in the Union's genetic code and is tangible proof of the European Union's indispensable commitment to respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.  However, there are two problems. First, the application, which is not immediate. And, secondly, the delay in decision-making. While we are involved in lengthy procedures—the Commissioner was talking about the rule of unanimity—there are others who make decisions overnight.  It is therefore important that the European Union has an agile and effective code of sanctions for human rights violations — Mrs Kalniete called for this to be adopted in this parliamentary term. This will help, Mr President, to make the European Union more consistent with its principles, to be more respected on the international stage and to have greater credibility.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Mr President, I welcome this proposal. The protection of human rights is one of the most important core values of the European Union. Unfortunately, the EU no longer shows unconditionally to form a common front against the individuals who violate these rights.  The current proposal that would deny people who commit gross violations of human rights access to the EU and freeze their assets is an effective tool. This proposal has two major advantages: the country's innocent population remains out of reach and human rights abusers are dealt with where it hurts them the most. Moreover, this new plan ensures the neutrality of our joint sanctions by depoliticising the sanctions process. This makes the European Union more effective.  That is why I look forward to the Commission's final proposal, so that our Union will be able to defend universal human rights even better than it is now.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, today the world has seen a sweeping wave of autocratic governments and strongmen, and our human rights toolbox needs to respond to these changes. By the way, we need only to listen to the debates in this Parliament, this very week, to understand that the situations in countries like Russia, China, Turkey, Nicaragua and Kazakhstan are totally anti-democratic and put the international human rights obligations of those countries into question. So the EU human rights toolbox must adapt. The global sanctions regime is one of the best tools for doing just that. The EU comprehensive sanctions regime for human rights violations is long overdue. To make it a success, it is vitally important that the new regime is legally sound and complies in full with the highest standards of due process. The listings should be based on hard evidence and on open source information and should be strictly rights based, as opposed to geostrategic, financial or other bases: that is the only way to guarantee political legitimacy. We do not wish to see symmetry with the US sanctions regime, as it does not have adequate judicial safeguards. I’m very grateful that the High Representative and the Council have undertaken an open approach to this possible new instrument, understanding that it’s a complex system that must be put in place. We cannot afford to fail.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, finally EU ministers have decided to establish an EU global human rights sanctions regime. But, to be efficient and credible, it needs joint efforts and rigorous and consistent implementation by all Member States. I welcome the move to drop the unanimity rule in this area, but on the condition that it must not lead to selective implementation by those who don’t agree. Implementation has to be mandatory for all. So far, progress since the 2014 European Parliament decision to establish an EU Magnitsky list has been alarmingly slow. Only five more states have followed the US Congress resolution and I think it is very important to maintain the name Magnitsky, which has symbolic and universal meaning.  Finally, it is shameful that Russia is so far not included in the money—laundering and terrorist—financing blacklist.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Mr President, the European Union remains the main force defending European rights throughout the world. The debate to create a European mechanism for imposing targeted sanctions on people or governments worldwide that violate human rights is a great challenge and we must all respond positively today to strengthen our credibility among the peoples who seek a Europe of solidarity, democracy and humanity.  However, in order to be effective, it must be based on objective criteria and not operate on the principle of unanimity. We cannot be the object of political and national interests, as is often the case in Parliament and in the Council. The European People's Party and parties on the European far right do not see human rights violations in Middle Eastern countries. On the other hand, the European left does not believe that there is a European and humanitarian crisis in Venezuela of three million refugees and the lack of basic goods. But human rights are not a field of petty political purpose. Their defense must be non-negotiable.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, this is not the first time that our Parliament has called for a global human rights sanctions regime that, along the lines of the United States of America, Canada and other countries such as Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, would bear Mr Magnitsky's name. Today, we reiterated our call in the report on European Union-Russia relations, the report urges the Commission and the European External Action Service to prepare without delay a legislative proposal for an EU-wide version of the Magnitsky Act, which would allow visa bans and targeted personal sanctions, such as blocking property ownership and interest, and so on and so on. I fully support the EU-wide mechanism, which should more effectively penalise individuals who are implicated in serious human rights violations.  If Europe is to remain faithful to its values, it cannot just look up to the lawlessness around it. The toothlessness of our responses to fabricated trials, the torture of political prisoners, diminishes our authority, and reinforces the expansionism and audacity of authoritarian regimes.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, there cannot be any kind of impunity for those who persecute peoples, for those who exterminate in the name of religion, for human and arms traffickers, for sex explorers or for the murderers of journalists.  No one of the money they have, however much protection they have in certain undemocratic regimes, the European Union can never give shelter to human rights violators. We are still a hope in the world.  We need to show determination and establish a Union-wide law that does not compact with those who do not respect human dignity. Impose a visa ban, freeze the assets of offenders and prohibit them from entering our house. It's time to join the countries that have already done so. Europe urgently needs a concrete proposal to punish these rapists. We need to do this if we do not want our speeches to be full of content, but empty of action. Until then, the weapons we buy and the deals we make will always be stained with the blood of those who fight for freedom.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to point out at the outset that I do not believe in sanctions. I do not believe in sanctions as the only exclusive tool and not as one of the elements of exerting a certain pressure. As with resolutions. The more resolutions there are, the more they are subject to inflation and become ineffective. I am the Head of the Delegation for Belarus, and I know how important it is to use many tools to exert certain pressure, a certain effect. First of all, you need to talk. You need to maintain communication channels. Attention must also be paid to certain specificities of the countries to which we use various types of tools. In any case, I would like to speak out, first of all, against inflation in resolutions and in our speeches, in favour of sanctions, which are combined with other elements, elements of other pressures, educational elements, elements of maintaining communication, because only then will we have a real effect.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, I too would like to stress the importance of creating a sanctioning mechanism that targets both individual criminals and state governments. But it is a question of this mechanism being effective and impartial, whether crimes are committed within the European Union, outside the European Union, whether the offender is in Russia or in Turkey. Unfortunately, our behaviour to date will show along the way whether it will change and we will finally treat all these offenders in the same way.  However, the European institutions have clearly not treated offenders and criminals in the same way. For example – and I am done – the crime of the disappearance of Christian and European culture in the northern Turkish-listed part of Cyprus is a crime for which you are silent, Commissioner.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, human rights have been violated and are still violated by a number of third states with which we have diplomatic and trade relations, some of our allies, as well as some Member States. While European leaders often talk about the European Union being a "community of values", I must recognise that we have often traded on human rights. Certain sanctions for systematic violations of human rights within the Union must exist as it constitutes a clear breach of the treaty. That is why we have the Court of Justice of the European Union and we do not need new mechanisms here. I fear they would be used to discipline Member States that do not share the same vision of the Union with Brussels, while some others, who share a federalist vision, as before, would be seen through their fingers. According to third countries, on the other hand, we have yet to develop effective mechanisms that would be related to our trade and other agreements with these countries.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, for the EU to be credible when standing for the protection of human rights worldwide, we need more than just words. We also need instruments. In this regard, the European regime to impose sanctions on individuals from both state and non—state actors responsible for human rights violations is imperative. It places the EU as the front—runner for the protection of human rights worldwide. It enhances the visibility of the EU as a responsible international actor. It sends a strong signal to those many existing dictatorships and authoritarian regimes which systematically disregard the right and the duty to preserve human dignity. It would be a tool to make life a bit more difficult for those responsible for – or involved – in grave human rights violations and abuses. It would be a way to support the victims of those abuses as well as human rights defenders and a step towards fighting against impunity. For all these reasons, I call on the Council to reach a prompt agreement on this much—needed regime.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there can be no result in the area of human rights without some kind of sanctions. However, these sanctions must be implemented after a thorough and democratic debate with the state against which they are imposed. In such a case, we may not convince the state under discussion or its officials, but we will no doubt have managed to develop the necessary debate within the population of that state. Without this public debate, sanctions can easily be seen by this state as a hostile move and this will not be constructive at all.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, today, the global trend leans towards undermining international law, in particular when it comes to human rights. Multilateralism is under attack by a number of countries, with the US leading the way. In this context, it’s essential that the EU’s foreign policy continues to focus on human rights, democracy and the rule of law, so I’m happy that the idea of a European human rights sanction regime is progressing. Sanctions can be a powerful tool, but it’s important to make them as efficient and as targeted as possible. A coherent European sanctions regime is therefore a step in the right direction.  Seeing this progress being made at European level reminds me that that if Brexit happens, the UK will not be able to participate in such positive policies. Since the Brexit negotiations began, the Conservative Government has shown increasing cynicism in its foreign policy, with Theresa May holding hands with Presidents Trump and Erdoğan, while Liam Fox went on a trade crusade with the self-confessed murderer Duterte, now the President of the Philippines. So, 28 countries working together in a sensible sanctions regime is far more effective than one desperate lonely island.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, a European sanctions system for the violation of human rights would certainly have our support. It would be very necessary. But above all, it would also be very necessary not to continue with a vision, with some complicity towards impunity. And I'm going to give you three examples, Commissioner, three countries.  Morocco, the case of the Rif. Yesterday, several Rif activists were convicted precisely for defending social rights for defending freedom of expression.  I'll keep setting examples for you, Commissioner. The case of Western Sahara, where, at the moment, there are political prisoners on hunger strike and, of course, the case of Turkey. We'll talk about Turkey later, but we have political leaders in jail, academics, journalists.  And what about Israel, Commissioner? What to say about Israel?  That is why we would very much like to stop having some complicity, because political influence is also in not making parallel trade agreements.  The United Nations has just stated that Israel's attacks in Gaza, in the march of return, can constitute crimes against humanity and that they have killed 189 people— 35 of them children — in these marches since 2018

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, allow me first of all to thank you for this extremely valuable, useful and timely exchange of views. I would like to take this opportunity to thank you again for all your speeches, comments and suggestions.  Today’s debate illustrates again that the possible EU global human rights sanctions regime is an interesting and necessary issue, but also a complex one meriting careful further study. As already mentioned, the current discussions are focusing on the various open questions that should be considered in order to allow for an informed political decision on the feasibility of such a proposal. Discussions will continue in the Council, and we stand ready to contribute to the debate constructively. A final decision will have to be taken unanimously. Allow me, therefore, to express my appreciation for your attention to this highly important topic.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Motions for resolutions, to be tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure, will be announced at a later date. The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. – On several occasions the High Representative has called for the establishment of an EU-wide mechanism for the imposition of specific sanctions against persons involved in serious human rights violations. Indeed, over the past two decades, EU sanctions have become an integral part of all its external relations instruments, and have been imposed to support objectives of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. The existence of its own EU-wide regime would make the application of sanctions more effective, not limiting their application to people from certain countries or involved in certain crimes, but covering all perpetrators of serious human rights violations who enjoy impunity, state and non-state actors such as terrorists and terrorist groups. This effectiveness in imposing sanctions would be a valuable tool that would strengthen the EU's role as a global human rights player.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: Writing. – This resolution is a vivid example of yet another effective tool for the European Union to carry out a coherent foreign policy. The hollowing of our eastern neighbour and the interference in the national policies of the Member States have been possible thanks to the dissemination of a simple narrative through useful idiots. The distraction of The Citizens of the Union through information operations is also part of the Kremlin's broader strategy that neither Russian citizens nor the rest of the world should see the horrors that few human rights advocates in this authoritarian state have to go through. This Magnitsky Act, as well as sanctions in general, is the best measure to combat the aggression of the Russian authorities and to draw attention to the fact that personal freedoms are restricted in Russia. This is demonstrated by Putin's nervousness and intrusive behaviour towards his european union-based partners, through which he has tried to lift sanctions or remove references to Magnitsky from legal texts. But without results – and that's how it should be kept! Of course, the Magnitsky name in this instrument is of significant symbolic importance, but it does not in any way prevent the instrument from being used in other countries.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the joint debate on the Kati Piri report, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the 2018 Report on Turkey (2018/2150(INI)) (A8-0091/2019).

name: Kati PIRI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, sitting in a cell for 17 months without knowing what you are being accused of – that is reality in today’s Turkey. Osman Kavala, a leading figure in Turkey’s civil society, and one of the many victims of President Erdoğan’s witch-hunt against his critics, was arrested in October 2017. Osman and 15 others heard the charges against them last week. They are being held responsible for an attempt to overthrow the government and are facing life imprisonment without parole if found guilty. The 657-page indictment talks of the spontaneous wave of anti-government Gezi protests in 2013, which have now been reframed as an outcome of an international conspiracy to unseat the government. The evidence against Kavala: in some intercepted calls, he is offering to lend a plastic folding table and in another call, he agrees to send some packages of fruit juice and milk. The indictment includes no evidence of Osman or any of the others planning the protest, let alone an uprising. One could have a good laugh about this if it wasn’t so serious. This is the level to which Turkey’s democracy has sunk.  And now, what is the answer of the EU to all of this? What is the answer to blatant human rights violations in our neighbouring country? During the last five years, the European Parliament has taken the lead in not only speaking out, but also asking the Commission and the Council to use all available tools to send a firm signal to President Erdoğan and prevent further backsliding and, on the other hand, to show Turkey’s citizens who adhere to values of freedom, human rights and the rule of law that the EU stands by their side. But so far, our European leaders have bitterly failed in doing so. Turkey has disappeared from our attention. It is no longer in the news, except when EU nationals are concerned. It seems that our government leaders have accepted that the situation in Turkey is as it is. Our calls for respect of fundamental rights have not only fallen on deaf ears in Ankara, but also in EU capitals. The red lines of this House have all been crossed. Severe human rights violations continue. The rule of law has been dismantled. Turkey is the record holder of jailed journalists and on top of that, the new constitution consolidates Erdoğan’s authoritarianism. That is why we asked the Council to formally suspend the accession talks with Turkey. Not that anyone was seriously considering accession under the current circumstances, but continuing talks on EU integration with President Erdoğan is a charade.  We want to hear what the EU will do for Osman Kavala. What will the EU do for Selahattin Demirtaş, the opposition leader who was imprisoned for two and a half years, for the other members of parliament in jail, for the tens of thousands of people who have been jailed without a fair trial, for the LGBTI activists, for the Saturday mothers who are no longer allowed to protest, for the brave Turkish women who, on 8 March, went out on the streets and were met with rubber bullets fired at them by the police? The silence of the Council is fuelling Erdoğan’s authoritarianism. It is also fuelling the disappointment of Turkey’s democrats. It is time to come up with a strategy. You can start on one this Friday, when you will have a meeting with Turkey’s Foreign Minister.  President, allow me also after these five years, to thank my colleague shadow rapporteurs who have been working on this file for the last five years in good cooperation. I very much hope that tomorrow we will be able to unite this House again and to give a strong signal to our European leaders.

name: Kati PIRI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for the invitation to participate in this debate today to discuss the European Parliament’s 2018 Turkey report, and to look at the issues of mutual concern, as well as those of mutual interest. We take note of the clear messages and concerns referred to in your resolution. We are continuing to follow domestic developments in Turkey very closely, in particular the implementation of the constitutional amendments. Particularly worrying in this respect, as you have also rightly noted on many occasions, is the continuing backsliding in the areas of rule of law and respect for fundamental rights, also highlighted in the Commissionʼs 2018 communication on enlargement policy. These concerns were clearly reflected in last June’s Council conclusions, as well as in Parliament’s report on the table today. In its conclusions of 18 July 2016, the Council strongly condemned the 15 July coup attempt and expressed solidarity with the Turkish people and full support for the democratic institutions of Turkey. The EU recognises the serious security threats that Turkey has faced. However, the disproportionate scale and scope of measures taken in the aftermath of the failed coup attempt also continue to raise serious concern. Turkey has been moving further away from the EU, and we are not currently in a ‘business as usual’ situation. While noting your call for a formal suspension of accession negotiations with Turkey, let me remind you that the Council noted in its June 2018 conclusions that Turkey’s accession negotiations have effectively come to a standstill, due to the issues just outlined. At the same time, we agree with you that it is important not to close the door to Turkey, but to keep the channels of communication open; the Council maintains that continued engagement and an open and frank dialogue with Turkey, as a candidate country and a key partner of the EU in many areas, remains important and is in the best interests of both sides. I refer in particular to the common challenges that we face and the need to cooperate in essential areas of joint interest such as migration, counterterrorism, energy, transport, economy and trade. The EU-Turkey Joint Action Plan for refugees and migration management and the March 2016 EU-Turkey statement are continuing to be implemented in the interest of both parties. This successful cooperation has led to a drastic decrease in deaths at sea, a substantial reduction in irregular migrant arrivals from Turkey, and a better future for the Syrian migrants in Turkey, to which the EU-funded Facility for refugees in Turkey is continuing to contribute. The Council fully subscribes to Parliament’s acknowledgement of the important role played by Turkey in responding to the migration crisis, as confirmed in its conclusions commending Turkey for its renewed efforts and constructive cooperation. At the same time, Turkey needs to commit to a normalisation of relations with Cyprus and fully implement the provisions of the Additional Protocol to the Association Agreement. Let me use this opportunity to assure you that we, as the Presidency, will therefore continue to raise these important matters with our Turkish interlocutors at every level and on every occasion, and do our utmost to persuade Turkey to do its part and live up to its promises of reform.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by congratulating the rapporteur, Kati Piri, and all the shadow rapporteurs, not only for this year but also in previous years, for all their excellent work on Turkey – a candidate country and, of course, a partner of strategic importance to the European Union. In relation to the rule of law and human rights, the negative developments that the Commission identified in its last – 2018 – report have continued. They have caused further serious concerns about the direction that the Turkish leadership is taking. The recent indictment against Osman Kavala, and 15 other highly respected civil society actors, exemplifies the increasing pressure that civil society is facing. It also casts doubt as to whether the judicial process in Turkey respects the principles of the presumption of innocence and the right to a fair trial. Honourable Members, Turkey says it remains committed to its goal of EU accession. It should not then be surprised that we are following developments in Turkey very closely and that we raise our strong concerns when the values and principles on which the European Union is founded – and to which Turkey too has officially committed as a member of the Council of Europe – are being ignored. On the contrary, one would expect Turkey to carry out the necessary reforms. But Turkey is also, and will remain, our neighbour and a partner of strategic importance for the European Union, with whom we work closely on areas such as energy, counterterrorism, trade and migration. Turkey is a key player in regions that are of strategic interest for the European Union. It also hosts the largest refugee population in the world, and our cooperation under the Facility for Refugees is an example of successful cooperation. A series of high-level sectoral dialogues on political issues, transport and the economy has taken place recently and an Association Council will be convened later this week. These meetings provide useful platforms not only to further our cooperation but also to share our grave concerns. Our engagement is not unconditional: open dialogue is not uncritical dialogue. Most recently, at our high-level political dialogue on 22 November in Ankara, the High Representative and I made it clear to our Turkish counterparts that there is an urgent need for Turkey to reverse its policy stance if it seriously wants EU-Turkey relations to improve. And during the recent high-level economic dialogue, Vice-President Katainen specifically raised our concerns about press freedom, in particular the accreditation of foreign journalists. We also continue to call on Turkey to improve its relations with all our Member States bilaterally, especially with Cyprus. We have emphasised that the Turkish Government should refrain from provocative and illegal actions, notably in the eastern Mediterranean and in the Aegean. At the same time, we must not lose sight of the long term and, perhaps even more importantly, of the many people in Turkey who are directly affected by the current downward trend on fundamental freedoms. We must keep our hands stretched out towards them, especially, and help them to defend our shared European values.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Kati Piri, and also the shadow rapporteurs from the other groups for their very good cooperation over the years.  In the end, we were able to agree on a good text, which only needs to be improved on a point-by-point basis. And on one point, I think, he needs to be improved, which is that he is only calling for the accession negotiations to be suspended, and this demand is not new. We raised it in case a presidential system is established, thereby abolishing democracy in Turkey. But that, of course, did not impress the Erdogan regime in any way. The Constitution has been amended, democracy and the rule of law have been abolished. Even if the accession negotiations were suspended, Turkey would still be entitled to payment of the pre-accession funds. With this money, however, we are de facto supporting the Turkish Government, which tramples on human rights and civil liberties, persecutes critics and opponents abroad, arrests them and sentences them to heavy prison sentences. A veritable witch-hunt hits the Gülen supporters. Can we want that? Do we help the critics of the regime in this way?  My group wants to end the accession negotiations once and for all, and I support that. We could then reallocate the pre-accession funds to support Turkish civil society. Let us be honest – everyone knows that it is impossible to take in Turkey and that the European Union itself is in no way capable of enlargement for a long time. I therefore ask for your support for amending the text to 'end the negotiations'.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would first like to thank the Council, the Commission and the Romanian rotating Presidency for their very balanced judgment and assessment on EU—Turkey relations.  I remain convinced that Turkey is an important partner of the EU. The enlargement process has allowed us to significantly influence Turkey’s path towards democracy in the last decades – maybe for too long. With regret I can only note the shredding of some of the democratic achievements since 2016. I trust nevertheless that a European Turkey is for the benefit of all: the EU, NATO and each of our Member States. Europe should be vigilant and firm when it comes to condemning the violations of human rights, freedom and the rule of law in Turkey, while always keeping up a strong, regular and constructive dialogue with this important country. Both are imperatives. This also includes an intensive dialogue on alignment of foreign policy, defence and security issues, with a strong focus on counterterrorism and matters of military and strategic importance, as Turkey is a very important member of the military alliance, NATO. Finally, while Turkey is the EU’s fifth largest trading partner and Europe is by far Turkey’s largest economic partner, with Germany in the lead, the customs union is still the world one. That is why I am calling on the Commission to start the preparatory work for the upgrade of the customs union and on the Council to provide the necessary mandate as soon as possible.   (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: "blue card" question. – I have listened carefully to Mr Boştinaru mentioning many times that Turkey is a partner. I really wanted you to explain to us here in the European Parliament how we mean and how we feel about partners. Partners such as Turkey, which is the most unreliable, the most provocative partner, which attacks Member States of the European Union. And I would like to know, if Turkey attacked Romania in the same way it attacks Greece and Cyprus, would that be your reaction? If in Romania Turkey did not recognise the country as a member country of the European Union, as an independent country, as it does not recognise Cyprus, would you consider Turkey a reliable partner that we must continue to treat in this way, without taking measures and sanctions? (applause)

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: blue-card answer. – Dear Colleague, I’m looking at Turkey, not with my Romanian eyes. To make it clear, we are here the European Parliament. I’m looking at the role of Turkey from an EU perspective, and no matter whether it is you, me or others, we are looking at Turkey. Turkey geographically is there, politically is there, militarily is there, and Europe can do better if it has stronger, more effective relations with Turkey. Europe will be much weaker and exposed to much higher risks if we sever relations with Turkey completely, as the EPP is doing in order to make the Turkish issue a hostage to different political agendas. I don’t share your view.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, thanks to amendment, the Turkey report briefly reflects on Diyanet, the Turkish Directorate for Religious Affairs, influential inside and outside Turkey's state borders and well-resourced, with a budget for 2019 of around EUR 1.7 billion and with 140 000 permanent employees. Here, Commissioner, European alertness is really needed. See also the in-depth analysis of Doctor Salim Çevik, " Erdoğan's Comprehensive Religious Policy", verse of the press, published last week in Stiftung Wissenschaft und Politik. Read it!  I urge the Council and the Commission, as well as the governments and parliaments of the EU Member States, to thoroughly examine and report on Diyanet's activities on European soil. First of all, we will have the opportunity to follow the Commission's new progress report. This is due to the serious suspicions of spying, surveillance and recruitment of agents by Diyanet officials. At the end of paragraph 11, the report calls on the Turkish authorities to effectively combat all manifestations of anti-Semitism in society. Such a call does not benefit the tiny Jewish minority when the report at the same time silences the presidential promotion of prominent figures who make shocking anti-Semitic statements. A missed opportunity! The rejection of this amendment. There's no point!

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the annual debate about Turkey’s progress towards EU accession has become more difficult and painful each year. It is now a report on regress.
