A lot has happened over the past year and, while it’s absolutely legitimate to hold the perpetrators of the failed coup and the attack on the Grand National Assembly to account, nothing justifies the overreaction that continues to haunt Turkey: hundreds of thousands fired from their jobs or arrested; abuse of the state of emergency and counterterrorism measures; limitations to press and internet freedom; and trumped-up charges to accuse civil society leaders, such as Osman Kavala. All in all, core principles are at stake: the independence of the judiciary, the separation of powers and the rule of law. These developments impact disproportionately on the opposition and on women, LGBTI people, journalists, religious minorities, human rights defenders and other minorities. But everybody in Turkey, whether openly or quietly in their hearts, knows what is going on and fears what may yet come. A fear of what could get worse still seems to paralyse the Commission and the Council too. Or is it the cynical outsourcing of the sheltering of refugees – for which Turkey deserves our support – that risks overshadowing everything else? I believe that our credibility is at stake and I insist that our words and principles must have meaning. As we warned in previous years, with the adoption of the constitutional reform package, a presidential system is now in place, one that lacks checks and balances, not so much according to us but according to the Venice Commission. So we need to be honest and principled. When we continue our relations on trade, defence, foreign policy or asylum, we must always work with Turkey on the basis of the rule of law and respect for human rights.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We are now actually dealing with the Commission's Turkey report for 2017, and, as everyone knows, a lot has happened since then. It started with the invasion of Afrin back in January 2018. I visited Turkey twice last year. Last summer I made a visit to Diyarbakir. I interviewed politicians, networks, organisations and citizens in general about the situation there. I visited the sur district, or rather looked in over what was left of Sur from above the World Heritage walls. I also attended a full day of the trial in Ankara against, among others, the Turkish Green spokesmen, who are accused of having signed a petition against the invasion of Afrin. I met academics, the EU representation and others. I asked everyone the same question about how they saw the further accession negotiations. And I got the same answer: "Be very tough on the regime, but don't close the door completely to membership."  During my second visit in December, I met, in addition to organisations and politicians, representatives of the armed forces and a number of Syrian rebel groups. On the agenda was one, as they put it, "imminent purging of terrorists in northern Syria". Several of them referred to our joint work on combating terrorism and asked for our support for their planned operation in Syria. The aim of the operation is to weed out virtually all the Kurdish groups that have so successfully fought Daesh, and to which we should instead be eternally grateful.  To be a candidate country obliges. EU membership is based on respect for human rights, including minority rights, freedom of the press, freedom of expression, independence of the courts. In this House, we are tired of seeing President Erdoğan's rule take leaps and bounds away from our common values. They cannot be explained away by the failed coup attempt in 2016, and there are no acceptable excuses for invasions by other countries. But we have different views on the accession negotiations. From us Greens – we choose to listen to the democrats and minorities. We want to be tough on the regime, but we do not want to suspend the negotiations. We want them to stay frozen.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, dear Mr Hahn, Mrs Piri, ladies and gentlemen, perhaps this is my last substantive intervention before the European Parliament, a very ambitious experiment undertaken by humanity. But speaking of Turkey, I have to tell you – and this is not just about Turkey – we lack solidarity, ladies and gentlemen, between the Member States and, unfortunately, sometimes also between the peoples. Cyprus is not – I come from Cyprus and I have to say a few words – Cyprus is not an occupied country in this debate, it is not a necessary depth of the debate that is taking place here today.  There is a ambiguity, to say the least, in our attitude towards Turkey both as Member States and as MEPs. We do not know what to say in Turkey, but at the same time Turkey knows very well what it is saying to us. At the same time, the European People's Party called for an end to negotiations with that country, but at the same time called for an upgrade of the customs union. It's like taking bread from someone, but you're giving them the oven and the wheat. I think this is a wrong approach. We must be honest with Turkey and know exactly what it is that we are asking of it.  Mr Çavuşoğlu, recently, but also many other officials – give me a few seconds, Mr President – often-densely refer to the phrase 'we are ready for any solution in Cyprus'. This includes the certain position that they are looking for a two-state solution. There can be no Cypriot who will lift the pen to sign a two-state solution. That is why my message to Turkish officials, but also to any Cypriot, is that any discussion of a two-state solution must be immediately suspended. Only the Federation can be a way out of solving this great problem.  I call on you in solidarity with the Cypriot people and I also call on the Cypriots in solidarity with any problems faced by other peoples in Europe.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I allowed you to speak more because you promised that this would be the last speech.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, last Wednesday, 6 March, Russian and Turkish media reported that ships from the Russian Black Sea fleet held a joint exercise drill with a Turkish navy corvette and a minesweeper, near the Port of Novorossiysk. This came shortly after President Erdoğan’s clarification over speculation about a Turkish deal to purchase Russian S-400 Triumf air defence systems, when he confirmed that his government will not cancel that deal, despite protests from his American NATO partner. Since the British people’s vote to leave the European Union, this place has increased rhetoric, emphasising alarming support for the development of integrated EU military forces. My only hope is that after the European elections a majority here will step back from this crazy federalist mantra and understand that NATO is a vital component of peace and security in Europe.  Mr President, to my mind the threat to NATO from a developing EU military capability is as concerning as Ankara’s continuing military alignment with Moscow.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for years, from these benches, quite in isolation, we have been saying that it is absolutely dangerous to have a plan to introduce into our European Union a country that did not have the prospects, not because – as perhaps wrongly or grossly said at the time – the whole of Turkey is not part of Europe: a significant part of Turkey is certainly Europe. , so much so that even during fascism she was summoned to the great convention in Rome in 1932 on the idea of Europe, Turkey was also invited.  But it was a different Turkey, a secular Turkey. It was not Turkey led by Erdoğan, with its dream of an Islamic caliphate, Turkey that is scary, that raises and probably brought in terrorists, Turkey that you discover today to be the country of lawlessness, of anti-democracy. You have chosen precisely the one to entrust the refugees from Syria and other countries. Congratulations on your hypocrisy. It's actually the temple of prison, for those who don't think like the government, starting with the 150 journalists in prison. A disgrace!

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the report reflects the real situation that currently exists in Turkey, namely violation of the principles of the rule of law, human rights, arrests and torture of dissidents and non-dissidents, manipulation of justice, persecution of dissidents abroad and abolition of freedom of the press. It also points out the non-recognition of the Republic of Cyprus by Turkey, the fact that it does not allow it to exploit resources in its economic zone and also because it constantly violates Greece's airspace and territorial waters and furthermore provokes and does not recognise the principles of international law. All that I have said is not just bilateral disputes between Turkey and its neighbours. It is a direct violation of the principles of international law and, in order to force Turkey to act, accession negotiations, negotiations on the customs union and its financing must be immediately interrupted. It is unacceptable for the European Union to finance Turkey's purchase of Cobra II armoured combat vehicles.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Mr President, I support the perspective put forward earlier by the rapporteur of the PPE Group, Mrs Sommer, for a very simple reason: the position that Kati Piri is embracing today, we have already embraced it two years ago and the Council has ignored us. There are Member States that are blocking the change of position towards Turkey. I believe, moreover, that we should not be under any illusions, unfortunately there are Member States that are attracted to the Erdogan model and even the rotating presidency of the Council is one of those cases. Turkey also fascinates and fascinates in the Western Balkans. I remind you that the only place Erdogan could hold an election rally is Sarajevo. So we need to see the danger not only for some of the Member States, but also for friends in the Western Balkans. That is why I believe that the signal in the European Parliament must be tougher than in the past, because this history must end. Turkey must clearly leave the negotiating table.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Hundreds of thousands of people in Turkey are experiencing fundamental violations of human rights. It is time for the European Union to send out a clear signal and formally suspend the accession negotiations, which are already stalled. Tens of thousands of people are in prison, waiting for their verdict in often unfair trials. The European Parliament's call for a formal suspension of the accession negotiations is logical and consistent, because we had already threatened in the last report if the constitutional reform was implemented in Turkey. That has now happened. Formal suspension should also be done so that everyone knows that the European Parliament is a credible interlocutor. We say 'suspend', not 'stop'. The door remains leaning. Despite the strong demands of the European Parliament, the doors to cooperation with Turkey, as an important strategic neighbour, should not be closed. It is important that, despite the toughness of the discussion with the Turkish Government, we do not abandon civil society. Right now, it needs our support. EU support is more important than ever. And the European Parliament will not stop demanding justice for Selahattin Demirtas and the many others wrongly imprisoned.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! Turkey is a country that has historically, culturally and geographically never heard and will never belong in Europe. That is why it is welcome that this Parliament has produced the first and most critical report ever against Turkish membership. However, it is not acceptable not to conclude these negotiations. Turkey has shown for a number of years that it is on a slippery slope towards an increasingly Islamist society. We have seen major setbacks with Turkish society in general, but also with the influence that Turkey wields here in Europe. The occupation of Cyprus and the totally unacceptable behaviour shown towards the many Turks who live and live in other European countries. That is why it is time to say stop. And to be honest in our talk with Turkey and admit to them that they will never – and should never be – members of the European Union.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Mr President, the final text of the 2018 report on Turkey doesn’t help to continue a constructive dialogue between the EU and our strategic partner. Suspension of the negotiation process is unacceptable for us. Before the final decision we need to take into account the progress made by Turkey recently. On 11 December 2018, the fifth meeting of the Reform Action Group (RAG), held in Ankara, announced that Turkey would decisively continue its efforts to align with EU standards despite political obstructions in the negotiations. Ankara has set the goal of achieving closure of the monitoring procedure of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. The Ministry of Justice intends to update the Judicial Reform Strategy together with the Council of Europe and the EU. To strengthen the protection of fundamental human rights, the RAG plans to update the Action Plan on the Prevention of the Violation of the European Convention on Human Rights. A proposal to suspend the negotiation process – even formally – will be received negatively by Turkish society: that was made clear during the recent meeting in Ankara of the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, where the EU is seen as a friendly community. In the light of the upcoming elections in Europe and in Turkey, we need to be careful about the kind of messages we are sending to voters.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, tomorrow this House, the very same institution that in 2004 eagerly voted in favour of starting negotiations, will vote on the formal suspension of accession talks with Turkey. Much has happened in these 15 years and our relationship has been difficult at many times. However, the current stalemate could have been avoided if the accession framework had been used fully and if Turkey had kept its path towards reform and towards more democracy. Regretfully, the situation in Turkey has deteriorated a lot in recent years. The rule of law, fundamental rights and basic freedoms have been under great pressure. The recent indictment seeking a lifelong imprisonment for Osman Kavala is just one among thousands of examples of this backlash. However, suspending accession negotiations with Turkey is not the solution. In order to keep alive the prospect of democracy in Turkey, respect for human rights and individual and collective freedoms, we need to keep the doors open – if not for the present, then for the future. If not for us, then for those men in Turkey fighting for human rights and justice.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, Erdogan had described the failed coup as a gift from God. The consequences of this are in the EU-Turkey report. But the EU has given the more divine gift to the Turkish rulers themselves.  The refugee deal encouraged the way to look away in the systematic persecution of the opposition, the silence in the raid on Afrin. Meanwhile, the only MEP, Feleknas Uca, is threatened with many years in prison. Politician Leyla Güven has been on hunger strike since November. Such means are only used when one has been deprived of all power of action. Incidentally, women in particular suffer acutely from the Erdogan regime. They should be systematically silenced and made invisible.  Let us opt for the signal of a freeze in the negotiations and not for an end. Let us show the capacity for dialogue and solidarity, because Turkey is more than Erdogan, it is above all the opposition and civil society. You need our voice! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. - Honourable Member, I have listened carefully to you. You talked about the fact that the European Parliament, the European Union, in the agreement with Turkey, has exchanged aid in the migration crisis for being silent on the non-freedom that is in Turkey. But that's not true! We are not silent, the European Parliament has repeatedly called for the release of political prisoners, we have had urgent reports here, our joint EU-Turkey delegation in Ankara has clearly called for the release of political prisoners. I'm asking you, do you know what we're talking about here?

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur I would remind you that we in this House had a situation where we actually agreed across the political groups that we had made ourselves blackmailable with the EU-Turkey deal. I have raised this situation. It is extortionate that Erdogan was able to show us here for months, even years, so to speak, on the nose ring. And I think we should not hide our own situation. This is just as much a part of it as anything else we have already done in critical dialogue with the Erdogan regime.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this debate comes at a very opportune time, with the recent expulsion from Turkish territory of as many as 3 German correspondents declared undesirable by the country. It is confirmation of how Turkey probably continues to be the worst country in the world for journalists, with as many as 68 of them in prison. In short, erdogan's purge shows no sign of subsiders and now seems to be fighting particularly in the media, which are accused of putting the sultan-president in a bad light. This is a very serious crime, especially just a few weeks before the local elections, which are already very complicated because of the shaky economy. Not to mention the other incredible and well-known violations of human rights. Ankara is indeed an exceptional case, ladies and gentlemen. Turkey continues to be a candidate country, despite the fact that the facts tell us that this simply should not be possible. The only small consolation is that this is not because of this Parliament. In these difficult years, the rapporteur, Kati Piri, has handled a complex dossier wisely. But I would like to remind you that back in 2016 we had called for a temporary deadlock in the negotiations, which in 2017 became a request for a formal suspension, a position that we will perhaps confirm tomorrow. But these are all empty words, because the ball remains in the hands of the Council, which in recent years has adopted the very courageous political choice of doing absolutely nothing, perhaps hoping that somehow things will improve on their own: hypocritical, unrealistic and punctually disregarded expectation.  I do not want to say that relations with Turkey, which obviously remains strategic, should be totally cut back. However, I am convinced that we need new and alternative forms of dialogue and cooperation, which will once and for all archive an accession process that now lacks any credibility and legitimacy. We must give a serious and unequivocal signal. We should have done this a long time ago, actually.  It is clear that wait-and-see strategies lead to nothing and not only useful to us, nor to the Turkish people, who are victims of this situation and who could one day demand accountability for our inability to act decisively and promptly.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: Mr President, every year the report presented by our colleague, Mrs Piri, is finding it increasingly difficult to hide the truth. The situation in Turkey remains most worrying, and even the most fanatical supporters of membership are now keeping a low profile. But Mrs Piri's report is limited to a single, albeit negative, analysis of the situation, but which does not exclude the prospect of membership of the European Union. For us, this is above all an essential question: Turkey has no place in the European Union for cultural and even civilizational reasons, even if the Turkish people, a long-time friend of France, deserve our full attention. Moreover, we cannot allow a modernisation of the customs union between the European Union and Turkey which would go against our economic interests and, first of all, against those of our farmers. What do you need: more incarceration, more human rights violations to make the only decision that is worth it? I therefore invite you, ladies and gentlemen, to vote in favour of the alternative resolution put forward by the Europe of Nations and Freedoms Group, which calls for a definitive end to the accession negotiations.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, Turkey's bourgeoisie is stepping up its aggression, greying territorial waters and airspace with constant violations, illegal NAVTEX military exercises and threats, while the SYRIZA government is involved in competition as a flag bearer of Euro-Atlantic plans in the confrontation with Russia, tries to wash away the dangerous role of the US-NATO-European Union and cultivates complacency.  As much criticism of Erdogan as the European Union reports include, they are characterized by the given role of a strategic partner they attach to Turkey, photographing the Euro-Nato settlement in the Aegean for co-exploitation, as well as a dichotomy plan in Cyprus to share the energy pie. They raise big questions, blurred references in the report to resolving outstanding bilateral disputes, unresolved legal obligations and unresolved disputes with immediate neighbours over land, maritime borders and airspace.  The people must be on hand with the fight against nationalism and the imperialist plans of the European Union, NATO and the urban classes.

name: David CASA
text: – Sur President, taħt l-amministrazzjoni li għandna bħalissa, it-Turkija tinsab iżjed 'il bogħod mis-sħubija fl-Unjoni Ewropea milli kienet meta applikat snin beauty. Mingħajr midja ħielsa i teżistix democratkrazija u l-każ ta' Pelin Unker yuri eżattament l-istat ta' democrat fikrazija fit-Turkija. Pelin hija parti mill-konsorzju internazzjonali tal-ġurnalisti investigattivi u kienet waħda minn dawk illi rrappurtat fuq l-iskandlu tal-Paradise Papers. Dak li kitbet ma nnegah ħadd u issa qed tiffa大大ja tlettax-il xahar ħabs u numru ta' multi. Dan kollu għaliex fir-rappurtaġġ tagħha ssemmi nies importanti fil-politika - nies ta' poter fil-Gvern Tork. Pelin hija omm, u din is-sentenza, jekk tiġi fis-seħħ, tkun tfisser illi l-omm tiġi sseparata mit-tarbija tagħha. Din hija amministrazzjoni krudili u bla qalb, u l-poplu Tork jixraqlu aħjar. Għalhekk qed insejjaħ fuq il-kollegi tiegħi hawn illum, fuq il-Gumsjoni u fuq il-Kunsill, ħudu azzjoni issa u itolbu flower-awtoritajiet Torok biex iwaqqkħu dawn l-akkużi fażulli kontra Pelin Unker.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: Mr President, supposedly suspension, but essentially a definitive cessation of accession negotiations with Turkey. Mr Weber, who believes that Turkey has no place in the European Union, wants to do so, even twenty years later. The Siemens and Deutsche Bank agreement of EUR 32 billion for Turkish railways shows us the privileged area of European Union-Turkey relations that some people envision, without, of course, the troublesome Copenhagen criteria. But others want it, as punishment for President Erdogan, for the unacceptable violation of the rule of law.  But all the democrats in Turkey, inside and outside the prisons, and Kavala and Demirtaş, all political parties, in a rare moment of agreement, are asking that we not kill their country's European dream. We know better, don't we? Business as usual and supposedly moral advantage, hand in hand, cancel the European perspective of a people of our neighbourhood, but also the only tool of our institutional intervention there, as the Greek government rightly argues.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: – Mr President, I have always taken the view that we need to keep Turkey close. Although neither side is under any illusions, the process of EU accession has proved beneficial to both Turkey and the EU. There is a saying that sometimes it’s better to travel than to arrive. This journey has been going on for at least 15 years; some might say over 30 years. Why add injury to insult and suspend it now? And surely it’s not in the interests of the EU to create animosity with its neighbours – Mr Barnier, take note. Over the years, there has been a range of obstacles to progress with Turkey; some real, some contrived. One consistent element has been Cyprus. The EU talks grandly about principles of democracy, but it is content to ignore the people of a third of the island of Cyprus. Seats allocated to the Republic of Cyprus should be used proportionately to represent the peoples of all parts of the island either through a Turkish Cypriot Member of the Parliament or through observer status, as is the case in the Council of Europe.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today, once again, we are preparing for Turkey's accession to the EU. But we should not really be talking about this in this House any more, because Turkey is now an Islamic country under its dictatorial caliph from the Bosphorus. It has nothing in common with the Western community of values in this Constitution. Turkey does not belong in the EU. My group has repeatedly requested that the accession negotiations not only be temporarily suspended, but that they should finally be brought to an end – so far to no avail. But now we have a new chance, because Manfred Weber said last week that he would end the accession negotiations if he became President of the Commission. Why wait, Mr Weber? Why not now, dear CDU and CSU? We can decide this immediately here in plenary. Vote in favour of my amendment No 17 on the final end of the accession negotiations! We call on you to give the electorate pure wine before the European elections and show how they really stand at the end of the accession negotiations.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have to enact several pages of very nicely written text. However, this is not a plebiscite on literary work – the beauty of words does not shape the political reality. This policy is, above all, the ability to build and use force. Today, the European Union is the area of the world that is growing at its slowest pace. Turkey, on the other hand, wants and can build its strength – boldly and brutally fighting its enemies, both external and internal. The joy expressed in the proposed resolution of Turkey's membership of NATO is a form of political naivety, as joint military exercises between Russia and Turkey took place in the Black Sea this month in March. There were more than forty ships in Turkey, and this summer the latest Russian anti-aircraft missile system is to be installed in Turkey. There is an S-400 "Triumph" system. Turkey is therefore beginning to rebuild its Ottoman empire. May we not wake up... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, two years ago from this step, I pointed out the insidious way in which Erdogan's Turkey is closing agreements. I had condemned the attempt to buy Turkey with billions of euros to solve the migration crisis. I was expelled, in breach of the Rules of Procedure, from the Chamber by the then President Schultz. Two years later, the Union wasted close to 5 billion, but Europe flooded illegal immigrants. Schultz went home failing on the German political scene, but his disastrous passage remains.  Weber has adopted my rhetoric and that not only makes me satisfied but above all vindicated. Of course, I do not see greek MEPs belonging to the European People's Party accusing Weber of racism, as they did in my case. Legally, in the upcoming elections, Europe will turn the page. Patriotic Eurosceptic forces will sweep stateless, internationalist and ethno-nihilistic tendencies.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: Mr President, I would particularly like to thank the rapporteur for this report. Mrs Piri, it is not easy to get a broad majority in this Parliament in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. You have done so, and that in itself is worth congratulating. It is also a lot stronger than the wetting and wetting that we hear from the European Council.  Nevertheless, I am very sorry that the rapporteur proposes to suspend the negotiations, but not to stop these negotiations in the end. I think, if you listen to colleagues, if you hear time and time again why Turkey is moving further away from the European Union every year instead of getting closer, then you have to draw the conclusion that you should go for an alternative partnership. So don't slam the door, but work on that alternative partnership, instead of trying again and again to revive those negotiations that are actually already stalled. Then I am very sorry, I must say to Mrs Piri, that she says through her own amendment 21: yes, we are going to suspend it, but do not worry, Turkey, in the end your European ambitions will be upheld. So it blows a little hot and cold at the same time. That's too bad. (The President deprives the speaker of the floor.)

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, first of all what I would like to do is thank Kati Piri, the rapporteur of this report, for her work, and not only for this year's, but for the five years of tireless work on Turkey, which has not always been easy. Today we send the umpteenth warning as a European Parliament to Mr Erdogan for the institutional deterioration that the country has suffered in recent years. A deterioration that has been especially profound after the coup d'am.  We have seen savage purges in public administration, systematic human rights violations, disrespect for minorities or arrests of journalists, day after day. And what has been the last straw has finally been constitutional reforms that have ended up transforming Turkey's identity: from a modern Turkey to a monolithic Turkey.  But today is also the day to send a message that Erdogan is not Turkey and we need channels of dialogue and negotiation. What? Conditionally, the modernization of the Customs Union. And, at the same time, visa liberalisation so that Turkey returns to the path of the rule of law.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Mr President, the report completely ignores the basic principles of law for solving the Cyprus problem and not only supports untrue facts, but lies blatantly when it refers to an alleged agreement reached in Crans-Montana. The bi-social bi-community federation that the report proposes as a solution to the Cyprus problem is not in line with the principles and values of the European Union and leads to the ex-Turkishization of Cyprus. The European Parliament already has a heavy responsibility for accepting the facts of the Turkish military occupation of the island.  The report absolves Turkey of any responsibility for not resolving the Cyprus problem and does not accept the interconnection of recognition of the Republic of Cyprus with the progress of the accession. For example, how do you want to update the customs union agreement when the existing one has not been implemented? Turkey is constantly and in fact threatening Cyprus. The report addresses threats with wishful meals. I will vote against the report because it contains falsehoods. It calls for a dangerous process of full conquest of my country by Turkey to continue, legitimises the occupation, supports the accession of a dictatorial regime to the European Union and, of course, for those who want to continue accession... (The President interrupts the speaker) One minute each year for the most important issue of my country: the occupation by Turkey.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you, colleague, I fully understand, we all have issues which are important to us, but I am afraid that the rules are the rules. I have to respect them, that is my obligation. However, you were absolutely clear in your message. Thank you for your understanding.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr President, in 1999 the European Council officially recognised Turkey as a candidate country for the European Community. Twenty years later, this report calls for the suspension of negotiations. Thus, Parliament procrastinates. Yet he would be proud to use language devoid of hypocrisy. Will it take another 20 years to make it clear to Turkey that it will never be a member of the Union? Unlike the Europeanists, our line has remained constant and firm. Already, in 1986, Jean-Marie Le Pen reminded him in a speech: Turkey is not European by geography, nor by history, nor by culture, not to the displeasure of the proponents of a multicultural Europe and to those who, like Erdogan or Chirac, have been able to affirm that Europe should not be a "Christian club". Turkey, on the other hand, has become Islamized since the fall of Constantinople. One hundred years ago, Christian communities still made up a quarter of the Turkish population, compared with a tiny percent today. This tragedy alone justifies us calling for a definitive halt to the negotiations, not just their suspension.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, Turkey is our strategic partner on security and migration issues. We must unequivocally condemn the abuse of the fight against terrorism to persecute critics of the regime and the political opposition. Not so long ago, three months ago, in December, we again demanded the release of political prisoners in Ankara for a joint EU-Turkey delegation. On the other hand, Turkish MePs are very interested in continuing the dialogue and the possibility of participating in programmes such as Erasmus and others. I am not a supporter of Turkey's accession to the European Union, but I believe that we must use all means to promote civil society, human rights and political pluralism. The European Parliament should use the suspension of negotiations to make this an impetus to set up a new form that should lead to partnership.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, I regret to note that a theatre of absurdity is developing and an attempt to serve interests. Some are talking about a break, but at the same time they are promoting the upgrading of the customs union. That is to say, no obligation on the part of Turkey, but to serve the economic and commercial interests on both sides, both in the countries of the European Union, but also in Turkey itself. Is that what we want?  Finally, let's make things clear. We want Turkey to have a European path and perspective only if it respects the principles and values of the European Union. Let us reflect: what has happened so far to the policy pursued? It imprisons Turkish citizens, ostracies European journalists, continues to own 40 % of Cyprus and threatens every day the exclusive economic zone of a Member State of the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, with my speech today I am supplementing 2,500 speeches and speeches in the plenary of the European Parliament in this term of office and I think it is important that this speech concerns Turkey, Turkey which illegally continues to hold 37 % of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus, Turkey which continues to threaten Greece and violates Greek territorial waters and Greek airspace. , Turkey which refuses to comply with international law and to allow the Greeks of the Dodecanese to access their property. All this, even though the Commission, after my intervention, has recognised that there is a question of so-called dodecanese properties.  The only solution for Ankara to be forced to comply is to impose diplomatic and economic sanctions against Turkey. Here and now, an immediate end to the European Union-Turkey accession negotiations and a cessation of all Union funding to Turkey.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the League said 'no' to Turkey's entry into Europe, it will continue to say 'no' to Turkey's entry into Europe because it is a crazy project, a criminal project: thinking of having 100 % Islamic a country enter Europe is something that would permanently destroy the West. The League says 'no' because one in 5 Turkish citizens claims to like Isis, because 3 million refugees are present in Turkey, because the European Court of Justice says that more than three thousand crimes and human rights violations have been committed against children, against women.  So these are some of the reasons why we will always say 'no' to Turkey's entry into Europe, and it would be insane, it would be criminal to think about continuing to move forward in a project that has already seen EUR 15 billion of European citizens thrown away to persuade Turkey to enter Europe. We use this money for the needs of Italians, for the needs of Europeans and not to throw it away... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: – Mr President, it is clear to all of us that Turkey's full membership of the European Union at this stage is unrealistic. Today, there are problems in Turkey in many sectors of socio-political life. There are problems with respect for the rule of law, fundamental human rights, freedom and independence of the media, which are fundamental values of the European Union.  But in Turkey there are opposition parties and a huge public mass of people who disapprove of what is happening in their country. European Union policy must be towards promoting political reforms in order to promote democracy in Turkey. It is important for the European Union to cooperate with Turkey on foreign policy, security and the economy. With all this in mind, let's ask ourselves how correct the report's recommendation on ending negotiations with Turkey is. Will the ceasefire make the border between Turkey and the European Union more secure? What alternative do we give to the vast majority of Turkish society that is pro-European? When we break bridges with Turkey, where are we pushing it? Will we push her towards Islamisation and radicalisation?

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I have already thanked Kati Piri personally and i will not repeat this here. As a long-standing journalist, I am particularly dismayed by the situation of press freedom in Turkey, and there is no improvement in sight. After all, journalists are still in prison in Turkey simply because they are doing their job. It is also unacceptable to me that foreign media representatives should be stripped of their accreditation, as was the case with the correspondents of ZDF and Berliner Tagesspiegel. The case of Max Zirngast is particularly concerning to us Austrians. The journalist spent four months in prison without charge and is still not allowed to leave the country. Nevertheless, we must not slam the door on the almost 50% of Turks who reject the government's course. Stopping the accession negotiations is not directed against the Turkish people, but is a response to the current government under President Erdogan. We must make it clear to the people that we are not giving up the democratic and pro-European forces in Turkey.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Mr Tellichka, allow me, honourable Member, to congratulate Colleague Piri on this report. Finally, after five years in this chamber, I see a report concerning Turkey moving closer to reality. The Republic of Turkey is not a European country today.  The Republic of Turkey is today a state that interferes unacceptably in the internal affairs of neighbouring countries. I can give an example of her intervention in the internal affairs of the Republic of Bulgaria. This intervention – inadmissible, unacceptable and reprehensible – is both in the spiritual affairs of Bulgarian Muslims and in the inadmissible attempts to do political engineering on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria. He tries to organize political parties, tries to influence political parties, tries to distort the results of elections in the Republic of Bulgaria. This is unacceptable and unacceptable.  I therefore insist that the negotiations with the Republic of Turkey be not just frozen, but terminated. I hope that tomorrow this House will vote on the specific text it implies, which obliges the Commission to terminate the talks with the Republic of Turkey.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Free and independent media are central values of the European Union and cornerstones of a genuine democracy. That is why, in this context, I also think paragraph 8 of Kati Piri's report is particularly important, which points out that there are disproportionate and arbitrary measures which, unfortunately, curtail freedom of expression and media in Turkey. An example of current reasons – certainly known to most: On Sunday, several German and other international correspondents had to leave Turkey because they were deprived of their work permit without justification. After the extensive synchronisation of the Turkish media, the foreign correspondents are now also to be intimidated. Domestic critics are considered terrorists, foreign critics as "enemies of Turkey." This is unacceptable, and it is a blatant violation of the freedom of the press. As the European Parliament, this cannot be criticised harshly enough.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank my colleague, Kati Piri, the rapporteur, for this extremely important work. Secondly, I wanted to say that, with the announced withdrawal of US troops from Syria, Turkey is now becoming even more important for the EU in terms of a solution to the Middle East security problem. Turkey is a key player that can help in restoring legitimate control by the Syrian Government over its territory and ending the eight-year-long conflict in Syria. EU diplomacy has a big role to play in favouring this peace commitment by supporting the Astana process and by recognising the roles of Turkey, Russia and Iran in the region’s stabilisation. We should not forget that it was Turkey and Russia who brokered a ceasefire in Aleppo, preventing a humanitarian disaster. Next month, another round of Syria talks will be held in Turkey, and the EU must use this chance to support the outcome of peace talks. The Astana process is strategically crucial to security in Europe, especially in terms of preventing foreign fighters committing attacks.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, I am reading a report which is – again – very sharp for Turkey, and lists very precisely what is going wrong in the country, especially after the coup attempt in 2016. But what I do not read or do not read enough are the appropriate conclusions, namely: no more European money for Ankara, stop the financing. The IPA II funds for Turkey may have been reduced, but they are still only a small part of the total budget that the EU spends on Turkey. Aid that has very little effect, because Turkey has only slipped further towards an authoritarian state.  Accession talks must be concluded immediately. Not suspended, but terminated. Turkey cannot become a member of the European Union. An upgrade of the customs union would also be a false signal. The root that this Parliament wants to hold up – upgrading in exchange for reforms – lacks credibility. Finally, no visa liberalisation, because it would pose major problems for the EU Member States. Those are the only correct conclusions. It is such a pity that I miss it in the report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, I believe that the dignity and credibility of the European Union is at the heart of Turkey and we in the European Parliament must defend European principles and values. They too will be able to be tried if Turkey is finally obliged to respect both resolutions and reports. Since it does not respect any of what we are discussing, we must react. And the only reaction when Turkey violates principles and values in occupied Cyprus by Turkish troops, when it violates the Cypriot EEZ, when it provokes Greece and Cyprus, member countries of the European Union, one is the reaction of the European Parliament.  If it does not implement what is recorded in the report, we should be forced to freeze Turkey's pre-accession aid. We have not asked any European citizen if he wants to give even one euro to Turkey today and we must do so, because that is the only way Turkey will finally comply with all that we are discussing and has never complied with. It is inconceivable that there should be an upgrade of the customs union without the recognition of the Republic of Cyprus, without breaking the deadlock on the Cyprus issue which, despite the goodwill of the President of the Republic of Cyprus, Turkey and Erdogan remain intransigent and provocative.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, no one doubts the important role that Turkey has played in responding to the migration crisis during the Syrian war. However, this does not mean that Europe is held hostage by an autocracy that crushes all who think differently.  The political purge is known. We have 150,000 arrests, 4,000 dismissed judges, more than 160 closed media platforms and more than 114,000 blocked websites.  But on the other hand, it is also these people who count on us. The situation, in fact, is bad, quite bad, and that is why this Union should be a bridge of dialogue through diplomacy.  There are objective criteria for Turkey's accession to the European Union. If Turkey meets these criteria, it enters, if it does not comply with them, it does not. It is up to us then to support the construction of efficient mechanisms that promote and protect human rights and democracy in third countries, and in this sense our support for civil society is fundamental.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Congratulations, Kati Piri, for the very good and important new Report on Turkey. There is a dramatic decline in democracy in Turkey, as we see in the arrests in the tens of thousands, but also in the dismissal of more than 152 civil servants. Freedom of the press, in particular, is particularly vulnerable in Turkey. Rebecca Harms and I were present at the Cumhuriyet show trial in Istanbul, and the journalist Can Dündar is now in Germany. He cannot go back. His wife's passport was revoked. We condemn this in the strongest possible terms. But German journalists have also stopped receiving press accreditation. In addition to foreign correspondents, it is Thomas Seibert and Jörg Brase from Tagesspiegel and ZDF who are no longer able to carry out their work there. We also condemn this in the strongest possible terms and see how much Turkey continues to restrict freedom of the press. That is why it is important that we now formally start suspending the accession negotiations, but that we do not completely break off the negotiations here, because we stand by civil society and the democratic forces in Turkey, which are committed to the rule of law, human rights and democracy.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I have always stood for human rights and democracy in Turkey since the beginning of my mandate and it’s very sad to see how much the situation has deteriorated over the past five years. Calling for the suspension of accession talks is painful because I’m convinced that Turkey’s future lies in Europe. My regular contact with Turkish civil society has convinced me that Turkish citizens long for human rights and democracy. However, the government’s crackdown against human rights defenders, academics, civil servants, trade unionists, journalists, women, ethnic minorities and LGBTIQ+ people makes it impossible to continue a fruitful dialogue. Zehra Doğan, a Kurdish, feminist journalist and artist who I have been twinned with as part of a project led by Human Rights Watch and the Committee to Protect Journalists, was recently released but her case shows just how Turkish authorities target any critical voices.  The ongoing hunger strike by hundreds of Kurds around the world against the isolation of Abdullah Öcalan is further evidence of huge dissatisfaction with Erdoğan’s regime.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, what is Turkey today? An open prison with a massive violation of human rights and a breakdown of the rule of law. Out of Turkey? An expansionist force that violates international law and with an Islamist political agenda. The policy of the European Union has unfortunately been poisoned by the economic interests and political aspirations of individual states at the expense of our values. The most important example: Turkey's obligations to the European Union, which concern a small Member State, the Republic of Cyprus, have never been fulfilled.  By the way, such hypocritical policy by the European Union feeds the anti-European forces, which want to destroy the European project. In order to have credibility, therefore, the policy of imposing sanctions and embargoing the sale of arms had to be already in the report. I'm sorry he's not in there and much more I'm sorry because unfortunately some of you will regret it in the future.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Mr President, Erdogan and his allies have virtually destroyed all of Turkey's democratic institutions. The character of this new regime is manifested in particular by the repression of the opposition and is aimed primarily at the Kurds and the HDP. The President of the HDP, Mr Demirtao, sent me a letter from his prison, in which he asked for a freeze, not a suspension, of negotiations with Turkey. Ms. Bodil, Mr. Solé and I visited her last December. Commissioner, Europe must continue the dialogue with Turkey in a transparent manner, with a close and critical look, particularly in view of the forthcoming local elections. Turkey is not Erdogan. The Turkish and Kurdish peoples deserve our attention and cooperation. We must not leave them alone in the face of a dictator who has jailed more than 150,000 civil servants, who has closed more than 2,000 NGOs and more than 200 media, also deputies... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Mr President, Turkey continues to trample on the human rights and basic freedoms of its people, while illegally and by force possessing arms on the territory of a Member State of the European Union. It is unacceptable to ask for an upgrade of the customs union when Turkey refuses to fully and indiscriminately fulfil the obligations under the current agreement and refuses to recognise the Republic of Cyprus. The EPP, in a show of populism, proposes an end to accession negotiations, at the same time as it advocates the unconditional upgrading of the customs union.  We call on you, ladies and gentlemen, to vote against the proposal for an unconditional upgrading of the customs union, as it goes against every rule of operation of the Union and every concept of law. At the same time, we expect the Union to put pressure on Turkey to implement all its cyprus obligations. To end illegal actions in the Cypriot EEZ, to withdraw the occupying army from Cyprus, to end the settlement and to contribute in practice to the resolution of the Cyprus problem, on the basis of a bi-social bi-community federation, as defined in UN Security Council resolutions.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the one in the picture here is Leyla Guven, on hunger strike since 8 November 2018. On hunger strike also to demand that Öçalan be removed from the isolation he has been in turkish prisons for more than twenty years.  What we can see in Turkey is now a permanent state of exception following the coup d'état, which has been used to stabilise an authoritarian regime. I myself went to Ankara to try to attend the trial of the two HDP presidents who were also detained, as did many other HDP Members, Selahattin Demirtas and Figen Yuksekdag. It was not possible and we were denied access.  Today I am going to greet and meet the people who are on hunger strike here in Strasbourg in solidarity with Leyla Guven and to demand that Abdullah Öcalan be removed from isolation. I believe that this Parliament should take a stand.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, Turkey, even geographically, is not a European country, does not embrace and does not wish to embrace the values of Western culture, discriminates against religious minorities, including Christians and Alevites. The Erdogan government daily fires and prosecutes civil servants, teachers, doctors, academics, lawyers, judges and prosecutors. Turkey, with an invasion since 1974, illegally holds a large part of Cyprus. Turkey pursues an aggressive policy against Greece, violating its airspace and territorial waters every day. It refuses to sign and ratify the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. Turkey supports and funds terrorism.  We demand an immediate, formal and definitive cessation of accession negotiations. We demand the complete cessation of all European financial aid to Turkey and, moreover, the application of economic and other sanctions. We call for Turkey's formal repudiation of any expansionary claim against Greece and the complete and tax-free release of the occupied cyprus. Until then, this killer state has no place at the same table as the Member States of the Union. In the European Union, Turkey has and should never have a place.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for all their contributions and remarks. I think we are all equally concerned about the state of EU-Turkey relations and the Council has already found, on the Commission’s proposal, that the accession process has effectively come to a standstill and that no further chapters can be opened or closed. I believe that the best way to strengthen our relations is by remaining critically engaged with Turkey and keeping channels open, and I think, unlike some others here in the plenary, that starting discussions about an upgrading of the Customs Union could be one of the opportunities, provided that some preconditions are fulfilled. At the same time, it is important to be crystal clear that Turkey must respect the norms and values to which it has subscribed, both as a candidate country and as a member of the Council of Europe. We have underlined the need for Ankara to take clear steps to improve the human rights situation in Turkey and to fix contentious bilateral issues with EU Member States, and we will continue to do so. The Commission will continue to report on developments in Turkey in the context of our annual enlargement package due later this spring. We will also continue to use our instruments to support a vibrant civil society and those in Turkey who consider that democratic society starts with accountability and with checks and balances.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, to conclude, I wish to thank the House for the very useful debate. I have listened carefully to the views expressed and I take note that our institutions have similar assessments on a range of issues. We look forward to continuing this constructive dialogue and engagement. I can assure you that the Council will continue closely to monitor developments in Turkey, paying particular attention to the important issues discussed here today. The imminent 54th meeting of the EU—Turkey Association Council, which will take place at the end of this week, on Friday 15 March, will provide an excellent opportunity not only to take stock of the state of EU—Turkey relations but also to reiterate our views on the challenges and the opportunities of our cooperation. We will convey to our Turkish interlocutors the unequivocal message that they must urgently and effectively address the shortcomings and outstanding issues identified both by you in your report today and by the Commission and the Council. At the same time, I believe that all sides have much to gain from an intensified dialogue at all levels. On our side, the Presidency, together with the Member States and the Commission, will continue to do what we can to move things forward. Finally, let me thank Parliament for its contribution and the rapporteur, Kati Piri, for her efforts in providing a comprehensive overview of developments in Turkey. Parliament’s role is important in the wider political process in which we operate. Engaging the citizens of both Turkey and the EU Member States in democratic discussions remains important and is in the best interests of both Turkey and the EU.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, Minister, and my colleagues. Let me first come back to what the Council, as the presidency, has said – because you say that all channels of communication must be open with Turkey. We all agree. But the channel of accession – that’s the one that we should close – because it has become a ridiculous channel. Minister, you said, ‘we take note and we continue to follow’, and I am very happy to hear from you in your conclusion that on Friday’s meeting with the Turkish President, you will put human rights at the top of the agenda. I’m very happy to have that commitment. But also, I want to hear from the Council, how are you going to help Turkey’s democrats? Will you provide extra funds for human rights defenders? Will you put respecting fundamental rights as a key conditionality, including in the trade relationship? I really hope that the Council will come up with a more sophisticated strategy than we have seen so far in how to deal with Turkey.  I didn’t hear more than five colleagues in this room who agree with the strategy of not having any consequences to the accession process. We have a big majority in this House to call for the formal suspension of the accession talks – to stop talks – I want to make it clear – to stop talks with President Erdoğan about accession. It doesn’t make sense. They have become totally ridiculous and incredible. But I also heard some colleagues from the far right and some members from the EPP Group who want to go one step further – not only stopping the talks, but also taking away the candidate status of Turkey. Now, I’m surprised to hear this. For 10 years, we had a Turkey rapporteur from the EPP who never made this call. If it’s really about human rights violations then stick with the majority in this House calling for the suspension of the accession talks.  Perhaps I’m still hopeful that in the years to come, in the decades to come, things in Turkey will improve. I hope we all share that things can change inside Turkey and that means we shouldn’t put a final stop forever on talks with Turkey on EU integration.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 March 2019.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the emergency situation in Venezuela (2019/2628(RSP)).

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, we welcome Parliament’s continued focus on the situation in Venezuela and your commitment to a lasting solution to the crisis in that country. It is important to use all the tools we have to encourage a peaceful and democratic solution, to be achieved through free and credible presidential elections. Since our last debate on Venezuela in this plenary at the end of January, tension and polarisation have further escalated and living conditions have been worsening. The number of Venezuelans leaving their country continues to grow. According to the UNHCR, some 2.7 million Venezuelans have left the country since 2015 and the number could rise to 5 million by the end of the year if the crisis continues to worsen. The recent nationwide blackout that is still affecting certain states is contributing to a further deterioration in health services and in the supply of food and water. As we all know, this crisis has at its origin a political and institutional problem. The current situation has built up over years of attacks against democracy, the constitution and fundamental human rights. The solution to the crisis needs to be political as well as democratic, peaceful and Venezuelan owned. Political prisoners need to be released and the powers of the National Assembly have to be restored as the National Assembly is currently the only democratically elected body in the country. We have also called a number of times for the constitutionally mandated immunity of all National Assembly members, and of Assembly President Juan Guaidó, to be respected. They need to be able to exercise their political mandate without fear of reprisals or intimidation. We firmly reject the use of force to resolve this situation. Any military option would only cause more human rights violations and more suffering for the people of Venezuela. At the same time, it is essential to avoid an escalation of violence within the country. We have called for a halt to attacks and intimidation against civilians and lawmakers, from both security forces and irregular armed groups. The only way to end this crisis is to let the people of Venezuela express their will through a democratic presidential election that must be free, fair, inclusive and transparent. With this goal, the European Union has promoted the creation of an international contact group on Venezuela. The purpose of this group is to help create the conditions for a political process that should lead to free and fair presidential elections. The contact group has set a clear timeframe to verify whether we can encourage some guarantees to give credibility to the electoral process. The electoral supervisory bodies need to be reformed, starting with the National Electoral Council. The electoral register needs to be updated. All political parties and leaders need to be able to compete on equal terms, and political prisoners should be released. Independent electoral observation should also be ensured. Our proposal does not aim to buy time. We are convinced that an international initiative can help build these minimum conditions, which would eventually lead to relaunching a meaningful political process and to new presidential elections. Meanwhile, it is urgent to address the pressing needs of the population. This cannot wait for a political settlement of the crisis. Lives are at risk. Humanitarian assistance needs to enter the country unimpeded and reach those in need. In the past two years, the European Union has committed more than EUR 67 million of humanitarian and development assistance and we are ready to scale up this assistance. The contact group is exploring the possibility of establishing an international mechanism for coordination and delivery of humanitarian assistance inside Venezuela in close cooperation with the United Nations and our international and local partners. The aid must be delivered impartially on the basis of the population’s real needs and not that of a political agenda. It must be distributed by independent actors under the leadership of the United Nations. Aid should never be politicised and it should serve only humanitarian purposes. The international contact group is now working on these two main areas: elections and humanitarian assistance. The group sent a technical mission to Venezuela in February to discuss with all sides the conditions and guarantees for holding credible presidential elections, and also the delivery of humanitarian assistance. A senior officials’ meeting discussed the results of the technical mission and a new ministerial meeting will be held at the end of March in Latin America. We Europeans are not neutral. More than one million Venezuelans have either a European passport or a family in Europe. We care about Venezuela and its people, and the people of Venezuela are asking for change. At the same time, we believe that change cannot be imposed from the outside. A sustainable solution can only come from the people of Venezuela. We are ready to do all in our power so that Venezuelans can be the masters of their own destiny.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if we were to run out of electricity right now, in an hour all patients who are in intensive care would die; in fifteen hours we would run out of insulin; in twenty hours, water would no longer come out of the tap; in one day the food that is in the fridges would be ruined; in two days babies in newborn units would die; within three days, the water we had stored would cease to be drinkable and, from the fifth day, patients who need dialysis would die. It would be a huge catastrophe.  Well, here's what's happening in Venezuela: more than a hundred hours without electricity. The Venezuelan people are helpless in the face of hunger, thirst, lack of medicine, in the face of the wicked who travel the country armed, sowing terror, in the absence of a national currency.  Nicolás Maduro has become the metaphor for death in Venezuela and his regime in death itself. Those who have created them cannot solve problems; can't solve problems those who don't see them.  The European Union must persist in the demand for the release of all political prisoners, starting with Luis Carlos Díaz, a Spaniard who has disappeared today for fulfilling his work as a journalist.  The European Union must increase the list of sanctions and should increase the list of sanctions. It is outrageous to see the children of the party generals in Madrid, as the people agonize in the mud. The European Union must support any decision to throw away the tyrant taken by Juan Guaidó or the National Assembly.  The image of today's news members is the town of Caracas going down to the river to collect faecal waters to drink them. Can we remain impassive? What does the famous contact group do to that?  Venezuela's democracy is our democracy; Venezuela's freedom is our freedom. Venezuela's hunger should be our hunger. If it's not for convictions, unless it's because there are two million European citizens locked up and terrified of the Venezuelan people.  If we really believe that being Europeans is a matter of principle, let us not leave Juan Guaidó or the Venezuelan people alone.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I have run out of words to condemn Maduro, but I think it is also time to make very serious and very dramatic forecasts, certainly not only because of the lack of light, but because, I would like to make a mistake, but I sincerely believe, ladies and gentlemen, that the risks of an internal confrontation in Venezuela are growing. And I want to make a mistake, I repeat, but the ruin of the country can end up in a social contest or worse and, in any case, without a solution.  That is why I believe that the European Union is succeeding in seeking a peaceful negotiation, a democratic exit. And, by the way, ladies and gentlemen, the only ones who can speak to Government and opposition today are the European Union and the Contact Group together with Costa Rica, Ecuador, Bolivia. And these countries can and should make internal reconciliation, the internal peaceful exit. There is no other way to avoid social strife and for the exit to be democratic and peaceful.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the failure of the Guri hydropower plant last Thursday was yet another devastating blow to the people of Venezuela: the latest challenge to present itself to an already beleaguered, long-suffering and demoralised people. The exact causes of the problem are still difficult to ascertain, given the secrecy and the ludicrous claim circulating that this was an act of sabotage by the USA. Much more likely, it seems, it was the result of underinvestment, attributable to the many years of corruption and mismanagement under the Chavez regime – a pattern we now see continuing under Maduro. Reports suggest that all current attempts to resolve the situation have resulted in a worsening of the problem, with more substations and the wider national power grid now affected. With some 80% of the country’s population now affected, it is difficult to overestimate the severity of the problems as hospitals and other key services and infrastructure struggle to keep afloat. I call upon all those EU Member States that have yet to do so to recognise Juan Guaidó as the interim President of Venezuela, in order to bring some relief to that broken state.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Venezuela is in a deep crisis of massive human rights violations in the face of food and medicine shortages, hyperinflation, violence and political repression, which has forced more than three million people to flee the country.  Nicolas Maduro's social control strategy through fear and punishment against those who demand change is repulsive. His government is getting dirty with the most impoverished people he claims to stand up for, but who he then murders, detains and threatens—it's not my words: it's Amnesty International's february 20 report.  With Maduro, poverty reaches 87% of the population and the minimum wage—minimum, of course—is six dollars per month. Venezuela has the honor of being country 168 on the list of the most corrupt in the world, in the company of Syria, Somalia and Afghanistan—countries at war, because Maduro is at war with his own people.  Talking about justice in Venezuela is sarcasm. The judges name them early. Selective extrajudicial executions by the Bolivarian national police occur, as Amnesty International denounces in the report I have presented to them, and the Helicoide is a reference of horror, of torture by SEBIN.  Democracy is absent. The legitimately elected National Assembly is duplicated by the mature Constituent Assembly. Guaidó is the rightful representative, the rightful president, not Maduro.  The country has been without electricity for five days and people drink water from the sewer that runs through Caracas, the Guaire River.  And there are still those who will talk about it as a revolutionary process and support it. The revolution to the last Venezuelan, of course, not of its illustrious skins, which demand electricity, light, medicine and food, what the Venezuelan people do not have.  I ask for our Venezuelan brothers all solidarity, and for the repulsive kleptocratic class mature all sanctions.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I seem to be living in déj vu and I do not say this because of the many times that the Venezuelan affair has been dealt with in this House. I say this so often that this Parliament, with the humanitarian excuse, has accompanied and instigated the path of military interventions or violent agendas of change of government.  I think of Libya and Syria and see the same lies of democracy and human rights, when all that mattered was to bring down sovereign governments to access gas or oil. Did you apologize? Did you spend a minute thinking about the total destruction of the Libyan state or the support of the terrorist groups that ravaged Syria? In Venezuela they use the same lies.  After the failures of a coup, street terrorism, murder, they disguise a criminal blockade as a humanitarian crisis and sabotage of the electricity system as a management crisis. The same lies as two weeks ago with the trucks of supposed help—burned by Guaido's followers.  Lies to help Washington hawks destroy the Charter of the United Nations. They are lies to hide the craving to knock down a government that is not to his liking. They didn't care about the poor when they ruled their own, as they don't care about the more than 500 children who die each year in La Guajira or the 120 social leaders killed in Colombia in these three months of 2019. Stop lying. Stop tying up the criminal war. Get your hands off Venezuela.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, only the Venezuelan people have the right to decide for themselves their future and for the internal affairs of their own country. We condemn and denounce the imperialist plans promoted by provocations, contact groups and all the undermining means of the United States, the European Union and their allied governments in Latin America, to overthrow the President-elect of Venezuela by putting their straw man. All of them did not take the pain for the Venezuelan people. Their aim is to control the energy of a rich country.  We condemn any scenario of a coup d'état and an imperialist military attack that is christened humanitarian aid or other pretexts. We express our solidarity with the Venezuelan people hit by the capitalist crisis and the struggle of the Venezuelan Communist Party. Imperialism is not invincible. The real superpower is the people, and they will win.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, following the resolution adopted a few weeks ago, I was wondering what the main task that the European Parliament has to perform in order to help resolve the Venezuelan issue. The first thing I believe is to remove this debate from a simple propaganda and instrumental dimension.  I believe that, in the current political stalemate, there is an urgent need to find a democratic way out of the crisis through free and credible presidential elections, in the knowledge that the solution can only be peaceful and democratic. There are and cannot be any other options because they would cause more damage and suffering to the population.  Humanitarian assistance is also essential, and it must be allowed through appropriate channels. These are the two options on which the European Parliament can attest. I repeat: other hypotheses would only represent unnecessary and harmful forcing. In a situation like this, complicated and difficult, I think the only thing that should guide us is political intelligence.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Mr President, do you know why Venezuela is in the dark? Because criminals need her to commit their crimes.  The Chavista regime is incompetent, authoritarian and corrupt. That is why, in Venezuela, a country rich in resources, the light is lacking, food is missing, medicines are missing. Maduro's regimen is responsible for every baby, for every patient who dies in a hospital from blackouts.  The regime is also responsible for the unlawful detention and imprisonment , today – of journalist Luis Carlos Díaz , by the way, a Spanish citizen; by the way, a European citizen.  The regime wants more darkness for its crimes. Why? Because he wants to exterminate en masse, without spending a bullet.  And I'm going to tell you straight. Do you know what the International Contact Group is for in these conditions? To make a fool of themselves, to discredit the European Union.  Do you know what it's like to be without electricity for five days? Nothing works — you can't take money, you can't buy food, the gas stations are closed, there's no water.  Venezuela has a legitimate interim president with a roadmap that we are committed to accompanying: cessation of usurpation, transitional government and free elections. If this is his plan, this must be Europe's plan and he, Juan Guaidó, is our only contact.  With the country in a state of national emergency, all Mrs Mogherini has to do is call President Guaidó and ask him what exactly the European Union can do for him and for the Venezuelans, and then do it.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, the Venezuelan people have been without access to electricity for five days, and access to water for many is also dependent on. The little food that rots, shops, schools, transport, services, stop, no generators die children, old people, sick people in hospitals, the news is erased. Venezuela is in the abyss. Maduro must be quickly run by the Venezuelan people. Nothing will be solved without free and genuine elections in a months-long horizon. The Armed Forces must defend the people, the state, not the rotten click, for corruption, for maduro's drug trafficking. The international community must make it clear that Maduro and his stooes will face international justice, they will not escape. The Russian and Cuban regimes must understand from the European Union that they will pay dearly the price of taking the removal of the guangue that insemente led Venezuela into this abyss. It's only a matter of time, because it's only a matter of time. It is not sustainable to keep Maduro and maintain the terrible suffering imposed on the Venezuelan people. The European Union must be clear about this.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr. President, Venezuela is on the brink of collapse. The latter-day blackout is one of the uncontrollable cases that confirm that Maduro is not the leader the country needs. He's a tyrant. It is another example of what Venezuelans suffer because of a regime that neither represents nor respects them. The blackout is further evidence that the European Union cannot continue to wait. We need to expand selective sanctions and ensure that the regime surrenders power peacefully. The European Union has two options: actively support a legal, peaceful and democratic solution, such as that proposed by Juan Guaidó, or to be awaited as witnesses to more deaths, more crimes and more suffering until Venezuela fails completely. The choice is ours. We have to respect Venezuelan democracy and the Constitution in our approach and this logically implies Guaidó's recognition as interim president. I hope that we can welcome President Guaidó to this Parliament soon.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, the situation in Venezuela is an emergency and an emergency situation. With the failure of electricity, the situation of misery and hunger has become clearer, but now even emergency by water, from virtually closure of hospitals, from clinical aid, from health aid to people who are at risk of life. Today the problem of Venezuela is no longer just a problem of dictatorship and democracy, it is a problem of life or death, it is a humanitarian emergency problem. I must say here that many Members in this Parliament have often been here who have announced that this was going to happen, and that must also be put to their credit, because we, the European Union and the international community, have taken a long time to recognise that Maduro is a dictator, and he is not just a dictator, he is being a despot and, in a sense, , truly a murderer to his people. We have to undo Maduro. (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, my struggle for freedom and democracy in Venezuela is not now, as is the case with some colleagues who have arrived in this cause. And so I want to say that in a terminally ill country like Venezuela, a four-day blackout has tremendous consequences.
