Supermarkets, many of them owned by Portuguese, are soothed and the damage is not only greater because there is little left to sell and in hospitals premature babies die and many patients whose vital functions depended on the equipment now turned off. To say, like Maduro, that the precariousness of electricity infrastructure is the result of international computer sabotage and American economic sanctions is a fallacy and is, above all, an insult to the millions who come out of Venezuela desperate and hungry. The collapse of the electricity system is the result of years of corruption and incompetence of a dictatorial regime that has long taken advantage of these blackouts to divert to offshore many millions of petrodollars that the country receives. These regime kleptocrats and those responsible for crimes against humanity in Venezuela must continue to be subject to Union sanctions, which now also need to be extended to their families.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The situation in Venezuela is indeed dramatic. It's children's drama, maternal drama, drama of older people, drama of whole families. But I want to make it clear that the ideas that have come up in the chamber, from my point of view, are unreliable in terms of actual effectiveness. I believe that our political interventions will have a very limited effect. What needs to be focused, of course, is the mobilisation of international opinion and humanitarian aid. And I think it is very important to remember that Venezuela has been struggling with these problems since de facto 1948.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Mr President, Venezuela's usurping government is crumbling. It remains only in power as a result of the use and exercise of brute force amid enormous suffering from the population.  The question, Mr President, is how much suffering Venezuelan society still has to experience and how many deaths the 21st-century socialism experiment has yet to be charged until its final collapse.  The country is in an absolutely chaotic situation, Mr President, and yet repression does not stop.  We are talking about the journalist to which other colleagues have referred, whose immediate release we request. We have seen harassment of the crew of the airline Air Europa and have seen the destruction of humanitarian aid on the borders of Brazil and Colombia.  Commissioner, the European Union cannot remain impassive in the face of serious and systematic violations of human rights, the respective sanctions must be increased and diplomatic sanctions effectively implemented.  I have not heard a protest over the expulsion of the ambassador from Germany...  (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: – Mr President, it is regrettable that one of the richest energy-rich countries on the planet has been in the dark for more than five days and is living the worst energy crisis in its history. And that's not what the imperialists and other false conspiranoia are to blame for. It is Chavista socialism that has led to chaos and despair. While in Venezuela citizens, as my colleagues have said, go to look for contaminated water and children die in hospitals, it turns out that, since 2013, electricity installations in Venezuela have been militarized. And Cuba continues to act like a real vampire, sucking more than 80,000 barrels of oil a day.  The European Union must demand that power plants be recovered and returned to the Venezuelan people, represented by Acting President Juan Guaidó, and that those shipments of oil by the Government of Nicolás Maduro to Cuba be stopped. These decisions are a priority.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the desupply, hunger, the absence of medicines, corruption, have been suffocating Venezuelans for years. That is why Maduro lost the election and an Assembly was invented to maintain power. Then came the sanctions.  Blackouts, which today aggravate the drama in the country, are further proof of the inability, inhumanity and incompetence of a regime to which some international agencies are already investigating as the perpetrator of a crime against humanity.  Last week, on the border with Peru, I had the opportunity to listen to Maduro's victims: people with training, with a future elsewhere; men and women condemned to hunger, marginalization, in need of humanitarian aid blocked by the dictator. They want a free and peaceful country.  And the solution goes through the contact group, to maintain a strong and common European position and to organise a free and credible election already.  And I want to show my opposition to any solution that is attempted outside international law.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, blackout, there has indeed been a physical blackout, but there is also an information blackout to talk about the two faces of reality. Commissioner, have you seen the New York Times article? I do not believe that the American newspaper is an accomplice of Maduro and yet they belie many lies, many fake news, and you know the worst? That there are many speakers, especially conservatives in this Chamber, who are not concerned about the people of Venezuela, make speeches of Spanish domestic consumption to apply as European candidates. Nor are they interested in the montevideo contact group and boycott it from time to time they are looking for a solution of dialogue. How can they talk about dialogue if they don't want dialogue, they just want business as usual, business, oil, money, money and money. They should be concerned above all, because soon their seats will be occupied by the far right. With that, yes, you should be worried.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am going to ask you four things.  One, leave Venezuela alone so that, as you said, Commissioner, it is Venezuelans and Venezuelans who decide their future.  Two, who are not cynical and who, if they are really interested in democracy and human rights, condemn America's attacks and criminal actions. Attacks like the one that has produced the blackout that is being talked about so much here, but which is not being said where it comes from.  Three, let them show that they are interested in the Venezuelan people and not their oil.  And four, get their hands off Venezuela and use their time to develop policies that really put an end to the impoverishment of the working class and no longer enrich multinationals.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, the credibility of the debates on Venezuela in this Parliament has been soothed, if ever. They blatantly and shamelessly mind the reasons for this debate, the electric blackout in the country, seeking to give the legitimate government of Venezuela responsibility for what we know to have been a terrorist sabotage of the Venezuelan electric system. You don't want dialogue or peace, but listen well, your intentions, your support for the most reactionary sectors of the Venezuelan opposition, your following to the Trump administration, everything has failed, the blackout has failed, the farce of humanitarian aid burned by the opposition on the border, your self-proclaimed puppet has failed. You trample on international law, the principles of non-interference and respect for sovereignty enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations. They seek to set the country on fire, compromising the interests of communities, such as the Portuguese, which resides there and works there. The Venezuelan people mobilized in the streets remain steadfast and resilient, saying they will not give up their independence and Bolivarian revolution and shouting "get your hands off Venezuela."

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, the situation in Venezuela is an absolute tragedy. What has led to it is socialism, which when in government always leads to catastrophe; and absolute socialism has led to absolute catastrophe. The people there are in an awful place, a crisis is going on. The only thing I can possibly say that could make it worse is well-meaning but bumbling intervention. I suggest that the EU and other foreign players be very, very careful about this and that they then be there to trade with – and, in the diplomatic sense, talk to – the Venezuelan people when they get back on their feet.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful and meaningful exchange and I thank the honourable Members for their contributions. EU policy towards Venezuela will continue to encompass both elements of pressure and the political channels through which we can contribute to a peaceful and democratic solution. We will continue working with countries in the region and other international stakeholders, notably through the International Contact Group, and will use all our instruments to accompany the country towards a peaceful and negotiated solution. Of course, Venezuelans both in Venezuela and abroad will continue to be our key concern, and we will continue our efforts to help address their needs. Let me close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the international agenda.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I understand that one colleague was asking for the floor under the catch-the-eye procedure, but I have been informed that that was the case only the moment we started the catch-the-eye procedure. The rule is that the procedure was then closed. I am sorry, but my colleagues did not see you. I apologise but I cannot do anything about it. I will take an unusual step and give you one minute. Do you want the one minute? We are running out of time. Once again, for all colleagues, the rule is that in catch-the-eye you ask for the floor. You eventually get the floor, but the moment we start speaking it is closed. So, colleagues, we were right not to take that request, and in any case I did not see it. My apologies. You now have one minute. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, I know that Venezuela was living in a period of darkness — we already knew this — but with an unprecedented humanitarian crisis. But today that darkness is not a metaphor, it is a reality in a city where children die in hospitals, without light, without water, with a...  We have already seen Maduro's reaction at the border, burning trucks with medicine in front of the sick, burning food in front of the hungry...  And Europe keeps talking about the contact group. And Maduro laughs at our contact group and our dialogue; months and years we've been seeing it.  I believe that the European Union cannot speak of free elections only in a non-concrete way. You have to talk to Guaidó and set a date and know what you are going to do, not just say... Because Maduro's never going to call a free election.  So all I want to do is tell the brave Venezuelan people... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you, colleague, the same rule applies to everyone: one minute sharp. We are behind schedule. Once again, please remember what I have said about the rules on the catch-the-eye procedure. I have no other option. The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the next part-session. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. – Just over half a year ago I led a delegation from the European Parliament to the border between Brazil and Venezuela. Even with a deep knowledge of the dramatic situation in that country that led - and continues to lead - to an exodus of millions of Venezuelans, what I observed there left me deeply restless and outraged. Since then almost everything has worsened: economic conditions, the humanitarian crisis, political repression. Only one thing has improved in Venezuela in recent times: with Juan Guaidó resurfaced hope. What has happened in recent days, with the death of many people due to an electrical blackout of the sole responsibility of the sinister regime that the tyrant Maduro continues to lead, surpasses all that is morally acceptable. Guaidó and everything he means today need an active solidarity, which goes far beyond the hollow words of those who, deep down in themselves, cannot truly break with the illusion that anything progressive and left-wing persists in the kleptocratic dictatorship that does not want to leave power in Caracas and refuses to give voice to the Venezuelan people.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The credibility of the debates on Venezuela in this parliament has been soo-great if it has ever had it. They blatantly and shamelessly. Take the reasons for this debate. The electric blackout in the country, seeking to give the legitimate Government of Venezuela responsibility for what we know was a terrorist sabotage of the Venezuelan electricity system. They want neither dialogue nor peace. But listen carefully! Your intentions, your support for the most reactionary sectors of the Venezuelan opposition, your following to the Trump Administration, all failed. The blackout failed, the humanitarian aid farce burned by the opposition on the border failed, and your self-proclaimed puppet failed. You trample on international law, the principles of non-interference and respect for sovereignty enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations. They seek to ignite the country by compromising the interests of communities such as Portugal, which resides there and works. The Venezuelan people mobilized in the streets remain steadfast and resilient, saying they do not give up their independence and Bolivarian revolution and shouting: Take your hands off Venezuela!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Anna Elżbieta Fotyga, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on a European Parliament recommendation to the Council and the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy concerning taking stock of the follow-up taken by the EEAS two years after the EP report on EU strategic communication to counteract propaganda against it by third parties (2018/2115(INI)) (A8—0031/2019).

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, it is my privilege to present recommendations to the Council and the Vice—President/High Representative prepared two years after the adoption of the important report on the EU strategic communication to counteract hostile propaganda against it by third parties. I served as the EP rapporteur for the other report as well. The first report, adopted in November 2016, was divided into two parts. It indicated major actors in this work against the EU in the presentation of hostile propaganda. It was a state actor, namely the Russian Federation, and non-state actors, predominantly radicalised Islamic organisations like Isis. This time we decided to structure the report’s recommendations differently, thanks to the contribution of representatives of major political groups in the Parliament. We divided the recommendations into parts, indicating the state of play in 2018 and targeting the hybrid warfare methods of this. We stress there the necessity to avoid censorship while countering the hostile propaganda, disinformation and misinformation that is presented to the EU and its Member States. We stress the importance of quality journalism sustaining freedom of speech and freedom of the media. We also indicate the notion of possible legislative regulatory activity, at both EU and international level. There parties indicated the necessity to even introduce humanitarian law to deal with cyber—warfare or information warfare. We stress the changing patterns of a variety of actors. In terms of radicalised organisation, we mentioned that, instead of very popular websites that increased the level of radicalisation of young people, there are methods of encrypted messaging services that are very popular. Much has been done, both within the EU institutions, EU-based institutions and organisations, and by civil society during those two years. We mention all of these activities in citations. I would like to stress the importance of the Code of Practice on Disinformation, the activity of the European Endowment for Democracy (EDD), as well as the transatlantic cooperation, and cooperation with like-minded countries and institutions like the Transatlantic Commission on Election Integrity on this. In the second part of this report, we focus on indicating types of misinformation, disinformation and hostile propaganda. The third part is dedicated to methods for safeguarding our elections. The current year, 2019, is the year of over 29 elections in EU Member States, including the European elections that are to take place at the same time. After the experience of interference by the Russian Federation in elections and referendums in the EU and elsewhere, we have to strengthen our resilience to this kind of activity. We indicate the role of East StratCom and complement its activity, also indicating two other task forces for the Western Balkans, the Middle East and the North African Gulf area.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, many thanks for making time to debate the challenge of disinformation and foreign interference, which is more urgent than ever in view of the European elections. Thanks to all who contributed and in particular to the rapporteur, Anna Elżbieta Fotyga, for delivering such a timely and helpful recommendation. It closely matches the logic and actions set out in the action plan against disinformation which the High Representative and the Commission submitted to the European Council. The response against hybrid threats should be a joint enterprise. We are doing, and will continue to do, our part, but Member States need to step up efforts collectively too, as the European Council indicated in its conclusions. The recommendation underlines the centrality of freedom of speech and expression, as well as media pluralism, to resilient democratic societies. Indeed, our fundamental values must be at the heart of our response to the challenge of disinformation. This is precisely the spirit in which we have drafted, and now are implementing, the action plan against disinformation. The report calls on the EU institutions to ensure that EU strategic communication becomes a matter of high priority on the European agenda and that the EU institutions and Member States work hand in hand in fighting against disinformation. I can assure you that all of this is already happening. However, this is a long—term endeavour which goes beyond this year’s European elections, so we are counting on the European Parliament’s continued support, not least in budgetary terms. With the action plan against disinformation, we are increasing the staffing of our three strategic communication task forces to better enable them to detect, analyse and expose disinformation, and raise awareness of its negative impact, as well as – crucially – to improve the way in which we communicate about our values and policies. Next week we launch the Rapid Alert System, as set out in the action plan. The system will make it easier for Member States to share assessments, data and best practices in tackling disinformation. This will, ahead of the European elections, bring better situational awareness, make it easier to determine responsibility for attacks and promote joint response, if and when needed, including in terms of awareness raising and increasing our society’s resilience. I appreciate your acknowledgment of the work done so far by the East StratCom Task Force, both in terms of positive communications and in addressing disinformation. I would also like to praise the other two task forces, for the Western Balkans and the South. The East StratCom Task Force had a pioneering function. To date, it has catalogued, and raised awareness of, more than 5 000 cases of disinformation coming from Russian sources. Unfortunately, the number is likely to rise further, as the problem will not go away anytime soon. It is our collective duty to keep the European elections clean from foreign interference. One way to do it is to raise awareness about the challenge, closely cooperating with the media, civil society organisations and online social media platforms. The European External Action Service is working on this in full concert with Parliament’s and the Commission’s services. Obviously, the action plan will fully respect the different national approaches, with freedom of expression and freedom of the media as guiding principles of our action. In parallel, we are building better cooperation in tackling foreign interference and hybrid threats with our international partners, such as NATO and G7. To give an example, our cooperation with NATO already involves sharing assessment reports on the information environment and conducting parallel and coordinated exercises involving hybrid threat scenarios, such as the base exercise. In addition, we should partner more with our neighbours to promote a positive European agenda. Investing in the EU’s positive communications and public diplomacy in our neighbourhood is crucial in addressing disinformation and promoting European values and interests. Cultural and economic diplomacy and close cooperation between EU Member Statesʼ missions and the European Union delegations on the ground are powerful tools for projecting a positive image of the EU in the world. The best antidote against disinformation is, on the one hand, to promote a healthy media environment and, on the other, to spread the word about the positive impact of EU policies. Our citizens, as well as the citizens of our region, have the right to make decisions based on correct information, not on fake news. They have the right to a pluralist media environment and to high—quality information. This is about the quality of our democracies and about the quality of our Union.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would first like to congratulate Mrs Fotyga on an excellent report, which came at the right time. We have a text recognising the existence of disinformation campaigns and hostile propaganda and calling on Member States to take proactive measures, measures to counter propaganda, effective measures to respond to proven cases of espionage by third countries, an exchange of information between Member States, as well as educational investments and the allocation, last but not least, of them adequate funds for istrat.com. Information warfare is as current as possible and the Union is obliged to act firmly. Let us remember that, since 2013, Valeri Gherasimov declared that "the role of non-military means of achieving political and strategic objectives has increased and, in many cases, exceeded the power of weapons through their efficiency". So we are not just talking about promoting lies, we are talking, above all, about annihilating the ability of our own citizens to distinguish between truth and lies. Not coincidentally, recently Putin congratulated those who work on the design of this propaganda: "I congratulate them on the active, fruitful and talented way in which they work". So it is time to act firmly. Europe urgently needs strong action and, above all, coordination with NATO and G7 partners. Otherwise, those who continue to argue otherwise or promote non-action endanger the interests of the 500 million citizens, endanger the values, security and even the integrity of the European Union.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the In just over two months' time, an election will be called again in Europe, and, as with Brexit, the election of the American President and the decision on the French Presidency, we are faced with particular challenges, namely that we are being bombarded with disinformation, fake news and propaganda articles on the Internet and, in particular, on social media. And they are often formulated in such a way that many users will have difficulty distinguishing facts from fiction, information from propaganda or truth from lies.  I therefore fully welcome the fact that a separate department of the European External Action Service is working to prevent these anti-democratic excesses. In spite of everything, I believe that these can only be first steps. The problem I see is that technological progress has long since overtaken countermeasures and is constantly doing so. On the whole, we are still fighting yesterday's disinformation with funds from the day before yesterday.  When we look at the field of artificial intelligence, we shudder at what is coming or is already on the market. People are literally being put in their mouths that they never did, and the fake video is indistinguishable from a real one. How can a politician prove that he never said that when it was heard and seen in the same way, albeit fictitiously?  Finally, Let me thank all those who were involved in the preparation of this report. It was my last collaboration as shadow rapporteur. I will no longer be a member of the next Parliament. It was a particular pleasure for me to have helped shape the European Union as a representative of Austria. I hope that this process will not be slowed down by nationalist or populist currents, because only a united, united, strong Europe can meet the great challenges of the future.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! Congratulations to Minister Anna Fotygi for this report – a very important report, because we are on the front line. It is that cyberspace, the media are instruments used against Europe, against European freedom, by third countries – specific third countries and it is worth calling them by name.  Political life creates such opportunities for us to be attacked by these instruments. We have European elections – they can be an opportunity. We have Brexit - it can be an opportunity, too. We also have other situations that we already know will be exploited by the enemies of freedom – for example, the decade of the creation of the Eastern Partnership, which is a salt in the eye for some of the European Union's neighbours – including my country's neighbours.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, access to information increasingly risks receiving unverified information. All EU Member States and countries that continue to deny the existence of disinformation and hostile propaganda, as well as its impact on public opinion, should recognise them, evaluate the situation within their territories and take proactive means in order to counteract and debunk them. We have to break down the existing market for fake news, lies, disinformation and propaganda in the European Union, which is effectively fuelled from inside and outside. There are different kinds of terrorism – from military ones to social security threats. Informational terrorism is one of those which we must regard as a threat to public order, security and the fundamentals of life and of our societies. Informational terrorism is directly connected to hybrid warfare and attacks the minds and hearts of our people. To make the ongoing battle between so-called elves and trolls more successful, we have to address current deficiencies in the East StratCom Task Force as its lack of regional expertise, institutional weaknesses, etc., requires urgent decisions in turning the East StratCom Task Force into a fully-fledged structure with increased support and funding.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Unlike the first Fotyga report, the representatives of the political groups were much more in agreement in the negotiation of the new report. In my opinion, this has to do with the fact that our experience of organised misinformation, propaganda and incitement in our countries has now gone much deeper. The country we have to deal with the most on this issue is Russia. Not only has Ukraine become a battlefield, but Russia is now directing more and more efforts, with ever-increasing resources, to incite citizens of European countries against their governments – most recently seen during the yellow vest protests. Citizens are being incited against migrants, but also against the EU, for example during the Brexit vote. In my opinion, the Department of Strategic Communication for the Detection and Prevention of Organised Disinformation needs to be substantially strengthened. More experts need to come in, there needs to be more money in. And it is very important that this department can also cooperate with Member State authorities in the future. This necessarily includes the secret services and NATO. However, paragraph 1a of the report must not be forgotten. Independent free media, pluralism in democratic societies are the be-all and end-all to stand up to incitement and propaganda.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, two years have passed since the presentation of this report. No one would say. The same accusations without strong evidence, the same arguments based on communication theories discredited decades ago, the same shortsightedness when it comes to a good-neighbourly policy with Russia.  Worse, the same willingness to blame the results of internal political processes here in Europe on external actors, when it is the electorate that punishes majority parties for their neoliberal policies.  And, to top it all off, this report includes a reference to the so-called Islamic State that all it contributes to is worsening our relations with Russia, equating it with a group designated as a terrorist by the United Nations.  This Parliament proposes to set up independent communication groups and journalists. But how can you be independent if you receive funding from the European Union? This Parliament does what it criticises and does not criticise what it does.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is undeniable that the scale of hybrid threats, especially those related to the dissemination of information, is becoming increasingly strategic for our societies, especially now that new technologies have increased the intensity, speed and scope of these attacks in an interconnected global context. On the basis of this fact, I wonder, ladies and gentlemen, whether the report we are going to vote on really serves to protect citizens from potentially harmful actions by third parties, be they states, non-state actors or even terrorists.  Perhaps a more balanced text, dealing with both disinformation and the jihadist threat online, a text that is not limited to a precise list of countries, would have been more desirable, when we know that there is less and less precisely in this area, let alone on the part of those states that often use so-called proxies. Finally, a text that addresses strategic communication holistically and does not focus, as has happened, on a single geographical dimension, and also using vague terminology and sometimes bordering on censorship.  These, in my view, are the demands we should be facing. However, these demands are not reflected in this report, because the intentions, although I support them, have been partially declined and, if I may say so, not effective.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Mrs Fotyga, you are not really dealing with strategic communication. You are proposing coercive measures to combat undefined propaganda from countries hostile to the European Union. You are inspired by the same conspiracy logic and, I dare say, Bolshevik, as the Kalniete report. You see the foreign hand behind any dissent from the European project: Brexit? It's Putin! The yellow vests? It's Moscow! Is it raining in Warsaw? It's the Russians' fault! Censorship must now be deployed to condemn the popular will that is rising across Europe. We are in a Stalinist approach. When are the re-education camps? This is the good old communist days: every opponent is a traitor. Madam, you are betraying the legacy of a great Pole, St. John Paul II, who wanted to work for a Europe with Russia, a Christian Europe, capable of giving his breath of the mind to a world now multipolar, to a europe without a soul. You thus cut Europe off from its Russian soul and its soul. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Indrek TARAND
text: blue-card question. – Mr Schaffhauser, would you agree with me that comparing Ms Kalniete with Stalinism and all sorts of things is a little bit inappropriate because, according to my knowledge, she was born in a Siberian gulag? That’s the end of the question. You can answer now.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: "blue card" answer. I had the opportunity to speak to Ms. Kalniete yesterday about her experience in the gulag. Unfortunately, she didn't listen to me while I was talking to her. I told him that it was a matter of intervening with Russia, not only out of feeling or even resentment, but that there was also a need for a little reason in his analysis of the situation. I would say that I can say all the more that I fought communism and that, on 8 September 1989, it was here in Strasbourg that we gathered all the anti-communist forces before the fall of the wall.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, let us tell the truth once in this Chamber. You don't mind the propaganda, gentlemen of the European Union. After all, the Union itself has the highest proportion of propaganda directed at citizens. It only bothers you anything that turns against your own interests. The Union funds hundreds of non-governmental organisations, which are propaganding the ideologies of the detainees at the moment. In fact, you had the audacity to baptize your own beliefs as values of the Union, without ever, of course, asking the citizens of the Member States about this.  What is worse, however, is that your attitude demonstrates the fact that you consider citizens incapable of judging the information they receive and choosing the positions that represent them. On the contrary, with a fatheristic logic, you believe that only you can point them to the "right" view. For you, citizens are free to vote whatever they want, as long as they agree with you. For us, the citizens of the Union have the mind and knowledge to judge and decide who represents them.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: –Mr President, if there is one recommendation to be repeated over and over again, it is that the East StratCom Task Force should urgently be turned into a permanent fully fledged structural unit of the European External Action Service (EEAS) and properly supported with adequate financial and personnel resources.  Secondly, we have to continue support for the work of the European Endowment for Democracy (EED) aimed at strengthening democratic and independent national language media in the EU neighbourhood and within the EU itself. And thirdly, a recommendation aimed at all political parties in the EU: be transparent about donors, big and small. European voters deserve to know which parties are directly or indirectly funded by the Russian intelligence services or global mega companies to make them into mouthpieces for these foreign and not always democratic interests.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, propaganda against the EU is not just about homegrown far-right nationalist Eurosceptics, who sit in this House with the intention of destroying the European peace project. As I discovered whilst working on the 2016 report, this phenomenon is about Russia and other countries who do not share our European values. Having successfully influenced the 2016 UK referendum, Putin’s agents could have a huge impact on the forthcoming European elections. The EU therefore needs to take proactive measures.  Firstly, tech companies should invest much more in tools to identify propaganda and ensure better identity checks of platform users in order to eliminate bots, and to reduce financial incentives for those who profit from disinformation.  Secondly, we need more awareness at political level. For example, the French far-right MEP, Aymeric Chauprade, gave employment to the daughter of President Vladimir Putin’s spokesman here in the European Parliament and this should not have been allowed.  Finally, the UK Government continues to ignore the hostile propaganda that proliferated in the Brexit campaign, so we must have a Mueller-style investigation in the UK regarding the dark money and the interference that clearly entered the campaign.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Mr President, in order to counter propaganda, it must understand its mechanisms. They may be different from country to country. In Romania, for example, Dughin's thesis is broadcast by the foundation of a former socialist prime minister, through the conferences of an actor from the National Theatre and with the help of a retired colonel. All this while the current government is itself the source of fake news about the European Commission and the European Parliament. The CVM is described by ministers as a tool based on erroneous information, and the resolutions adopted here as electoral manipulations. No wonder, that's why the Prime Minister, our former colleague Dancilă, is praised by Sputnik every week. Let us add that the main news tv stations are controlled by convicts of corruption, who argue that the rule of law is a manipulation of George Soros. Finally, Facebook closed 31 pages that manipulated the opinion in favor of the Romanian social democrats. Here's what propaganda needs to be countered in my country!

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. Chairman, the Cambridge Analytica scandal clearly confirms the extent of external influence on elections and referendums. As we await the news from London, let us remember all the false information passed on without sanction to the citizens of Britain that has significantly influenced the result of Brexit.   As for the upcoming European elections, Russian influence through various media channels and social networks, which reaches the European Parliament, should not be ignored. This is certainly not an agenda for a stronger European Union, quite the opposite.   Let's also highlight the impact of hybrid warfare on our Western Balkans neighbourhood involved in euro-immigration processes. One coup attempt is also suspected.   But Russia is not the only source of this kind of action. Fake propaganda comes from the West and the Middle East. All have similar operational action and the same goal – weakening Europe's democratic institutions.   I support this report and the proposed measures. In the run-up to the European elections, it is essential to ensure that citizens make decisions based on truthful information, as the future of the European project depends on their decisions.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Given the scale of the active hybrid propaganda war against the European Union, we must recognise that the measures we have taken so far are not sufficient. I firmly support the Foreign Office's Strategic Communications Task Force to grow into a permanent counter-operative unit for disinformation campaigns, and to be adequately financially and staffed. Not only the European Union but also member states need to make such structures. For example, Bulgaria created such a structure. I know other countries have them, too. Under the leadership of Commissioner Mariya Gabriel, the European Commission has also proposed a coordinated response to this challenge: a code of conduct on online platforms, measures to promote education and critical thinking, especially for the young generations of the European Union, support for objective investigative journalism. All this must be put into effect as soon as possible.  Our response to hybrid warfare must also include measures to identify and sanction those responsible for organising and conducting disinformation campaigns through online media, influence agents and others. Of course, criticism of the European Union – not every criticism is a hybrid war. The European Union is not a sacred cow. We must all be critical of what is happening around us, but also not allow third parties to wage hostile propaganda against us.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I actually wanted to say to Mr Freund that I can agree with his entire speech – he is unfortunately no longer here – but that I was surprised that in two minutes he failed to call the name 'Russia'. This may be an Austrian speciality, but it will not help you. I would like to call the child by its name. Russia's main concern is to destabilise the EU. The main thing is to weaken the mainstream. Anything that contributes to this is attractive. The days when Russia, like the former USSR, has its own ideology is over. We must be aware in all the countries of the EU that this is taking place in order to weaken the resilience of our people. Where money is flowing to support like-minded people, Mr Schaffhauser, we need legislation to prohibit this, and we need the appropriate exchange of information from our competent authorities. The EU could play a coordinating role in this. I therefore hope that the EU's East Stratcom working group will be strengthened and that it will continue to network with relevant experts in the Member States.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, Europe faces a grave threat to our democracies. The ability to argue with facts against lies, disinformation and propaganda from third countries, is becoming more and more difficult. We must strive at both EU and national level to defend our values and fight off cyber- and information warfare.  It’s a problem we face both in the EU and in the regions on our borders, in the western Balkans and the eastern neighbourhood. In this respect, we need the European External Action Service (EEAS) East StratCom Task Force with particular regional focuses, which need to improve communication on EU topics. I also support the call for improving the funding and resources for these structures and their cooperation with official EU bodies such as EU delegations in third countries. Countering this information and hostile propaganda needs to be a priority, not only in the European elections but also for the incoming European Commission, Council and Parliament. We need to do a much better job in communicating the EU’s values and policies effectively. Otherwise our democracies might not survive this external pressure.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, East StratCom has delivered excellent results. It has analysed and collected more than 5 000 examples of pro-Kremlin disinformation. We keep demanding that East StratCom is turned into a fully-fledged structure within the European External Action Service with adequate financial and personnel resources. Financing has finally increased but is still lagging behind exponentially growing tasks – because next to East StratCom, there’s also the Western Balkans StratCom and Task Force South. The EU Action Plan has an important task – to improve capabilities, enhance coordination and joint responses by EU institutions and Member States, develop better cooperation with the private sector, raise public awareness and promote education on disinformation, and not least provide adequate resources. Networkers and fact-checkers could be helpful in tackling disinformation, and the Commission task is to coordinate their activities into the European network.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, Mrs Fotyga's report contains a total of thirty-eight recommendations to the Council and the High Representative of the Union. The aim of the recommendation is to combat propaganda against the European Union by third parties. One of the most important recommendations in the report is to raise awareness of Russia's disinformation campaigns, as they are the main source of disinformation in Europe. In 2014, Russian General Gerasimov set out a doctrine of new kinds of attacks, according to which the words used are stronger than missile systems and tanks. If Gerasimov speaks of appropriately used words, there is no doubt that he means a lie. The lie has become the official doctrine of Kremlin politics. It is high time that we realised this in the European Union. To realize that we are losing the hybrid war with Russia. We've lost the ability to call things by their real names. We have lost the ability to defend the European Union. Russia is not our ally, Russia is our enemy.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. Chairman, I am in any case concerned about the disinformation that has been coursing around the European Union lately coming from third countries. We should certainly be worried. I therefore maximally support this report, which takes into account that we are in some way coordinated against such disinformation. I understand that the fight needs to be at national level, but since the internet has a cross-border dimension, I am sure that we need to exchange best practices and make deals.  I also support this position which says that Russian propaganda is very important, that is, very negative and that it definitely influenced the referendum in the UK. And today we suffer the consequences of that referendum, not only us but, I believe, British citizens, whatever you think about it. In any case, a strong fight against disinformation and the impediment of third-party interference in the electoral process is needed, especially given the Elections to the European Parliament that follow us.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by At the beginning of this term of office, I pointed out that hybrid conflicts, hybrid wars require hybrid responses, hybrid responses, that is, very complex ones. The basic components of these appropriate responses should consist precisely: the fight against propaganda, the fight against disinformation, but also security in cyberspace, education at every level or cooperation, which is what the report calls strategicity. I must say that, in some ways, I am disappointed with the Commission. It should be noted that this report, to which we refer today in 2016, including this year, is not an initiative of the Commission. It is an initiative of the Chair of the Committee on Defence and Security. It seems to me that, in this matter, the Commission should be ahead of the facts. The fact that MEPs are at the fore front in cybersecurity or information, in the fight against disinformation, is not a good signal. It is a signal that the European Commission is reacting too late to various problems that arise in public spaces and in the security area. I would like to stress that these recommendations – there are almost forty of them – are well addressed, well written, well described and at the right time. It is important today that reactions to them are not late.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I apologise, but I was having a meeting with Mr Barnier who, as you can imagine, at this moment is quite busy. So it was impossible for me to attend here on time. Mr President, I would like to stress essentially the following: the issue of propaganda and, in particular, of the one which is essentially aimed at misleading the public and which, as we know, is parallel, in essence, to the whole discussion we have had of fake news, is today, we know, extremely dominated by third countries. And I think that here we have to take a very determined action to block any possibility of often evil strategic interests, third countries and some well-known ones, such as Russia, to influence our election campaigns, our debates, our referendums. And i therefore welcome this attitude of the Commission in combating this type of action.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, hybrid warfare is not a novelty, but the accelerated development of information technologies has opened new channels and today it is easier than ever to reach people with propaganda.  On the other hand, citizens' trust in institutions is at a historically low level, which opens up a lot of room for action for those who want to influence democratic processes and public opinion in Europe. My colleague Fotyga did a great job, so I can only support the recommendations in this report. I think it is worth pointing out, although this should be clear in a developed democracy, that there are also legitimate criticisms at the expense of the European Union, its leadership and individual Member States, and that not every criticism is hostile. I emphasise this because the Union leadership has been trying for some time to attribute any criticism to external and internal enemies, rather than listening to citizens and bringing about changes in line with their demands.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, in this day and age marked by the rapid evolution of technology, the principles and methods of propaganda can be applied in many different ways, the main of which are the falsification of the truth and the dissemination of false news. The basic principle for a democratic society, so that it can deal with hostile propaganda, is to present the truth to the public and not to prosecute political opponents and journalists, who criticise the government or present various scandals.  At national level, public information, objective and non-discriminatory, is achieved through the creation of an operational broadcasting system. Many times, however, this system does not work properly. This is the case in Greece, where national broadcasting has become a party organ of the ruling party and even goes so far as not to invite MPs and MEPs from the party to which I belong, Golden Dawn, which is the third political force in the country, to the broadcasts. As you understand, with such methods there is unreliability and it is not possible to counter any hostile propaganda.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, disinformation, which is becoming more common in social and traditional media, threatens democracy. It is important that citizens receive accurate information in order to form informed and fact-based voting decisions. Social media social media social media services like Facebook have a big responsibility in identifying and removing disinformation from their platforms. It is important to detect efforts to influence false and false information as quickly as possible before they become widespread. Online platforms also have a duty to ensure the transparency of political advertising and to find out who is behind the ads. Active fake user accounts, of which there are millions, must also be deleted as quickly as possible. Technological advances make it easier than ever to make fake videos that look real, for example. The bite of fake news must be prevented, above all through education and awareness raising. I would like to emphasise the promotion of media literacy in solving the problem.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, we are discussing misinformation, propaganda and fake news here, but these must also be applied against the European Parliament itself, because, as you all know, the European Parliament has commissioned a polling company to poll for the European elections, which, instead of polling, has taken the polls at national level, polls carried out for national elections and has drawn conclusions about who is elected and who is not elected by this European Parliament. , how many MEPs of us will not be elected and how many will supposedly be elected. This is black propaganda, on the eve of the European elections, it is fake news, it is guided propaganda against certain MEPs.  This must be denounced and banned and the European Parliament must stop this tactic, because it is a disgrace and that is why all colleagues must take a stand. Do not allow fake news, that some of us will not be elected because a polling company says so and this has been reproduced in all the media, all over Europe. It's a disgrace, it's a disgrace!

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Thank you very much for this passionate speech.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There have been many indications that we are dealing with false information provided by the electronic media, including by traditional media, but also such information falls in this House in the European Parliament and also during this debate. Today we had an example of this on the part of Mr Schaffhauser, who wiped his mouth with the memory of St. John Paul II. He went so far as to point out that those who act in accordance with the teachings of John Paul II, who carry out the programme he has set out, indicated that they were acting on the contrary. This is a situation, this is the basis of an extremely evil one, requiring condemnation. Those who are dealing with this issue are acting in accordance with the teachings of John Paul II, it is obvious to them all. On the other hand, this statement by Mr Schaffhauser is likely to be broadcast, reproduced and perhaps even in some countries as the main line of expression during today's Debate of the European Parliament. And this is also an example of this, of misinformation, of telling obvious untruths, which here in this House are obvious untruths, and already outside this room in certain places they can be presented as something completely different, as the main line of this debate.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange. I thank the rapporteur, Ms Fotyga, and the honourable Members for their interventions. From this debate, I conclude that we overwhelmingly share a common interest in tackling the challenge of disinformation and foreign interference ahead of the European elections. This debate has been a further opportunity to increase awareness about the subject. I close by reiterating once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the agenda.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, disinformation poisons the minds and conscience of people affected. The best example of this was accusations delivered against persons like Sandra Kalniete and myself. Well, it is Putin who affirms the policy of Stalin, not ourselves; he tells it himself. And there are well—known fans of Putin in this Chamber from time to time. I would like to very warmly thank all shadow rapporteurs. Their contribution was really excellent. I’m aware of deep debates about this topic within each political group. I think that the final outcome is a real contribution to further work by all EU institutions in countering hostile propaganda. I would like to thank especially Charles Tannock, who assisted me in a very difficult period of preparation for this report when I had certain health problems. Thank you very much indeed.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 13 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – The increasingly aggressive steps taken by Russia, China, Iran and North Korea, which seek to undermine the foundations of European democracy and the sovereignty of the Eastern Partnership countries, are not acceptable and must be combated consistently. It is important to develop a legal framework at EU and international level to combat hybrid threats, including cyber and information warfare. Russia's disinformation campaigns are the main source of disinformation in Europe and therefore a fully-fledged structural unit working under the European External Action Service should be rapidly transformed from the Working Party on Strategic Communication in the Eastern Neighbourhood in order to combat Russian propaganda. Third-party interference in elections must be stopped, and it is important that EU countries change their electoral laws, taking into account the potential risks posed by disinformation campaigns, cyber-attacks and cybercrimes.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – the recommendation made by Anna Fotyga, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of a Partnership and Development Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, on the other hand (15093/2016 - C8 0107/2018 - 2015/0302(NLE)) (A8-0026/2019) and - a report by Anna Fotyga on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, the Partnership and Development Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, of the other part (15093/2016 - C8-0107/2018 - 2015/0302M(NLE)) (A8-0058/2019)

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development (CAPD) between the EU and Afghanistan was signed in February 2017, partially and provisionally entering into force on 1 December 2017. It was upon a Council decision that the agreement remains a mixed one, meaning that both the EU and Member States are engaged in the process of ratification. The security situation in Afghanistan remains difficult, yet over 56% of the territory is under the control of the Afghan Government. That means that more than 65% of the population is also under the control of the Government. Since 2002, when the EU engaged in financing, more than EUR 3.66 billion of humanitarian aid has been delivered in Afghanistan. For the decade of transformation starting in 2015 we intend to deliver a further EUR 1.4 billion to stabilise this country. Efforts by the NATO International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) operation and current resolute support with the participation of many countries, including my own, has brought development to the security situation, although, after the emergence of Islamic State Khorasan (ISK), the Daesh cells and groups that emerged following operations in Iraq make this situation still vulnerable and fragile. The CAPD focuses on areas of relevance to the rule of the law, good governance, human rights, economic stabilisation and social stabilisation. We have to acknowledge and compliment the good achievements reflected in the statistics. Access to health care has increased, due to European assistance, from 9% to 57%, a huge development. Life expectancy has increased from 45 to 60. The level of education – schooling, access to schools – is much higher. Voting patterns, in terms of participation in elections and the empowerment of women, also represent achievements in this country. The agreement was signed by Vice—President / High Representative Federica Mogherini and by the Minister of Finance of Afghanistan, in the presence of the country’s President. We parliamentarians consider it regrettable that information about proceedings in the negotiation of the agreement came to this Chamber considerably late, after the signing of the agreement. While our role is substantial, we participate, in accordance with the Treaties, in the consent procedure for this agreement. I welcome and support it. I hope that it will be voted on positively.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the honourable rapporteur, Madam Fotyga, for your report, your positive opinion and the consent expressed on the conclusion of the EU-Afghanistan Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development. After decades of war, Afghanistan stands at a crossroads. Last year was the deadliest ever for civilians since the start of the war in 2001. Yet 2019 could be the year of peace. In recent years, the European Union has engaged even more closely with the Government of Afghanistan to accompany the country in this delicate moment of its history.  This is the goal that we set both in the Afghanistan strategy of 2017 and in our latest Council conclusions. This agreement represents the first legal framework governing EU-Afghanistan relations and is the result of a long negotiation process.  The agreement is now being applied provisionally and we already had a promising start to our structured dialogue and cooperation. Two bilateral meetings took place in 2018 where we discussed a number of key issues that we have agreed together with our Afghan friends. These include human rights, gender issues and good governance, development cooperation, trade, regional cooperation and migration. On all of these files, Afghanistan wants to make substantial progress for the benefit of its citizens and we Europeans have offered assistance and support. We paid special attention to the situation of Afghan refugees in the region. The European Union remains committed to working towards finding a comprehensive and durable regional solution by supporting the predictable, safe, orderly and dignified return of Afghan nationals residing in neighbouring countries and to continuing to implement the EU’s regional programmes on migration and forced displacement. In your report, you draw a realistic picture of the situation in Afghanistan. I would like to elaborate a little more on the current developments related to peace. The situation on the ground remains worrying. Innocent Afghan men, women and children continue to suffer from this conflict. Yet there are good reasons to hope that this year could finally bring good news for the country. President Ghani’s peace offer for the Taliban in February 2018, just a little over a year ago, has created an unprecedented opportunity for peace, and since September last year, the US and the Taliban have been negotiating international troop withdrawals and counter-terrorism commitments. We know that lasting peace will take time. A quick agreement is not necessarily a lasting one. This is why the European Union is committed to supporting Afghanistan before, during and after a peace agreement to ensure that this will be sustainable.  Last November, at the Geneva Ministerial Conference on Afghanistan, hosted by the United Nations, High Representative Mogherini made a concrete five-point offer to Afghanistan about how the European Union could support a peace deal. First, we can help make the peace process more inclusive. Second, we can assist with reforms, including in the security sector. Third, we can help with the reintegration of former fighters and their families. Fourth, we can act as a guarantor of a possible peace agreement, and fifth, we can promote regional trade and connectivity. Since then, we have been working closely with our Afghan partners to better define our assistance. We are launching a dedicated peace mechanism to help repair and build capacities for inclusive negotiations. As the High Representative said in Geneva, the Afghan people are asking to move forward and there is no going back. During the coming months, we will continue to work together with the international community to support a better electoral process for this year's presidential elections in Afghanistan. As you rightly pointed out in your report, the EU committed a large amount of funding in terms of development aid. At a Brussels conference on Afghanistan in October 2016, the EU and its Member States pledged EUR 5 billion, and this pledge is currently being operationalised. Let me also mention the fact that the EU development support for Afghanistan has a strong focus on peace and state building and supports Afghanistan in its regional contacts. With other development partners, we are exploring how to adapt the existing development programmes to a peace scenario. This would include supporting post-conflict reforms, social cohesion at community level, cross-border trade and regional connectivity. Afghanistan has a unique chance for peace. We Europeans will do everything in our power to help the people of Afghanistan turn this opportunity into a truly sustainable and lasting peace.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has It is a somewhat absurd situation today. We are to approve an agreement which has been in force for the time being for more than a year and which has not been transparent at all in the process of trade-off. In fact, if it were not for Afghanistan, I would say: this is not the way to deal with the European Parliament! That is why I am once again making a clear statement to the Council, but also to the Commission: it is not acceptable for an agreement to be applied provisionally without this democratically elected House giving its consent. This is not at all a concept of democracy. In the area of trade, we have a clear agreement that no agreement will be applied provisionally before the European Parliament has said yes. And that is what I am asking the Commission and the Council to do as a general principle. We are the democratic institution of the European Union, we have the right to be transparently involved and to take a decision here in our democratic House before any entry into force.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I completely disagree with the utter. It is not at all the case that the Consent of the European Parliament is needed for any cooperation. That cooperation, on the other hand, is now entering a decisive phase and, at that stage, that consent is necessary. I am pleased that the Committee on Foreign Affairs has adopted a positive recommendation for Parliament's consent. I am pleased that there will be the first formal cooperation between the European Union and Afghanistan, but I am particularly pleased with the report itself, which in all respects is simply complete – it contains political and strategic aspects, talks about the role and responsibility of regional actors, raises issues relating to security and peace-building in Afghanistan, but also state-building, because this country is still under construction. I also draw attention to human rights, which are very often undermined in Afghanistan, to issues relating to the economy and, in particular, to development and trade. But what is also crucial is the migration processes themselves. It must be remembered that Afghanistan fears migration from Pakistan or Iran – it is not prepared for it. And it is very important that, in the final phase of the report, sectoral cooperation is also included. This makes this report, in short, complete.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development confirms the EU commitment to Afghanistan’s future development during the decade of transformation – 2014 to 2024 – and lays the foundations for the Union’s continued support for the country in implementing key reforms. Through the report I’m also trying to flag up the point that, despite the significant progress made, Afghanistan still faces substantial challenges that require further stronger, longer force to safeguard and build on these joint achievements. I also put emphasis on a more constructive dialogue on human rights, in particular the rights of women, of children, and of ethnic and religious minorities, which are essential elements of this agreement. The agreement aims to develop EU—Afghan relations in a growing range of mutually beneficial areas, such as rule of law, fighting terrorism and extremism, improved governance, achieving sustainable peace in development, combating terrorist financing, countering narcotics smuggling, fostering inclusive and sustainable economic growth and social and rural development and addressing global challenges such as climate change. Afghanistan needs to refrain from involving proxies in internal rivalries. Neighbouring countries should contribute to the stability of Afghanistan instead of undermining it.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all let me thank Anna Fotyga for her excellent job in drawing up this report being presented to us for our attention and consideration. The EU-Afghanistan Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development brings the EU’s relationship with Afghanistan to a new qualitative level of mutually beneficial cooperation. Undeniably, Afghanistan has made very significant progress in many fields, as rightly mentioned by Anna before. However, security concerns, corruption, human rights issues and other problems still persist, endangering the current achievements.  Afghanistan is at a crucial point in its history, as in the absence of further efforts, all of the progress and sacrifices hitherto could be wasted. Withdrawing the coalition forces prematurely could have negative consequences and should be decided by all consulting allies.  The European Union is committed to a long-term partnership with Afghanistan. Therefore, following the November 2018 Geneva Conference on Afghanistan, the European Union announced a financial package worth EUR 474 million to support state-building and public sector reforms, health, justice and elections, as well as to address migration and displacement challenges in Afghanistan.  I hope that this Agreement embedded in a regional approach which includes the Afghanistan neighbourhood, the global powers and the international community, can pave the way for a better future for the country. The first step to the path of stability is peace. Achieving a peace agreement between warring parties in Afghanistan is a priority at the moment, and I hope very much that the Qatar process of negotiations will include the Afghanistan Government in the very essence of this meaning. In particular, a peace deal cannot compromise the values of democracy, human rights and rule of law. The citizens of Afghanistan deserve this.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the It is good that objectives of an agreement with Afghanistan – including the eradication of poverty, the implementation of the UN development goals, gender equality – bring about action on an equal footing. However, it is not as if we have no experience with the strategy of neoliberal, so-called reforms that guide the new cooperation agreement that we are discussing here today.  As early as 2003, the West began a neo-liberal, radical market transformation of the economic system with the IMF in Afghanistan. Numerous studies and the experience of the years show that such a concept of pacification is inappropriate to improve the social situation of the population and to contribute to stabilisation. The current situation in Afghanistan is a disaster, but I fear that the agreement promoting foreign direct investment, the private sector and the exploitation of natural resources will not help this tormented country, but will, above all, increase the profits of European companies.  The agreement also includes the deportation deal, which was informally agreed in advance – and here I am putting a signal of exclamation point – with the cynical name 'common way forward', which sends African refugees back to their deaths together. This inhumane practice must be brought to an immediate end.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, in the last 17 years, the allies, within the framework of ISAF and the EUPOL mission and others in the European Union, have wanted to give voice to those that the Taliban regime has oppressed, women and ethnic minorities in particular.  History has taught a bloody lesson in Afghanistan, that there is no peace without inclusion and with the power given to warlords. Now the agreement being negotiated between the Trump Administration and the Taliban with a view to withdrawing troops from Afghanistan is very worrying, it does not include the voices of Afghan women, young people, civil society or even the elected government. The scant gains of hard-won inclusion are under threat and we can see the majority of the Afghan population, women and children, savagely oppressed. To negotiate like this is not to negotiate, to betray, as seen by the Taliban's increasing attacks on civilians and military personnel in Afghanistan. It is not enough for the European Union to fix such an agreement of partnership and cooperation that may not be worth the paper where it is written, we must make ourselves heard politically and avoid the civilizational setback that will make in vain such an agreement of partnership and cooperation and all the financial, humanitarian and sacrifice efforts of lives, of so many Afghan civilians and military and also allies , including Europeans in that country.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I note the agreement between the EU and Afghanistan and do believe that it would have been better had Parliament been informed earlier about the negotiations, particularly covering trade and investments. However, being mindful of the fact that Washington is no longer pressing for a military advantage means there is an opening up of space for diplomacy and the EU needs to support political resolution for the conflict in Afghanistan. But I have a number of questions for the Commission. The US and Taliban negotiators have reached a draft peace framework in Qatar, but it has not been disclosed if it contains assurances about the rights of Afghan women or minorities. Given the EU’s efforts to enhance women’s participation in public life, how are we going to ensure that this will not be in vain, once the Taliban have a political role again. Secondly, there is no regional agreed framework corresponding to the Doha talks. Neither the US nor the Afghan Government can lead it. How do we ensure sustained interest by regional powers and neighbours like Pakistan, China, India and Iran in a stable state? And finally, how do we ensure that the Afghan Government plays a core role in the dialogue in the Afghan peace process?

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, EU Member States continue to consider Afghanistan a safe country. This allows them to return to the country people who have come to Europe to seek asylum, often through very dangerous routes. However, the security situation on the ground has severely deteriorated and the Taliban now control a significant part of the territory. It is hypocritical and irresponsible for our Member States to be sending these people back to a land where they will inevitably face persecution, especially those who came to seek shelter in Europe after being targeted for their cooperation with Western forces. Another worrying issue is the current exclusion of women and young people from talks that could lead to a peace deal between the US and the Taliban. My colleague, Ana Gomes, brought an important initiative to our attention last week, whereby a group of Afghan women have launched an appeal regarding those who are currently excluded from the talks. It’s essential that their voice is heard in order to build sustainable peace and to safeguard women’s hard—won rights in the country.

name: Patricia LALONDE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, an agreement was reached between the Taliban and the United States a few hours ago in Doha. Just yesterday, the Taliban attacked an entire company of the Afghan army, 50 soldiers: 16 were killed and 40 taken prisoner. Ten days earlier, 40 soldiers were killed by the Taliban in the south of the country. I could multiply the recent examples. The Taliban still refuse to negotiate with the Afghan government, despite repeated requests from the Afghan government. On the contrary, they are increasing attacks on the government, which now controls only 50% of the territory. These negotiations with the United States pave the way for the Taliban to return to political power at the national level, in the face of an executive that is, as a result, weakened. This would mean a significant regression for the fundamental rights and freedom of Afghans and especially Afghan women. Afghan society as a whole is concerned about the re-establishing of a repressive Taliban Islamic Emirate in Afghanistan, as was the case in the 1990s. The European Union cannot afford to endorse such an eventuality after 20 years of investment in Afghanistan. It's about his credibility. Commissioner, we cannot let the Afghans fall back under the Taliban, even in the name of peace.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, so we’re discussing Afghanistan, the historically ungovernable, impossible State, and the EU – and again, really, really, with the right intentions – we’re looking at billions of euros, offers to help with state building, social programmes, but there’s the word – ‘state building’ – to try and get to democracy and so on. Now, Russia, the United States and the British Empire have all failed to try and impose themselves upon Afghanistan and I don’t think there’s any change to make us suggest that anything will be any different if this place – through its soft power – tries to impose itself on Afghanistan. I would suggest the best way to improve the lot of the people of Afghanistan is to agree to have tariff-free trade, to open the border to trade completely with them, and allow their economy to grow and people there to get better off and better educated through trade and the economic growth that will come with free trade. Everything else is doomed to failure.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Afghanistan is a state that can only be close to our sensitivity as citizens and Europeans, if only for all those who have fallen from Member States and allied countries who have sacrificed their lives there in recent years and which I would therefore like to mention today.  Having said that, I believe that Afghanistan and the European Union need an agreement that supports bilateral political dialogue in order to consolidate the internal stability of the country, without forgetting, but rather placing at the centre, civil rights, the rule of law, justice reform, sustainable development and the fight against corruption. In the context of a changing Central Asia, Afghan stability is in fact part of a win-win logic, with benefits for all regional actors. Without their involvement, the EU's efforts alone will not be possible, they will not be enough and will ultimately be much more difficult. Apart from stability, the agreement logically results in precise control of the funds.
