The road is difficult, but this is a positive first step and we must keep the doors open to ensure hope and a future for the citizens of Afghanistan.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, allow me to thank the Members for this useful debate. My conclusion is that we should pursue the implementation of the Cooperation Agreement with Afghanistan and the overall EU effort to support Afghanistan. This is especially important at this moment, when increased commitment from all the international community is needed. We will keep the European Parliament involved in, and informed about, our ongoing work and dialogue.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the Cooperation Agreement on Partnership and Development (CAPD) is the first ever legal base for a relationship between the EU and Afghanistan. It is to remain in place, in force, presumably, for the next decade. We have to use it to its full extent to further provide peace, stability, security and development, and social sustainability for this country. The task is really difficult.  I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs or persons who contributed to this report, the advisers of my political group, the staff of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, naturally, and my own assistants. Thank you very much indeed.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 13 March 2019.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The war in Afghanistan has been going on for many years and unfortunately there is no end to it. The past year, 2018, has absorbed an exceptional number of casualties, especially among civilians. This year, at least 3,800 civilians have been killed, including nearly 1,000 children. Afghanistan is still in all-encompassing poverty, with 54% of the population living in poverty or on the brink of poverty. Everything must be done to end this cruel war and reduce the suffering of the population. I propose that the EU focus on three actions. First, it supported peace talks between the Americans, the current authorities in Kabul and the Taliban. The agreement of these forces is the key to peace. Secondly, the reforms of the military and security forces in Afghanistan need to be more strongly supported. These forces should be supported, but not used. Thirdly, humanitarian aid, food and medicine supplies to civilians urgently need to be increased. It is extreme poverty and despair that makes many people allies of the Taliban.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the report by Juan Fernand López Aguilar, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the Recommendation of the European Parliament to the Council, the Commission and the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Association Agreement between the EU and Monaco, Andorra and San Marino (2018/2246(INI))(A8-0074/2019).

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, it is an honour for me to speak at this session of the plenary session of the European Parliament as rapporteur for the European Parliament's Recommendation on the Association Agreement of the European Union with the Principality of Monaco, the Principality of Andorra and the Republic of San Marino.  On 22 December 2014 the Council authorized the European Commission, on behalf of the Member States, to negotiate an association agreement between the three European micro-states and the European Union.  The European Commission had already established this will in 2012, but this is the first time that the European Parliament has had the opportunity to discuss this proposal for a Recommendation in which the European Parliament sets its position, before the end of this parliamentary term, on this ongoing negotiation agreement which, not ignored, will not be able to enter into force without the final consent of the European Parliament , because that is the rule of the Treaty of Lisbon, which strengthens, like never before, this European Parliament as the last word in international agreements negotiated on behalf of the European Union.  Well, there we have them: Principality of Andorra, Principality of Monaco, Republic of San Marino, sovereign states that have a long history that has interested me – I must say - as a lawyer specialized in constitutional law compared, with peculiarities that must be observed and respected throughout the negotiation of the ongoing Association Agreement and its conclusion.  But I have also seen the interest it is in not only its border states – France, Italy and Spain – but also in the European Union as a whole. They are important partners for the future of the Union, despite being micro-states, despite their small size and small population.  But in accordance with the Declaration on Article 8 of the Treaty on European Union, it makes perfect sense to exercise flexibility, an exercise in realism in incorporating the acquis communautaire – the four freedoms in terms of legal certainty – but, at the same time, respect for the singularities and specificities and the ability of these three micro-states to absorb the European acquis.  Because it is clear that, in relation to the implementation of the four freedoms in small territories with very small populations, temporary exceptions will have to be established in the course of time, in accordance with the circumstances and the evolution of their adaptation in each of the three States involved in this negotiation, to ensure an adequate implementation of it. The budgetary capacity of these three small States is also limited, so a dispute resolution mechanism and even a consultation forum should be established. Because we are not talking about joining the Union, we are talking about an association agreement without membership and accession to the European Union, which is a very different thing.  But I must finally influence a point that is interesting. Fiscal issues have been left out of the negotiating mandate – we all know this – and yet the efforts made by these three small States on transparency and cooperation in tax matters, the willingness to cooperate in the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism in particular must be acknowledged. I think it is important to call on these three States to continue on the right path of cooperation with the OECD and with all international bodies.  It should be noted that these three States are members of the Council of Europe, which are incorporated into the Greco Anti-Corruption Group, and it is important to recognise efforts in these structures.  The Recommendation draws attention to the importance of emphasizing the relationship with the border States – this is the case in Spain, France and Italy – and of better cooperation in areas of mutual interest and horizontal policies. And finally, I just want to point out three points.  In the case of Andorra, I believe that it is necessary to recognise the efforts made in the field of financial regulation, particularly in relation to tobacco, an area in which an agreement has been signed not only with the European Union, but with the border State that demanded it, Spain.  It is also important to recognise San Marino's difficulties in exporting to Member States due to VAT documentation known as T2.  And finally, with Monaco it must be acknowledged that it is a very small population in which, moreover, the Monegasca population is a minority relative to the population that lives in the town of Monaco.  So it will be very important to do this active exercise in flexibility, intelligence, so that this negotiation can be conducted successfully.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, over the past year the negotiations on the Association Agreement with Andorra, Monaco and San Marino have intensified. We aim to finalise discussions on the framework of the agreement by June. Then it might take an additional two years for negotiations on the very high volume of EU legislation to be adopted by our partners. As rightly pointed out in the report by Mr López Aguilar, we enjoy excellent relations with these three small—sized states. The three countries are proud of their history and independence, yet we also have much in common. We are part of the same European family and it is only natural to seek an even closer partnership with them. We appreciate their desire to seek full integration into the internal market. Andorra, Monaco and San Marino have made considerable efforts in the past years towards financial and economic recovery and towards preparations for the future Association Agreement. For example, they have already transposed, or are transposing, certain EU internal market rules. In line with Parliament’s draft recommendations, we continue to encourage our partners to seek support from Member States for the acquis takeover and implementation process. This will require strong administrative capacity, and cooperation with the EU countries can be of great help. We welcome the fact that the draft recommendations emphasise the importance of preserving the overall integrity and homogeneity of the internal market and of respect for the fundamental freedoms. We fully share Parliament’s view and the Union will not compromise on the main principles of the internal market. This is also our guideline in the negotiations with the United Kingdom and Switzerland. Any agreement will fall within the limits set by these principles and rules, but within these limits there is certainly room for mediation that takes full account of the specific situation of our small—sized partners. In this respect, Parliament’s recommendations are particularly welcome and timely. The European Union seeks a comprehensive agreement with full access to the EU internal market, therefore covering all the four freedoms: movement of goods, services, persons and capital. The overall principles are always the same: same market, same rules. There is no such thing as partial integration. The four freedoms cannot be cherry-picked and separated from one another. For the same reason, the EU Court of Justice should have exclusive competence for the uniform interpretation and application of the agreement, including for last-resort dispute settlement. The Commission, as guardian of the EU treaties, should be given competence to monitor the overall implementation of the agreement, including in the area of state aid. In line with Parliament’s recommendations and with the EU Treaties, we will look carefully into Andorran, Monegasque and San Marinese requests for transitional arrangements on issues such as the right of establishment, the free movement of workers and the free provision of services. These requests should be duly justified and proportional. An association agreement would be a clear win—win situation and a further step towards a more united European continent.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it was a pleasure to be a shadow rapporteur on this report. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr López Aguilar, for his guidance, and the other shadow rapporteurs for their constructive cooperation. An important aspect of the report is the recognition of the territorial dimensions of these states and its implications. Together with my colleagues, I proposed measures to adopt an institutional framework that will help the three neighbouring countries to implement the future association agreements in an effective and efficient way. Parliament undoubtedly needs to encourage these association agreements with Andorra, Monaco and San Marino. All three countries are surrounded by EU Member States and clearly share our history and cultural values. The three states have each, in their own right, pursued important reforms and regulatory alignment with the European Union, in particular regarding the regulation of banking and finance. These great efforts deserve our appraisal. With the adoption of this report we call for the rapid conclusion of the negotiations on a comprehensive agreement in order to build on our long-standing relations with our neighbours.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking my colleague and rapporteur, López Aguilar. The Association Agreement between the European Union, Monaco, Andorra and San Marino is an important step in the construction of European integration, which today involves these three countries, which have always been rooted in the history of Europe but have so far been outside the unitary project. In order to improve the text and further strengthen cooperation, including through dialogue with my political family's party, the Party of Socialists and Democrats in San Marino, I have tabled and adopted two amendments on crucial aspects such as scientific research and interaction between the European Parliament and the parliaments of the three States. The negotiations may be an opportunity to implement measures for investment in infrastructure of common interest, as well as academic research and exchanges in scientific matters. It is also necessary to provide for regular hearings of national delegations to the European Parliament throughout the negotiations.  It is therefore essential that the integration of these three countries should proceed immediately in the most fruitful way possible, including for discussion on issues where we may have disputes or mutual demands. In today's world, the more united we are in the European area, the stronger we all are.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the geographic, cultural and historical links between the European Union and those three enchanting micro-states are undeniable. There exists already, though, a good degree of political and practical cooperation between them and the EU. All three of them use the euro as their currency, whilst Andorra and San Marino are members of the EU Customs Union. The three states combined have a population of around just 150 000 people – three times smaller than the EU’s smallest Member State, Malta. Therefore, the Association Agreement will recognise this important imbalance between the two negotiating sides, and I’m pleased to note that the López Aguilar report repeatedly calls for its implications to be taken into account, so as to recognise the difficulties facing the micro-states in concluding an association agreement. They range from the practical difficulties of the disproportionate burden of implementing the EU’s ‘acquis communautaire’, given the small size of their civil services, to more divisive debates around freedom of movement. Given the intense debates in my own country around Brexit, I’m only too familiar with the importance of the indivisibility of the four freedoms of the Single Market. Clearly, for any state the size of the United Kingdom, freedom of movement opt-outs, whether within or outside the EU, would be problematic but, in the case of the three micro-states, permanent derogations must surely be considered reasonable. As shadow rapporteur, I too would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr López Aguilar, for his positive approach throughout the negotiations on our text. I will be very pleased tomorrow to vote in favour.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Andorra, San Marino and Monaco are three European countries with very clear historical, political and socio-economic particularities, which have good relations with their neighbouring countries. As a European Union we are interested in closer relations with them and the Association Agreement is certainly an opportunity to improve and modernise these relations. It is important for the good channel of the negotiations — which I hope can be concluded briefly — that the public opinions of the three countries, especially those sectors which may have the most reluctance to the Agreement, are well informed at all times of the content and progress thereof, which must be transparent. Specifically, andorra is fair to recognise the effort that this Pyrenean country is making to transform the foundations of its economic model and also – and this was very urgent – to have a transparent tax regime that can be approved to European and international standards. In this regard, the Andorran authorities should be placed to move forward on this path of reform, cooperation and greater relationship with the European Union.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to congratulate rapporteur Juan Fernando López Aguilar on the excellent work he has done.  This agreement is very relevant, because, although these are small States, they are located on the territory of the European Union, so I think it is important that they can participate in the European internal market.  I am very pleased for Andorra, for reasons of proximity and for being the chairman of the Friendship Group between the European Union and the Principat d'Andorra.   I have been able to see the great effort that the Government of Andorra has made to meet the European criteria and overcome the image of fiscal paradise. Andorra's evolution in recent years is truly remarkable, as it has gone from an opaque economy to an economy based on services, tourism and banking business, understood transparently. It is a model state throughout Europe, with very high standards of well-being.  In short, these three States, which by their characteristics cannot belong to the European Union, will have as much integration as possible thanks to this Agreement.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, in the States of Andorra, Monaco and San Marino there are some 150,000 Europeans in a close relationship with neighbouring states which are members of the European Union and whose history is inseparable from the history of those territories. It is therefore highly desirable to renew the political and institutional framework that frames the relations of these countries with the European Union and its Member States in order to close them. The small size of Andorra, Monaco and San Marino makes them more vulnerable in the context of globalisation and poses the challenge of preserving their cultural specificities and ensuring that they remain viable as social and economic realities. This association agreement cannot fail to take this challenge into account by strengthening their access to the European internal market. Of course, this also requires an effort on the part of these states to bring the European Union to financial and banking regulation closer to the european union and legal certainty and the exchange of information. Fortunately, the progress made in the adoption of the acquis communautaire is already remarkable. That is why this association agreement should deserve the support and commitment of this Parliament, as should the proposal contained in this report to set up a delegation dedicated to interparliamentary dialogue with these three States.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, so the three micro-states are the next in line for the Association Agreement – I can’t help but think of Pacman as he goes round gobbling things up as he goes along! But if these nations think that they’re going to get some special treatment, I would refer them to the words of the Commissioner – there is no such thing as partial integration he says; there are a lot of laws and rules of the EU and the single market that have to be taken on board. Despite some of the earlier words about concessions and temporary opt-outs, I wonder just how long those will last. I’m thinking specifically in terms of the banking regimes of these countries – just how long they’ll be tolerated once they get closer to the EU, the Single Market and all of the other rules that go with it. My advice to these three excellent micro-states, actually, would be ‘watch out, Pacman’s coming, start running’.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: – Mr President, this speech is very brief, I would simply like to thank and congratulate rapporteur Juan Fernando López Aguilar, the shadow rapporteurs and especially Mr Santiago Fisas because they have done an extraordinary job.  My father was born in the Pyrenees, in a valley near Andorra; there living conditions have historically been very harsh for centuries. Andorra has in recent years in an extraordinary transformation and this Agreement is very commendable and will be approved by a large majority tomorrow. And I would like to thank all the Members, and especially those I have appointed, for their dedication and their work in achieving the harmonisation in good practices being carried out by the Government of Andorra. And I would also like to acknowledge , as Jordi Solé has done - the efforts of the Andorran Government, its Parliament and the people of Andorra to converge and to approach good practices and the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Monaco, Andorra and San Marino are three micro-states, which were and are known as tax havens, as areas where, of course, multinationals or very rich people go and settle, and the role they play is well known. Now, with the association agreement, these are supposed to be eliminated. I am particularly concerned about whether this will happen, whether they will stop being tax havens, whether they will proceed transparently with the regulations imposed by the European Union.  I ask: can someone practice law in Monaco? Because that's forbidden. I ask: what about family law, especially in Monaco which discriminates against women? There are issues with custody of children, also relations with the operation of banks. These are serious issues that need to be monitored. Some of them, because there are many more. And around the concept of flexibility, we must not allow all these unacceptable practices.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, I should like to begin by congratulating colleague and friend Santiago Fisas on his commitment to this dossier and I would like to say that the European Union and the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Republic of San Marino share values of history, interests and challenges. They use the euro as a national currency, speak official Languages of the Union, are geographically as European as the six founding Member States and have long signed agreements with the European Union, andorra being a pioneer in this area when, in 1990, it signed a trade and customs agreement with the then European Community which is still in force. In view of the proximity of the European elections and the progress of regulatory convergence with the Union in the last four years, in particular in the context of financial regulation, tax governance and the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing, negotiations must be strengthened so that we can conclude negotiations by the next two years at the latest. I believe that, in the face of Sino-American competition for the hegemony of the world, it is vital to increase the process of continental integration centred on the European Union in order to increase Europe's global economic, educational and environmental competitiveness.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, the adoption of the recommendations would be very useful and timely. I would like to thank the honourable Members for their speeches, comments and suggestions made today and in the Committee on Foreign Affairs on 21 January. I am very grateful for Parliament’s political support for a swift conclusion of the association agreement negotiations with Andorra, Monaco and San Marino.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, in this closing speech I would like to be pleasantly impressed by the weighted and constructive good judgment that has dominated all the interventions from very different parliamentary groups, expressing the European Union's welcoming gaze to three small states — three micro-states — which are part of European mapping, values and history.  And I believe that in this closing intervention it is appropriate to draw attention to the opportunity for us to launch a joint political statement between the European Union and these three small States just as we are here validating the report on the recommendation of the current procedure to support it, to encourage it and to draw attention to the need to carry it out successfully by expressing sensitivity to the particularities of each of the these three situations.  Secondly, I believe that a pedagogy exercise must be done because these are three democratic countries. Some of the criticisms I have been able to hear are perfectly replicable to each of the Member States, including those that relate to fiscal particularities. , explaining the goodness of an Association Agreement of these three small States with regard to the great european integration project, which they nevertheless do not knock on the door as would-be Member States but as candidates for the association. And finally, a word of recognition that proceeds. It is necessary to recognize the approval efforts of its legal systems in all areas in order to continue to promote and encourage the positive conclusion of that Association Agreement which must be—we hope, as I have heard—soon a reality.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, March 13, 2019, at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Despite their small size, Andorra, Monaco and San Marino have always been an integral part of the European Union's history of operation and today have strong economic, political and cultural relations with many EU countries. It is high time to formalise these links – and I therefore welcome the ongoing negotiations on association agreements. Once completed, all three micro-entiers will enjoy full participation in the internal market, and few but still existing trade obstacles will be removed. In this regard, we must bear in mind the very limited administrative resources of each of these countries, as well as the great deal of work involved in the need for legislative changes and the implementation of new legislation. It is therefore important to ensure that the burdens involved are as low as possible. I hope that the negotiations will be finalised in the next two years, as planned, and that after that Andorra, Monaco and San Marino will enjoy even closer relations with the European Union.

name: Bogusław SONIK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Andorra, Monaco and San Marino are three micro-states that have always been part of European history, not only because of their geographical proximity to the States of the Union, but also through a community of political and cultural values. As a consequence of their efforts to increase integration into the EU, negotiations on an association agreement were launched in 2015 and are currently in the final stages. Andorra, Monaco and San Marino have carried out important reforms and ensured that the rules are in line with EU law. It is therefore important to create an effective framework to facilitate the implementation of association agreements in these three countries and to ensure a coherent interpretation of the EU acquis, taking into account their territorial and social, economic and administrative implications. I hope that the negotiations will be concluded in the near future, which in turn will open the way for the ratification of the agreement by all stakeholders.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Morten Løkkegaard, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States relating to accessibility requirements for products and services (COM(2015)0615 - C8-0387/2015 - 2015/0278(COD)) (A8-0188/2017).

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: Rapporteur. Mr President! Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen. This is, of course, an important moment for us in this House and for some 80 million European citizens. We are faced with having to confirm legislation that will lift and ensure the availability of various products and services. So that in future, no matter what disability or disability you have, you can expect your phone, your computer, your TV to be accessible to you and that you can use these everyday tools on an equal footing with all other consumers. In an emergency, you can call 112 for help, you can find information about a train journey – either digitally or at the station – you can withdraw money at any vending machine located on your way. Things that the rest of us take for granted in everyday life, but which you cannot necessarily do in the same way as the disability. Finally, this legislation delivers the harmonisation that has been expected for many years, thus confirming the ambitions that we find in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I'm personally really, really proud of that. It has been a long and hard move to lead these negotiations, but I am proud of the changes that we are bringing forward now. What will actually happen? Yes, as I said, the emergency services 112 are included in the agreement, we have check-in machines, payment terminals and other terminals among the self-service terminals that now need to be made available. Thanks to the House, all terminals of urban transport such as metro, bus and tram are also included. Parliament has managed to include public procurement in the agreement, although it was a problem for the Council from the outset. We have also created the necessary balance for businesses by excluding micro-enterprises that provide services. And for the micro-enterprises that supply products, there will be support from the Member States and more lenient requirements. The accessibility requirements are functional, they are not technical – there was a great deal of debate about this – which means that companies can continue to innovate and work to improve their products. We're not going to tell them how to do it. So perfect – no, of course it is not, even if compromises have to be made in all negotiations. And I know that there is disappointment that, for example, mandatory requirements for the built environment are not part of the legislation. I am aware that there was a desire and hope for more. Then I tried to deliver this, but I had to realize that to get all the good stuff through, we had to compromise. After all, I am not prepared to throw the whole thing on the floor, thereby depriving so many citizens of the opportunity to make progress in other important areas. I am pleased, however, that the built environment was included, albeit at a voluntary level, and that the Commission should assess how far the Member States have come in this area some years after the law came into force. I hope for broad support from this House for such important legislation as this one.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. It's been a long journey. In 2009, I became the first desicn Member of this House. In 2011, a European draft disability for the period 2010-2020 on the mobility and inclusion of persons with disabilities was adopted. In this report, I called on the Commission to put forward steps in the European Accessibility Package and I stressed proposals on access to goods and services for persons with disabilities and on the direction of improving this through robust, rigorous measures at European level.  Unfortunately, this was not possible in the previous cycle. In 2015, however, the Commission put this on the table, and after more than three years of hard work, it can be said that a balanced text has been adopted, the result of which is good for both social and economic development, and it would have been good to make greater progress in certain areas. The conclusion of the negotiations was urgent and did not tolerate delays due to the entry into force of the legislation.  I am moved and proud to stand before them today and I would like to thank them on behalf of people with disabilities, and I would also ask that we continue down this path together, which we may not have achieved today, and I am sure we will succeed tomorrow. Let us continue to work together on this in the future, and I would like to thank the reporter for his commitment and perseverance. It's a good line. I can vote for this with all my heart tomorrow.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, around this time last year, Ireland was the last EU Member State to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It means that the European Union and all its Member States are now committed to carrying out the following message: it is not about adapting people to the environment, but it is about adapting the environment to people.  This is precisely what the European Accessibility Act will do. After three hard years of negotiating, after some tough give and take, you have reached an agreement with the Council on this important piece of legislation. I want to warmly congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Løkkegaard, and his co—rapporteurs, Mr Kósa and Mr Taylor. What is on the table is a solid package which will make Europe a more accessible place to live and work for persons with disabilities. The European Accessibility Act is a key initiative of this Commission’s social agenda. Back in December 2015, we tabled an ambitious proposal. It offered a coordinated EU—wide approach to implement the UN Convention’s obligations on accessibility. It relied on the full strength of our internal market. With the European Accessibility Act, we established the world’s largest market for accessible products and services. The level playing field we have created is good for European business. It will increase the availability and affordability of accessible products and services. This will allow more than 80 million people with disabilities, including many older people, to participate in society and the labour market on an equal basis with others.  The European Accessibility Act will cover a wide array of products and services, such as phones; computers; payment terminals or self—service terminals; banking services; electronic communications, including the 112 emergency number; access to audio—visual media services; e—books; e—commerce, and some elements of transport services. These are key products and services for everyday life and they are increasingly affected by digitalisation. That is why the European Accessibility Act will also contribute to implementing the European Pillar of Social Rights and its principle on the inclusion of persons with disabilities. We are adapting our rules to make them future proof, to make sure that the digital revolution can be a catalyst for social inclusion and that nobody is left behind. The European Accessibility Act needs to be seen in synergy with other important EU instruments, for example, the public procurement directives or the Electronic Communications Code, where accessibility is an obligation. The European Accessibility Act will facilitate its implementation. To conclude, let me stress that the impact of the European Accessibility Act goes beyond its scope. Its accessibility requirements should be inspirational for other sectors and indeed for other parts of the world. Europe is about breaking down borders between countries and peoples. Let’s continue to take the lead in breaking down barriers to the full and equal participation of persons with disabilities in society. I count on you all to support the European Accessibility Act, which will make a difference in the lives of millions of European citizens.

name: Julie WARD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Mr President, there are more than 100 million disabled persons in the EU, a figure that is expected to rise to 120 million by 2020. Persons with disabilities in Europe often have difficulties accessing many basic products and services on an equal basis with other people. That means daily exclusion from society and from using basic products and services, something that is taken for granted by the majority, such as going to a bank, withdrawing money from an ATM, entering a school or university or library, a theatre or any public building, using the metro, buying a ticket.  We must ensure closer engagement and proper consultation with the disability community. We need to hear their needs and act on the reality of their daily-lived experiences so that no one is left out or falls behind in all areas of society. And that’s what this report is about: ‘Nothing about us without us’, as my friends in the disability community say, and I know they will be looking for a good result when we vote on this report. We must not let them down.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. Mr President, six years have passed since the Commission's announcement of the European Accessibility Act. Today we are called upon to vote for it more weakened than ever, because the voices of people with disabilities have not been heard. We have tried to incorporate the proposals of the wheelchair movement through hundreds of amendments, but the conservative forces in Parliament have voted against them. Thus, we do not have an accessible, structured environment, nor an enlarged scope of the directive.  The worst part: we need at least another six years before we see the directive implemented. What an insult to the wheelchair movement this is! However, we respect disability bodies and that is why we will continue to fight for the rights of disabled people until we remove all obstacles.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am also pleased that the accessibility requirements here in Europe have been met across borders, because more than 80 million people in Europe have a more or less severe disability, and the infrastructures of the European Union, the Member States, must also be made accessible across borders. This not only increases their chances of exploring Europe, but also leads us to create uniform system requirements for all infrastructure managers, and I believe that, with the framework we have created here, we have taken a major step towards the concerns of these people, and at the same time – and this is the positive – we have also succeeded in creating a common economic incentive for further investment. I think that it is nevertheless justified that we have excluded micro-enterprises from the scope, because in principle individual investments might actually have gone a little beyond what can be demonstrated.  Secondly, unfortunately, the building environment, which Parliament would have liked to have included in the scope, has unfortunately not been able to be taken away from the Council in the way we would have liked. This will be a point on which we in the new Parliament will have to make a fresh start.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: On the part of the S&D Group. The community of eighty million people with disabilities therefore rightly put high hopes into this regulation. The European Act of Accessibility, meanwhile, had not been made on roses from the very beginning. It took more than ten years to present the proposal, add to that another four years of intensive negotiations. And the result? I think we stayed halfway there. A few things have been done, and I would like to thank a number of colleagues here in the European Parliament for that. In particular in the digital field, the act will make available selected services and goods in the telecommunications, payment services or computer use sectors.  However, full participation in society means, in particular, accessible mobility. Possibility to move without restrictions, travel by public transport, go to the bank or to the store. And here, in my opinion, the European Accessibility Act has remained far beyond expectations. The European Parliament is sometimes criticised by citizens for making decisions that are disconnected from reality. Unfortunately, it was the Member States that, unfortunately, approached the act in cold blood from the outset in the sense of 'Just so it doesn't cost much', and completely contrary to the commitments they had previously signed up to in the area of accessibility. But I believe that not everything can be expressed in simple numbers. For us Social Democrats, the use of ordinary services and goods by citizens without distinction on an equal basis is a fundamental human right and a prerequisite for full participation in society. The fight for the rights of the weaker, people with disabilities, the elderly, all those who do not stand on the same starting line, therefore, is far from over for us today.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group. – Mr President, I am very happy that this directive, which I consider to be an extremely important legislative proposal to improve the lives of persons with disabilities, will be definitively approved while the current European Parliament is in office. From the outset, I supported the proposal for this directive and, through amendments, together with other colleagues, tried to improve it. However, the subsequent negotiations in the trilogue have changed the wording of the directive, and I do not hide some disappointment that the result is not as ambitious as I would have wished, but above all, as necessary for the daily lives of people with disabilities.  Today, however, nothing ends, quite the contrary. I believe that efforts to make goods and services more accessible, as well as to debarerise the physical environment or transport, will continue not only here in the European Parliament, but especially and above all in the Member States.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – More than 80 million Europeans have waited a long time for this much-needed act. In particular, I would like to begin by thanking the reporter for his important work and cooperation. And I must say that, of course, this act is also extremely important because it facilitates access to both services and goods and appliances for people with disabilities and also the elderly. But that's just the first step. Think of this document, this directive, of course, not achieved everything we expected. A lot of things have remained open, especially with regard to the built environment, including some other things that matter. But it's the beginning. It is the beginning of something that gives hope to show that the European Parliament also understands the needs of the people and that it understands the need to become an inclusive society for all.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which When I started my work in the European Parliament 25 years ago, people with special needs, or, in other words, people with disabilities, did not play a role; they were invisible, partly because there were no efforts to build a social pillar. This shortcoming has now been finally overcome. Due to the ageing of the population, around 120 million people in the EU are expected to live with multiple and/or mild disabilities by 2020. Today's report concerns us all, not just the more than 80 million Europeans with disabilities. European rules on accessibility and access to assistance for persons with reduced mobility already exist for road, rail, shipping and bus transport. The new rules do not undermine these already existing rules, but they complement them, and I very much welcome this. There is certainly a need for these additions, as, for example, the interactive self-service terminals at airports, railway and bus stations are still not barrier-free. This also applies to the provision of real-time travel information, as it is already available today. I am particularly pleased with our strategy for allowing a person with a disability to use the life-saving emergency number 112 like anyone else. This report is an important step in the right direction to ensure a self-determined life for people with disabilities – a task that we must all continue to work on together in the future. I say this not only as a co-founder of the Disability Intergroup, but also with complete conviction.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Act on Accessibility will bring tangible benefits to more than 80 million people in Europe with disabilities or functional limitations.  Computers, mobile phones, but also banking services and self-service terminals will have to comply with harmonised accessibility requirements in order to be used in Europe. From online shopping to transport, from banking services to the single European emergency number: all citizens, including the most vulnerable, will be provided with the same conditions and opportunities for access at the same price.  Of course, we could have done more about the time taken to apply these rules, which are too long, and about the requirements for accessibility to the built environment. In this respect, Parliament's position was certainly better than that which emerged from this trialogue. However, the accessibility directive, although not sufficient, confirms to us that there is a fairer, human-friendly Europe that guarantees the fundamental rights of the people who need it most.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, this is an important step after more than ten years of hand-wringing and struggle for human rights, fundamental rights – the rights of people with disabilities, which are human and fundamental rights. But this is only the first step. We need to create an enabling habitat. It means both the built environment, housing, various products and, above all, the step taken here in digital services, which threaten to displace a large number of people. Information technology can be a great enabler for all disabled and elderly people, or it can be a major unequal and repellent factor. That is why the next steps, both at member state level and in the Commission, should be in terms of how we include different categories of users, people with disabilities and older people in the design of services and products, user-driven design so that they are available – just like living and living environments – whether the constraints are in the area of sight, consultation, touching, moving, remembering or cognition. We owe it, we are now trendsees, now just boldly moving forward.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, there are some 80 million people with disabilities in Europe and some 150 million older people. Any legislation that improves the accessibility of products and services is a step forward that really benefits everyone in Europe.  So I am pleased that the dossier on accessibility requirements for products and services can now be finalised. Steps have been taken in the right direction, although it does not go nearly far enough for me.  Compared to the United States, Europe is lagging seriously behind when it comes to integrated accessibility. In the US, the Americans with Disabilities Act provided a real cultural change. Not only the government, but also all kinds of private companies regard accessibility as an opportunity rather than an obligation.  We miss that mentality here. As a result, people with disabilities in Europe continue to face obstacles that should no longer exist. As a result, their potential is under-exploited, a real shame!

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, we absolutely have to improve accessibility to enable people to use products and services, especially the disabled. I can’t help wondering, though, if so much top—down legislation may not always be the answer. Things like international trade bodies coming together, and manufacturers, companies, working together to get closer to the customer, might be a more efficient way. I also have to flag up one thing that the Commissioner mentioned earlier, which always sets alarm bells ringing for me: ‘future proofing’. I don’t believe that future proofing is actually possible. In fact, I think it may have been an idea invented by King Canute when he was trying to stop the tide. I don’t think it can be done. If you set out to future proof, rather than being flexible, and rather than allowing businesses to react to the market, you are actually having a negative effect when you want a positive one. So, yes of course, more accessibility for the disabled, but don’t be Canute.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, indeed, as has been said, there are 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union, unfortunately, another 150 million who are elderly and it is a given that serious measures must be taken to ensure full accessibility to services and products. We must take seriously the fact that the disabled really have difficulties in participating in the social, economic and political life of the European Union and that is why very specific measures are needed and we have too many complaints, Mr President, which we have received in the Committee on Petitions, from thousands of citizens of the European Union. I think there should be the following arrangement: no project, whether public or private, with Community resources, with European Union resources, should be financed if there is no regulation on full accessibility. This must be a criterion for the approval of the various financings.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to warmly congratulate my colleague Morten Lukkegaard, because, in view of the Council's restrictive position , as always — he has achieved the best of possible agreements. We have made progress in recognizing the rights of the more than one hundred million Europeans suffering from some form of disability to any degree. The new Directive will ensure that the obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities are equally fulfilled throughout the Union. The Directive projects its effects on transport and many basic services accessed by physical or digital means, and improvements range from financial services to computers, telephone terminals or e-books. Another great conquest is to make accessible the emergency services accessed through 112. I regret that newly built environments or tourist services on beaches and other entertainment venues are not included in the scope. I hope that the empathy distilled by this report will stimulate innovation and help us to be world leaders in all technologies that alleviate disability.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we have come a long way to reach this result. The negotiations between the Council and Parliament have been intensive. We all had to show flexibility and willingness to reach an agreement. I know very well that many of you would have liked to see more areas covered or more ambition on certain points. In fact, the Commission’s proposal was more ambitious, so I can understand some of your concerns. But the perfect is sometimes the enemy of the good, and we must see the substantial progress we are making and will continue to make. The accessibility of many everyday products and services will be felt by everyone in their daily lives. Everyone should benefit from the digital revolution. No one should be left behind as our society is changing. These changes to accessibility requirements are so obviously good, so obviously necessary, that people will soon say: why did we not we have them already? I call on you to support the European Accessibility Act.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: Rapporteur. Mr President! Thank you to all colleagues for taking part in the debate here, to which I have listened intently. It is clear that when you have been through an intense process with all of you and have been through tough negotiations, it is nice to know how you assess the outcome. I can only say that in politics the glass is always half empty or half full, and in this case I have to say that I belong to that part of the human race that thinks the glass is half full. Like the Commissioner, Mr Mimica, I believe that we have a very good result. Sometimes the best can be the worst enemy of the good, I totally agree with that. It has been my starting point for the whole debate that we secured the best possible result, because in reality we are now in a situation where we are breaking with three or four decades of standstill in this area, as my MEP colleague said just now. In fact, twenty years ago, there was no way of giving people with disabilities a place in society at all. I think we should be concerned about that, and this is really a major breakthrough for the idea that disabled people should be equal. That is what I am concerned about, I think is historic, and I think we should be pleased that we are in the situation that we can actually now offer 80 million people or more a dignified everyday life in terms of services and products. So I am pleased with this –I note that many speakers could have thought for something more, I could also personally – but I have to say that I am still quite proud that we achieved as much as we achieved. I myself did not expect that we would have achieved so much, and that tells me that there is also sensitivity in the Member States, and of course there is also in the Commission from the outset. So thank you so much to everyone for participating, thank you very much for a fantastically good result, which I hope we will back up tomorrow. Thanks!

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, March 13, 2019, at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, the text of the EU Accessibility Act is not ambitious enough, and it is important for me to stress that this is only the first step towards a more accessible Europe. Together with non-governmental organisations, I look forward to continuing the campaign for the rights of people with disabilities and the elderly, and I hope that the new European Parliament and other EU decision-makers will look to the future and seek an improved Accessibility Act to fill the gaps that are still in place. Millions of people with disabilities still need better access to hospitals, municipalities, schools, banks and other buildings. Millions of people with disabilities still need more accessible public transport. However, I now support the agreement reached on the EU Accessibility Act. Let it be the first step towards more ambitious legislation in the future.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the urgency of a third-country blacklist adopted by the EU in line with the Anti-Money Laundering Directive (2019/2612(SRR)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank President Tajani for his letter and for inviting the Presidency to contribute to this debate. Let me start by very clearly stating that the Council is strongly committed to the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. There can be no doubt about that. The Presidency and the Council as a whole fully share the sense of urgency and the commitment of the Parliament and the Commission in addressing this issue. Together we – the Parliament, Council and Commission – have worked closely over recent years in our common endeavour to establish an effective regime to counter money laundering and the financing of terrorism. We have in particular strengthened EU rules with the adoption in 2019 of the latest amendments to the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, which stands as a very good example of this good cooperation. Of course, further progress is needed in our joint fight. So, coming straight to the issue at hand, the Council has objected to the Commission’s delegated act identifying high-risk third countries with strategic deficiencies. This decision to object does not mean that the listing is not an important element of the ongoing work. On the contrary. But to achieve the full impact of this instrument and to ensure its quality, we need to introduce the list in an orderly process. This is effectively what we wrote in our Council statement.  We believe that in order to establish a strong and effective instrument, the Commission proposal needs to be established in a transparent manner and one that incentivises affected countries to take decisive action. This is why the Council calls for an EU listing in line, of course, with the 5th Anti-Money Laundering Directive, which will effectively strengthen anti-money laundering and combat terrorist financing. We are united and fully committed to maintaining and promoting the existing cooperation between the institutions. We are in fact advancing on other fronts as well in this fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. Hopefully, we will be finalising negotiations in the coming days on an important piece of legislation on anti-money laundering, which is contained in the European System of Financial Supervision package. Member States, but also the European Parliament, attribute a huge importance to this file. The Council also agreed last December on a dedicated anti-money laundering action plan with a view to further improving the current system, and we are monitoring developments on that front. I look forward to hearing your views and the views of the Commissioner and to continue working closely with you on the new listing.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for organising today’s debate on this important matter and I want to thank the Council for expressing the same sense of urgency on this issue. After each terrorist attack, we hear passionate speeches about how we have to efficiently fight against terrorists. After each banking scandal, we hear a lot of other speeches about how we have to make our financial sector more healthy. This is what we try to do, including by means of high—risk third countries, and this is what we did. We did it according to the methodology on which consultations were held and which was adopted in a transparent manner. That’s why I have to start by expressing my deep regret that the Council rejected this list – because being equipped with such a list, we would be able to start with this efficient fight immediately.  As you know, the Juncker Commission and I personally have made the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing a top priority during this mandate, and I always felt very strong support from this House, from the Members of Parliament who are also sitting here today. In recent years, we have witnessed a series of terrorist attacks in Europe and we have seen major money laundering scandals that unveil how organised criminals misuse our financial system. Together with you, we have worked relentlessly to make our rules and systems stronger against financial crime that causes harm to our society and our citizens. We have twice updated the Anti-Money Laundering Directive. You have adopted a new directive on criminalisation of money laundering and we have provisionally agreed on a new directive on the use of financial information by law enforcement authorities. This week, we are in the final stage of negotiating a reform of the European Banking Authority that would give it a stronger role in anti—money laundering supervision of the financial sector, thereby helping to ensure that our strong rules are properly enforced across Europe. The delegated regulation the Commission adopted on 13 February to identify third countries with strategic deficiencies in their anti—money laundering and counter—terrorist—financing frameworks is part of all these efforts to better protect the EU financial system from the risk of money laundering and terrorist financing. Unfortunately, this measure will not enter into force for the reason I mentioned at the beginning: using its scrutiny rights, the Council objected on 7 March to this delegated act. As I said, I am disappointed by the decision of the Council and I regret that this issue has not been discussed at political level in the Council. Neither by the Justice and Interior Ministers last week, nor by the Finance Ministers meeting at the Economic and Financial Affairs Council (ECOFIN) in Brussels today. In the fifth Anti—Money Laundering Directive, this Parliament and the Council decided together to strengthen the rules with regard to third countries, complementing the legal criteria of the Financial Action Task Force. The Commission attaches great importance to multilateralism and the work the Financial Action Task Force is doing. We are an active founding member of this task force and we must take its important work into full account. At the same time, it is necessary that we take further steps to protect the integrity of the EU financial system on the basis of the criteria set out in our anti—money laundering rules so that due diligence measures are applied. In light of experience, including the lessons from the Panama Papers scandal, we, the European Parliament and the Council decided together to add transparency rules on beneficial ownership structures. This goes beyond the Financial Action Task Force rules. We, therefore, can no longer simply replicate this Action Task Force list. We have a legal obligation under the current anti—money laundering rules to carry out our own autonomous assessment. In order to prepare our first autonomous list, the Commission carried out a careful assessment, based on a solid methodology, together with Member States’ experts. Member States were also consulted on the methodology itself, which follows the criteria set out in the directive. The Commission also engaged with the third countries concerned immediately after the College of Commissioners endorsed the preliminary findings on 23 January 2019 in full of respect of the third countries’ right to be heard. The Commission stands by its assessment. Therefore, we will continue to engage with the third countries concerned and encourage them to address their deficiencies in the areas of preventing money laundering and terrorist financing. We do not list third countries for the sake of listing them, but in order to address the risks to the EU financial system. In terms of the next steps, I stand ready to engage with you and with the Council at political level to discuss the way forward. Our aim remains to fulfil our legal obligation under the Anti—Money Laundering Directive. It is a joint responsibility of the EU institutions to protect citizens and the EU financial system against threats of money laundering and terrorist financing. As for the timing, I asked the College to give me a chance to finalise the next list still in this mandate. I want to finish my mandate with a clean table and to do that, I also have to stress once again that I count on your support.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, i.e. the Presidency of the Council, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work on the work she has done. I believe that we all agree that, in the fight against money laundering, we need a blacklist that has bite, which encourages third countries to step in and which is credible. Because we had doubts that this was the case with earlier drafts of the blacklist, we in the European Parliament ourselves have already rejected delegated acts. I almost feel sorry for the Commission now, because we have always said that it is not enough just to copy the list of the Financial Action Task Force, but we have to make our own analyses. That was exactly what we always asked for. The list is certainly not perfect. One can also ask why a country like Russia is not yet on this list. And, of course, the Council has also mentioned a few procedural points – how do you get down on them, how to get back down – that we can talk about. Nevertheless, I have the feeling that the reason for the Council's rejection of the list was not a formal one, but that a number of irrelevant considerations also played a role here. In recent weeks, we have heard the argument more often that this or that third country should not be put on the list because they are important allies. If we get involved in this argument, the list loses all credibility. Because then it is clear that a third country only has to lobby intensively with the Member States, then it is off the list again. And once that's been talked about, this list is a toothless tiger. We cannot want that, because at the end of the day it is also a question of ensuring that the European financial sector is not misused for money laundering, terrorist financing or for organised crime purposes. It is not fitting to give European banking supervision new anti-money laundering powers on the one hand, but to leave a gateway open on the other, because we cannot agree on a list. I can only encourage the Commission to make a proposal again as soon as possible. And I can only appeal to the Council to vote in favour of this list.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the European Commission has drawn up the list of third countries with strategic flaws in the fight against money laundering, terrorist financing and tax evasion, on the basis of an independent and independent assessment, also taking into account the FATF assessment, as Parliament insisted and as dictated by the 5th Anti-Money Laundering Directive and terrorist financing and related , as dictated by the need to effectively combat the financial and fiscal crime that lives off-shores inside and outside the European Union. The Commission complied, Parliament applauded, the Council destroyed it. Once again, efforts for transparency, tax justice against organised crime, including terrorism, are blocked by member state governments from collective security. Do not come to the governments of the European Union to claim now that it is Brussels that is to blame. It is the Council, each and every one of the 28 governments of the Member States that allow themselves to be captured by perverse interests, succumbing to pressure from either the Saudi-based regime, or its protector, the Trump Administration, to the council. My tribute, Commissioner Jourová, for your determination and persistence. You have our full support.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Europe is once again coming up with a new list of tax havens. Fortunately, the Commission has done its job this time. It can always be improved - it has to be better - but Parliament also drew up a list of tax havens here two weeks ago, and they had thrown Belgium on to it without any methodology. So I think the Commission has done it properly here. So there is now a new list and the countries on it, Panama, Iran, etc. are not sanctioned, but European banks do have to carry out additional checks on transactions involving customers or banks from those countries. I think that is very important in the fight against financial fraud. We support that fight. It is something that my party has worked hard for over the last few years and we will continue to fight that fight.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It was with some interest that I read through the list of the blacklisted ones. The interest was due to the fact that we have been doing this thing for quite some time. Next to me in this chamber I have Sargentini, and it is about six years since we tried to get these lists in order, without really getting them right.  When I read through the arguments about which countries have been put on this list, I am even more surprised by the simple reason that in all the banking scandals we have seen in recent times there is a recurring pattern. That pattern is called Russia. It may be that those who write this list have relatively little experience of how the Russian system works. I've actually lived in the country for six years. I have to say that I am deeply surprised that this is not taken more seriously. Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, we have seen the systematic theft of state and other property, which is then turned through various channels into property in Europe or in tax havens. That is what has been the consistent feature of all the banking scandals we have seen.  The fact that Russia does not put Russia on this list suggests to us that we are not really seriously considering how this is going to deal with, and this is coming back to us in the form of a loss of confidence in the European institutions. Our task is to safeguard trust and ensure that what we do on the international stage is also of the quality, of that calibre, that our citizens believe that we are actually out there trying to put money laundering in order, on terrorist financing and on tax havens.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the What has happened here in the last few days is a piece from the Tollhaus. It must be made quite clear to the Council that we have jointly agreed on a methodology. The Commission has pointed this out. For months, there have been no methodological objections. Then, as the list slowly becomes known, there are massive interventions from Panama, from the relevant American jurisdictions and also from Saudi Arabia. And suddenly a critique of methods develops. This criticism of methods is not credible at all. To date, not a single one of the Commission's country assessments has been criticised in substance by the Member States. Instead, you are removing this important anti-money laundering instrument. So the question now is: how do we proceed now? All I can say is that let us not let up now, but – as the Commission has pointed out – the examination for important countries is not complete: for Russia, for Azerbaijan, for the United Arab Emirates, for countries where we have seen here that there are major problems. So let us be clear: we must not let up now, but the tests must continue. And we do not need a shorter list, which is adjusted for problematic states, but a more sophisticated list. And the Commission should finally publish all the country evaluations so that we have the transparent debate that the citizens deserve on this issue.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we have before us one of the starkest examples that we’ve seen of the impact of lobbying on the Council that is harming the people of the EU. The new process for compiling the anti-money laundering blacklist is far from perfect. It ignores the fact that the majority of international money laundering scandals in recent years have actually involved European banks. Nevertheless, we welcome the increased autonomy in the process. The Council’s objections are politically motivated interference in a process that’s supposed to be independent. I’m particularly concerned that the defence of Saudi Arabia and the US by EU governments is a direct result of their close financial and trading ties and of lobbying by the US and Saudi Arabia. We don’t just urgently need an anti-money laundering blacklist; we urgently need mechanisms to prevent the lobbying by corporations and countries from harming the public interest and to ensure that we have full transparency over the lobbying process.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, EU Socialists have an obsession about money laundering; a total fear that some poor over-taxed soul might make an extra centime or an extra penny. This taxes your every waking moment, if you’ll pardon the pun! Some clever creature will always find a way around taxes, that’s just the way it is. We look to minimise it in the UK and move on.  This is better than crucifying every job-creating, hard-working businessman or businesswoman, disrupting their business with pointless money-laundering bureaucracy and seizures of money until they can prove what they’ve done with it or where they got it. Business people need to get on with creating wealth and jobs. The UK is less neurotic about money laundering and we have lower unemployment. Youth unemployment in Spain stands at 34%, in Italy 30%, in France 21%, – surely wealth and job creation through the cutting, not the increasing, of red tape is more useful to the citizens of Europe than any sort of European socialistic avarice and jealousy of hard-working, successful businessmen and women who want to keep the fruits of their labour and employ their fellow citizens. The EU wants to turn all of us into a spy state. Meanwhile, the European Investment Bank bankers will have immunity in the UK, even after Brexit. Even after Brexit! This is appalling. This is hypocrisy of immunity. One rule for the EU, one rule for the rest of us.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are witnessing a truly impressive spectacle, namely this game of countries that, as in a game of cards, enter and leave the lists, which plastically represents the unwillingness, the opacity of the intervention of the European institutions on such a sensitive and important and serious issue. We need only recall the alarm also raised in our committees by an important person such as the then Director of Anti-Drugs in Geneva, who said that all international drug trafficking involves money laundering, the banking system, certain sectors of the financial and banking system.  But as long as the tax parcel of offshore squares lasts, how can the European Union attack with clear and decisive measures the whole huge web of countries that allow money laundering and are therefore a paradise for terrorists, criminals, drug and arms dealers? That's the point.  I would like to point out to the courteous representative of the Commission that the fifth directive introduces as a qualifying element the availability of the actual owners of companies and legal institutions. Are you sure that in Luxembourg, for example, it is so easy to trace the real owners of offshore companies? It is so certain that in our countries it is possible, in the countries of the European Union... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Jourová for providing EU citizens with what we have asked for for a long time: a real EU list of third countries that are too lax on money laundering. The list we received is based on the Commission’s new methodology and its own assessment of various third countries and I would like to commend you, Commissioner, for this initiative. At the same time, I would like to tell colleagues that, together with my group, I very much regret that the Council officially objected to the delegated acts proposed by the Commission last Thursday. This is very unfortunate, I must say, because the blacklist – the identification of non—cooperative jurisdictions – is an important component of our fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. Frankly, it is difficult to understand this obstruction on the part of the Council. Still, while I welcome the new methodology, I expect the Commission to include in the further assessment the findings of the TAX3 Committee of this House, especially findings on Russia and its deficiencies in fighting money laundering. Let me underline that virtually all major money-laundering scandals uncovered during this legislative term were connected to Russian money or Russian individuals. EU citizens expect us to act and be ambitious in the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. That’s why I encourage you, Commissioner, to continue your work and to come up with a new delegated act on this matter.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, throughout this parliamentary term we have often had to regret the lack of results and the systematic blockade by the Council of extremely important pieces of legislation for this European Parliament. But the balance of results in the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism is not negligible, it is not a balance sheet that can be underestimated.  There we have the fifth anti-money laundering directive, adopted, which is beginning to roll out its effects throughout the European Union and the European Criminal Law Directive, which is an extremely important tool for approx approximation of criminal rules and for filling the legislative work of this Parliament as a European criminal legislator.  The Socialist Group has strongly supported each and every one of these initiatives. He did so in the Commission which dealt with the panama papers in the TAX3 Commission, of which I have had the honour of being a party. Now is the time to tell the Commission that it has to resist pressure from the Council to try to discolor or degrade the list of countries that suspiciously contribute to these inadmissible practices.  And we call on the Commission to stand firm, particularly in the fight against the laundering and financing of terrorism on a date like today, when Spain has been in the worst terrorist attack in the history of the European Union for fifteen years. It's time to stand firm, Commissioner Jourová.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Mr President, or Minister Siod really speaks all languages, or she does not listen to Parliament. I would have expected you to explain to us at your introduction why 28 Member States oppose the European Commission implementing the law. This European Parliament has negotiated twice with the Council - and I was the rapporteur - on revising the Money Laundering Directive against criminal money and against terrorist financing. This Parliament also got the wind from the Council when we were not quick enough with rules to fight terrorism in the wake of the attacks on Charlie Hebdo and the Bataclan. This Parliament is therefore also very surprised that now that the European Commission is doing what it is supposed to do, which is to protect us from terrorists by tackling its financing, you are making an argument that consists of: we do not understand the procedure.
