Perhaps I can invite you if you speak so directly at the end of the debate, to explain to us what the problem is with Saudi Arabia, Panama and the Virgin Islands on the list.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, during this parliamentary term the Commission has submitted two lists of countries. Both have been rejected by this Parliament on the initiative, interless, of my political group, for omitting, in main, the lairs of the European Union environment. We welcome the Commission's decision now to include Panama and Saudi Arabia. However, once again, to analyse the list we need to look above all at the countries that are not on it. Above all, in those; where they're not. The ones that don't point out. What, for example, happens to Switzerland, which flagrantly violates several articles in the code of the International Financial Action Task Group on Money Laundering? Ladies and gentlemen, if we are to seriously tackle international terrorism and money laundering, we have to cut off their funding avenues. And whether they like it or not, will also mean ending tax havens where large fortunes and European multinationals hide their money.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are pleased to see at last that the European Commission has published a blacklist of countries at risk of recycling worthy of the name. However, we find it absurd that this Parliament has repeatedly had to denounce the lack of a truly independent and autonomous process in order to judge those States that posed a threat of financial crime. After several rejections, the European Commission has finally managed to draw up a more comprehensive, if not complete, list, with a more independent methodology. The publication of the new blacklist is a step in the right direction but should only be considered as a first step.  First of all, it must be made clear that it is necessary to ensure that natural and legal persons from countries on this list are subject to stricter controls when carrying out activities within the Union, given the strategic shortcomings on anti-money laundering and countering terrorist financing in those countries. Furthermore, there is still much to be done to ensure that all lobbying in some countries does not affect the ability of the European institutions to act independently and independently.  Finally, the process needs to become even more transparent. That is why we are asking the Commission to publish its assessments of the countries on the list in order to ensure public scrutiny.  I am delighted that before the end of this parliamentary term, another important step forward has been taken in the fight against money laundering, a heinous crime that enriches criminals and puts out those who act legally. This is a crime that must be repressed and to which I have devoted a great deal of effort during this term of office, among other things by lay off a directive – the directive on combating money laundering through criminal law – which will allow law enforcement authorities throughout Europe to investigate and prosecute the crime itself more effectively. I would like to take this opportunity to reiterate my call on the Member States to transpose the text quickly and correctly into their national legislation.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Article 9 of the Fourth and Fifth Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Directive contains a clear obligation for the European Commission to analyse the legal and institutional framework of countries outside the European Union, the powers of their competent authorities and the effectiveness of their systems in order to identify where problems exist in the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. These requirements were jointly agreed by the European Parliament and the Council and at no time during the negotiations did any Member State oppose those powers of the Commission. Let me be clear – and before the European Commission has published lists of high-risk countries actually identical to those of the FATF. But for the first time, it is tasked with carrying out an analysis that takes into account, but not identical to, fatf's.  The European Union is a huge single market and the Commission's main task is to protect its functioning from all kinds of threats, including coming from third countries. Obliged entities in the European Union must be aware that financial flows from certain regions of the world may be of questionable origin. But this by no means means that all financial flows are suspicious or that business with these countries will stop. The increased attention following the list is a warning to obliged entities to be careful, because otherwise they will be responsible for supporting money laundering and terrorist financing.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, like my colleagues, I also want to commend the work the Commission is doing on listing third countries as high risk for money laundering and terrorist financing. We all know how huge a threat to our security in Europe is posed by financial crimes, terrorist financing and terrorism, as well as the threat that these countries that are acting as safe havens for this pose to Europe. So it’s a very serious threat to us and I commend the Commission for working seriously and objectively on this, along with the directives on anti—money laundering. In a way, I just want to say that it’s a little bit ironic. We are a Union based on the rule of law and objective criteria, and yet we see that the Council, one of our institutions, undermines that principle when we apply the objective criteria and methodology that we have agreed upon in this case. I think it is a disaster and a scandal. I want say one more thing. I think what we see in the Council is a black box. We don’t see what Member States’ representatives are doing in the secret working groups and I think we could at least demand from their side that they are accountable and transparent so that citizens, the media and others – we in Parliament – can see what is happening. Why are countries taking items off the list in the Council? Why are they blocking items? What is the reason? We need to get that out in the open to get a real debate going because, if we don’t do this, we will never have an efficient list and I do not think we will fulfil the principle of the rule of law that we should all support.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report I would like to add a practical example to the debate: every year, it has been proven – as several studies have now shown – billions of criminal money from criminal transactions flow into the German real estate market alone, and then the dirty money is laundered. This, of course, drives up prices in the real estate market, and that in turn drives up rents. The tenants, who then have to pay more and more rent and can no longer afford some of their homes, are ultimately the ones who have to pay the bill at this point for the political inaction of the Council. And against this background alone, the Council's rejection of the revised money laundering list is a scandal. And, of course, the list presented by the Commission is quite flawed, but it is a step in the right direction. With half-heartedness, one does not win the fight against dirty money. You win it with determination and political will. And that is clearly lacking in some European governments.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for being here. Anti-money laundering, the fight against financial crime and tax fraud are among the key priorities of civilised countries in the 21st century, despite the fact that maybe Mr Coburn would not agree. I believe that we are civilised countries, so I believe that this is our priority, but instead of that, maybe I should say I wish it were our priority. Today I feel great frustration, maybe the most frustration I have ever experienced here for some time, and this is really something. A clear majority of the Member States in the Council have rejected the methodology-based, relatively transparent and evidence-based list proposed by the Commission and Commissioner Jourová, and this is really frustrating. Obviously, nothing is perfect. The list was not perfect, but this could have been a good start to a good process in which we expressed our view on this very important matter. This is a really shocking result and this is putting into doubt our dedication, our principles and our self-confidence, so that’s why I kindly ask the Commission to continue and I ask the Council to reconsider this position and not put us into such a shameful position.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, the Commission is proposing a blacklist against money laundering and anti-terrorist financing, and this is a good initiative. But what do we learn today, and we learn it with dismay? It is because the Council hastened to unravel this list, to refuse to include countries which, however, are publicly known, are champions of opacity, or worse! I take two examples: how can we deny today the involvement of countries such as Panama or Saudi Arabia - criminal and even downright criminal involvement - at a time when the peoples of Europe are demanding more transparency? I recall that the Panama Papers were searched and concluded that they were involved in money laundering. As for Saudi Arabia, it is well known that individuals participated in the financing of Daesh and that the kingdom could not ignore it. So what I see is that between Mr Ben Salman's cheques and the interests of European citizens, the Council has decided. Parliament must reject, and clearly reject, this democratic scandal.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Mr President, the Council rejects the list. Not good. Preventing the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing is part of any strategy to address the threat. To this end, the Anti-Money Laundering Directive was adopted and entered into force last July.  Article 9(2) empowers the Commission to adopt delegated acts in order to identify high-risk third countries, taking into account their strategic shortcomings. While this list is not perfect, it is necessary for financial institutions to strengthen their controls. However, it is necessary to allow the countries concerned sufficient time to ensure that the necessary reforms can be undertaken in their systems and not to include those already in the process of reforms. The Union must monitor and evolve twenty-three States and others and provide sufficient means for Commission units to have the necessary operationality and independence to amend the list, where appropriate, as effectively as possible. In the same sense, the Union must find strengthened mechanisms to deal with the legitimate pressures of third countries that do not want to be associated with money laundering or the financing of terrorism, but which, at the same time, lax regulation brings significant benefits.  And then there's the Russian thing. The LIBE, ECON and TAX3 Commissions have repeatedly pointed to Russia's non-adequacy of the financial framework. In this regard, Mr President, the Commission must take into account Parliament's repeated opinion.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, the security of citizens and the financial system of the European Union must be protected from the illegal instruments that enable terrorist financing and money laundering. The Union has the ability to draw up a list of third countries on the basis of the risk identified through suspicious capital flows moving between fictitious companies and opaque structures used to conceal the true beneficiaries of a transaction, including for the purposes of tax evasion.  Based on intelligence provided by Europol and the Financial Action Group, we were able to tighten the evaluation network and increase the list of suspicious countries. It must be realised that, with this list, we are not applying any economic sanction or making any diplomatic boycotts. On the contrary. It is therefore not understood that the Council's refusal to accept the list of countries at risk proposed by the Commission.  The Union must maintain its commitment to intervene with countries with strategic shortcomings to prevent dirty money from being used to finance corruption, organised crime and terrorism. Of course, no country is happy to be on this blacklist, and tries, by all means, including through bilateral talks, to put together arguments justifying their exclusion. Ladies and gentlemen, let us agree: we know how insidious the penetration of corruption, organised crime and terrorism within Europe can be insidious. There are issues where Europe has to close ranks and act with one voice, and in this case it is in the purest common sense that it is better to prevent than to remedy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, money laundering, money laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance must be hit. And after the Commission has finally been persuaded to draw up the blacklist of countries that are fleeing tax, we see that the Council is refusing to go through this process. It really blocks the blacklisting of countries of tax evasion. I don't know. Because that's where Panama is? Because it's Saudi Arabia? From then on, there is another issue: transparency. When we say the Council, which countries do we mean? Were all the countries in the Council that refused to ratify the Commission's list? If not, I want you to tell us which countries brought the obstacles. Because behind the word Council there is a complete opacity and specific countries and policies are covered. We want an answer, Mrs Ciot, on this very specific point.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, not everyone on this list is here, but they are all who are. I do not like the Council's attitude to the Commission's proposals. I congratulate the Commissioner for defending her assessments. He's got all our support. The Council's attitude in this matter is bad for two reasons. First, because it erodes the confidence and credibility of the European institutions. And, second, because it encourages behaviors that harm us all. We have to believe that what is good for the Union is good for all its members. And what is not transparent, which unfortunately is repeated, is to see the Member States make cambalaches between them to protect particular interests, state by state, to change cards between them and which do not defend the Union. This is a matter that speaks of our collective ethics. We are faced with practices that overall damage the volume of available resources managed by the European Finances. And this is one of those issues on which states are the ones who make the unjustifiable decisions and it is the Union that pays, in terms of prestige, a great invoice. This is the gasoline of populism. That is why I would like to ask the representative of the Council what those reasons have rejected the list. Tell us at least two of them.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, indeed, combating terrorism sounds like a great idea. Nobody – nobody – is more in favour of combating terrorism than I am. Absolutely. Let’s get to grips with it, let’s stop them getting their dirty money, let’s stop this money laundering. But hang on. Then something occurred to me. In all of the debates that I sit through here, and I’ve sat through a lot today, often one of the things that gets mentioned is that you’re really quite frustrated that you can’t get to grips with banks and bankers and finances and that you can’t really peek into bank accounts as much as you’d like. I’ve heard this for five years now. Isn’t it really convenient to put up Russia, terrorists and all sorts of baddies and say ‘Oh, we must get to them. I know: we need to be able to see into people’s bank accounts, we need more power for the financial authorities, and we need to be able to blacklist people if they don’t play along’. Strongman arguments. I’m a little concerned, a little suspicious. Yes, combat terrorism, but I think – I detect – a little bit more about this: I think you’d like to have a peek into someone’s bank account.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, yes, this is the first time we are working on this autonomous EU list of high—risk third countries. We knew when we were planning this and discussing the methodology, the rationale and the criteria which will be used for the assessment that it would be difficult, that it would demand expertise and that it would be sensitive – because we work in the context of the geopolitical and external ties and contacts of each Member State – and that it might be unpopular, but we knew absolutely, clearly and for sure that it was necessary. These high-risk third countries are a very important element of everything we do against money laundering and terrorist financing. This is the most important element of the whole system. I will repeat again that this is what we do in the field of the fight against organised crime, where we need to be much better on the side of systematic prevention.  This is about prevention. We must be aware of how the financial sector is interconnected and that, if we want to have a safe financial sector, we must not leave any weak points or easy entry points into the system from outside. Whenever I discuss these matters with law enforcement authorities, with practitioners and experts, they always have a very clear goal for us: cut the influx of illicit money into Europe because this is the money which is financing organised crime and terrorism. So this is what we are doing, and I remain convinced that the countries we listed belong to the list. At the same time, we see that we have to work with the Member States on procedural matters because they were at the centre of the criticism which we heard from the Member States. So I agree that maybe we need more transparency. I also heard in this House and in the two days of debate that you would like to see a more detailed assessment. We need more clarity and we need stronger – I would even say full – ownership from the side of the Member States. We need to check again whether the Member States are ready to cooperate and whether that readiness is driven by a genuine interest from the side of the Member States to fight against organised crime and terrorism. I hope – and I do believe – that we will find this readiness from the side of the Member States because the Member States must be aware that in a system where the financial institutions and the whole financial system has no borders in the EU, individual Member States cannot efficiently fight against these dangerous phenomena. It has to be a common task and this is what we are doing. The Commission is going to work on two parallel strands. On one side, we will work with the Member States and with Parliament on procedural matters. We will look into the methodology and the criteria we use. I am convinced the criteria are pretty precise and we use them in full. It was a very objective assessment, based on the criteria known, but we will work on this with the stakeholders. The second strand will be our parallel work with the listed countries, with those who are willing to eliminate the risks on their side. I have had discussions with several of those listed and who don’t want to be listed, so this is the invitation: let’s work on the elimination of risks on your side. We need to see the partners where there are no deficiencies anymore. I think that we are very clear about this. This will be one strand of work with the listed countries. The second strand will be working on the assessment of the countries which are in group two, where indeed we also have Russia and other countries which you mentioned in this debate. My message is also for the Member States. I am not giving up. The machine is working. We are working on it. We are continuing to fulfil our obligations, which we have in legislation. We are doing what’s necessary and we will be back with the new list later this year.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: You had a lot of criticism from almost all the political groups and a lot of questions. We are very interested to hear your answers.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I have followed your contributions and heard the intervention by the Commissioner. I take this opportunity to reaffirm the importance which the Presidency attaches to the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing.  As mentioned, the Council felt that there were problems with the process as it was conducted by the Commission. I am encouraged by the fact that Commissioner Jourová already said that the Commission was aware that many considered that the time for consultation was too short, as well as by her recognition that the process could be improved in the future. We stand ready to continue engaging with the Commission in this respect.  The Council has no position on the listing of any particular country on the list. The reasons for the Council’s objection to the list are very well known and were the ones presented in my initial intervention. They relate to the process employed by the Commission to arrive at the list and are clarified in the Council statement. The Presidency will remain available for exchanges on the subject as needed.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The motions for resolutions to be tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure will be announced at a later date. The debate is closed. Vote: 14 March 2019. Written declarations (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Eva JOLY
text: In writing. Europe that protects is a Europe that acts impartially and decisively against dirty money and the financing of terrorism, regardless of the countries concerned. Let us not accept the Europe of the double standard and privileges defended by Emmanuel Macron! A blacklist is a blacklist: if a country poses a threat, it must be included. Whatever his size, influence, or the weapons he buys us! For it is to reassure Saudi Arabia, among others, that the French government and the other Member States have rejected the anti-money laundering blacklist. They gave in to the lobby of third countries dissatisfied with being on the list. This little game is unbearable. It is time for governments to stop their double discourse: at the same time we cannot want to fight dirty money and oppose a more complete blacklist. The Council needs to reconsider its position. The update of the list proposed by the Commission must be adopted as soon as possible. Let's not leave our doors open to dirty money. Let's be consistent in our fights.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Mr Carlos Coelho, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. Regulation (EU) No 810/2009 of Regulation (EU) 2017/2226, Regulation (EU) 2016/399, Regulation XX/2018 [Interoperability Regulation] and Decision 2004/512/EC, and repealing Council Decision 2008/633/JHA (COM(2018)0302 - C8-0185/2018 - 2018/0152(COD)) (A8-0078/2019).

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I can't help but remember that Schengen and freedom of movement are the success of European integration that Europeans hold out most. But this freedom of movement requires measures to ensure the security of our common borders and cooperation between the police within our territory. It also requires a common visa policy, i.e. a European approach for those who legally cross our borders, whether to visit, study or work.  The visa information system, the VIS, is the most visible example of this policy. Currently this system is limited to the entry of tourists, so-called short-stay visas. In 2017 alone, around 16 million visas were registered. Of course, it is not just tourists entering Schengen. In 2017 one million workers entered the European Union, more than 800,000 people came to join family members and more than half a million came to study. These people, although they also benefit from free movement, are not registered in any European database. More worryingly, each Member State decides which security checks they are subject to. There is also one last category of people, the big investors, the so-called Gold visas, which are already issued by 20 Member States. They too are currently outside the VIS and are not subject to any kind of security checks against other Union information systems, such as the Schengen Information System. With this vis reform we intend to change that. Moreover, this reform will only make sense if long-stay visas and residence permits, including Gold visas, are registered with the VIS. That's why I see with surprise and concern that the S&D group has changed its mind in the last month. When we voted on this report in committee supported the measure, they now seem to want to follow the Greens and the GUE. Ladies and gentlemen, let us be clear, the current distinction between short-stay visas and long-stay documents makes no sense. Anyone seeking a visa to enter the European Union should be subject to the same security checks across Europe. Tourists who visit us and who normally stay on our territory for a period of well under 90 days are subject to European security checks. But people who decide to settle more permanently from our territory or acquire residence through investments, I am talking about Gold visas, are not subject to even remotely similar controls. That is why, with this reform, we want, first of all, to ensure that all visas, whatever their duration, are automatically preceded by adequate security checks, in full respect of fundamental rights, the principles of necessity and proportionality, but by ensuring that a Russian investor, the subject of a European arrest warrant, does not end the Gold visa in Romania. These checks will be carried out systematically and completely before the issuance of visas. Any third-country national will be subject to 15 security checks against seven EU information systems before it even reaches European soil. It is precisely for security reasons that parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs considered that fingerprints should be collected from the age of six. Only then can we better protect our children, whether it's against identity fraud, kidnapping or trafficking. Every year 15,000 people are trafficked in Europe, of which at least 3,000 are children. We have a duty to fight this scourge and through this reform we are doing so. Mr President, with this enhanced VIS we will facilitate the issuance of visas, prevent so-called visa shopping, visa fraud and illegal immigration, we will increase the scrutiny of Gold visas and better protect our children. Finally, we take another important step towards an area of free movement with justice and security. We take another step towards a true Europe of citizens.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, allow me to start by expressing my thanks to our rapporteur, Mr Coelho, and the shadow rapporteurs for the work done in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the proposal we are discussing tonight. We all know that every year, millions of non-EU nationals enter the European Union with a visa, be it for a short stay or for a longer period. Most of them are legitimate travellers who fulfil the entry and stay conditions on the territory of the Member States. The current Visa Information System (VIS) allows us to check at the external borders, and in the consulates around the world, that these conditions are fulfilled. There are, however, still some gaps that we need to close. With the new Visa Information System, we will remove blind spots in our systems and give visa authorities and border guards the information they need to do their jobs properly. We cannot allow criminals and potential terrorists to enter Europe undetected. Europe, I have repeatedly said, is not a fortress, and will never become one but, at the same time, we need to know who is crossing our borders. The Commission welcomes Parliament’s support on the key objectives of our proposal. Let me mention the most important ones. Firstly, the interlinking of the VIS to the Entry/Exit System, ETIAS (European Travel Information and Authorisation System), the Schengen Information System and ECRIS (European Criminal Records Information System). This will help us to detect the use of multiple identities and to identify anyone posing a security risk. Secondly, the closing of the information gap on long-stay visas and residence permits – which currently is information not shared at EU level – will allow guards and immigration authorities quickly to determine whether the documents presented to them are valid, and whether they are in the hands of persons entitled to have them. It will also allow national authorities not to legalise the presence of third-country nationals who do not fulfil basic security conditions for entry and stay in the European Union, such as persons with links to known terrorists or organised crime networks. This will close an important security gap. Finally, the inclusion of copies of the visa applicant’s travel document in the VIS database is a measure which, together with authorisation for European Border and Coast Guard Agency staff to have access to the VIS, will facilitate the identification and readmission of undocumented irregular migrants. This will increase the efficiency of the European Union returns policy, notably in relation to third countries refusing to give us their cooperation. In addition to this, to strengthen our capacity to prosecute and prevent crime, law-enforcement authorities and Europol will have better access to the Visa Information System for prevention, detection or investigation of terrorist offences or other serious crimes. Access to the VIS will also be opened to law-enforcement authorities for the purpose of searching or identifying missing or abducted persons and victims of trafficking. This access will always be subject to full respect for the European Union’s data protection rules. The VIS upgrade is part of the Smart Borders package and also part of interoperability. For that reason, the rationale and foundations of this proposal should be preserved throughout the legislative process. That is why I would like to refer to some changes proposed in the report. Firstly, the inclusion of information on residence permits in the VIS is linked also to the issue of golden visas. While registering all permits issued by Member States in a single EU information system might not resolve the question of possible abuse in granting such permits, it provides greater transparency among Member States. I understand that Parliament wants to take this measure one step further and enable the storage and verification of these documents in the VIS from the moment of application, in order to ensure better control over the issuing process. We are looking positively at this proposal. Secondly, regarding multiple queries for security and irregular migration checks, the benefits of interoperability should not be watered down by excluding some databases from searches. We managed to agree that ECRIS and the travel documents associated with notices are relevant in ETIAS, and that should be the relevant standard for the VIS as well. It is a matter of coherence and consistency. The standards of verification of third-country nationals who can enter the EU visa free should not be tougher than those applied to third-country nationals under visa obligations. Thirdly, the Commission proposed to update the existing law-enforcement access rules for the VIS. But it is important to ensure that law-enforcement access remains balanced and is not detrimental to the efficiency of the procedure. For instance, adding the obligation to consult Prüm databases first will make access more burdensome. Fourthly, regarding the finger-printing of children, we have to be consistent. We have proposed lowering the age for finger-printing because we want to fight child trafficking more effectively. I am sure this is an objective that we all share. I understand that you are concerned about the fundamental rights of children and so are we. Trafficking of children, abduction or smuggling is an abuse of fundamental rights. Statistics show that, annually, between 1 500 and 2 000 third-country national children under the age of 12 are victims of trafficking in the Schengen area, and between 3 200 and 4 250 aged between 12 and 17. Most of these children come from countries that are under visa obligation. We need to make all possible efforts to tackle this issue. The lowering of the age of finger-printing provides us with a key tool for achieving concrete results. I want to close with the most important point for our citizens. Fundamental rights will be, as always, at the heart of all our policies, including in the design of our information systems. All reports on the performance of the VIS indicate that its implementation has never led to fundamental-rights or data-protection concerns. Not a single complaint has been registered against the VIS in its first five years of functioning. We have taken the relevant provisions one step further following the ‘data protection by design’ principle. We stand ready to work with the co-legislators, during the trilogies, to improve those standards further, but we need to remain effective and not depart from our key objectives. Thank you for your attention. I’m looking forward to our debate.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his good work. The Committee on Budgets fully supports the rapporteur's statements.  Ensuring compatible IT systems is absolutely essential today. Particularly in the area of border crossings and visas, these conditions must be met so that we can combat multiple identities and identity fraud. We also need the opportunity to identify identities more easily. This is a contribution to preventing crime, especially in the fight against terrorism. This requires investment. According to the calculations, a total of EUR 461 million will have to be invested over nine years. That is a large amount, but I am convinced that we will get better security for the citizens of the EU, and that is why the money is well invested.  However, we must be aware that only 2019 and 2020 will have the necessary budgetary resources. In the new multiannual financial framework, these funds have yet to be earmarked, and i therefore urge this House to be aware that, if this project is to be approached, the necessary funds must also be made available in the next budget, otherwise we will create a torso, and of course no one has anything of that.

name: Emil RADEV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Visa Information System is an important element of the security framework in the European Union because it enables the competent services to detect the authenticity and validity of visas issued allowing free movement within the Schengen area. However, the fact that the system includes only short-stay visas at this stage is a breach of European security. I therefore welcome the reform proposed by the European Commission last year, which will keep information on long-stay visas and residence permits within the European Union. These documents also provide an opportunity for free movement within Schengen and it is important that the authorities, those fighting illegal migration and ensuring the security of European citizens, have information on their validity and veracity. The reform of the Visa Information System is also an important element of the interconnection of security information systems in the European Union. It is high time that the security authorities were able to take advantage of the information available in the various systems, of course without compromising the security of citizens' personal information and data.  Last but not least, I would like to call on the Home Affairs Council to finally take a positive decision on Bulgaria's immediate accession to Schengen, which will allow our country to actively use the Visa Information System and thereby contribute to ensuring security in Europe.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. First of all, I would like to thank the reporter Mr Coelho for his work on a very constructive, open and common solution-seeking cooperation.  The visa system, I think, is a very important element of the common European asylum policy. Joint action in this area is particularly important, as millions of visas to the European Union are issued every year. The primary objective of the reform now proposed is to improve the exchange and sharing of relevant data on visa issuing between the different EU information systems. All this is necessary because, in the face of today's security challenges, we need to operate much more efficiently than before and to strengthen the protection of the European Union's external borders through this system.  During the reform of the system, the opinion of the Union Agency for Fundamental Rights and the European Data Protection Commissioner was of particular importance to my group, in particular with regard to long-term visas, on which both reports stressed the need and proportionality principles. As the bill is closely linked to the interoperability of EU information systems, changes in any database also have an impact on the processing of data of third-country nationals. This, in turn, once again raises the question of necessity and proportionality mentioned above and the necessary exclusion of the possibility of discrimination. I think that, in the end, we have reached an acceptable compromise. The report does not undermine fundamental rights while contributing to increasing and increasing security, thereby reaching its original objective. Thank you, Mr. President.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the Visa Information System facilitates the visa application process while combating visa fraud and illegal migration. Border guards are connected to EU consulates around the world through the system. It provides the visa-delivering authorities with essential information about applicants, while border guards can track down and stop travellers with bad intentions.  Every year, 16 million Schengen visas are delivered for short stays. The importance of the system cannot thus be underestimated.  I wholeheartedly support the practical improvements that this proposal is making, from automatic cross-checks with other databases and access for law enforcement authorities, to the storage of information designed to facilitate the return of illegal immigrants. Any reform that can eliminate the shortcomings of the current database, so that it becomes even more useful and effective, can count on our support.  The text before us today seems to us to be an excellent starting point for starting negotiations with the Council during the next parliamentary term.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, more than 48 million visa applications and 41 million registered fingerprints. In truth, the visa information system is already, in its current state, a very beautiful tool, both necessary and effective. Thanks to the proposals contained in the report of our friend Carlos Coelho, whom I want to congratulate for the quality of his work, the system will become even more efficient tomorrow. We support the inclusion in the VIS of long-stay visas and residence permits. At present, data on third-country nationals staying in a Member State is not exchanged. Exchanges tomorrow will allow residents to easily prove their right to stay throughout the Schengen area and to introduce a start of transparency in the granting - I should say the sale - of visas and long-stay documents. I support and support the idea of facilitating access by the enforcement and Europol services to the data recorded in the VIS. I support and support the willingness to record a copy of the applicant's travel document to facilitate return proceedings. I would argue, even if this point is not unanimous among my group, that the desire to lower the age at which fingerprints will be recorded in the VIS from 12 to 6 years, which will allow for better control when crossing an external border and will provide better protection for children. I recall that, according to the available data, 40% of children involved in human trafficking are under the age of 12. Finally, I stress that, in addition to automatic searches of databases, visa applications will be analysed on the basis of specific risk indicators based on statistics and information provided by Member States, which will eliminate abnormal refusal rates or the overstay of the length of stay of certain categories of third-country nationals. Carlos, I congratulate you on your work, which deserves the support of our Parliament.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, I have the impression that I will feel a little lonely. Created in 2004, which came into force in 2014, the VIS (visa information system), like the visa code, was intended to facilitate visas. Since 2014, we have witnessed an unfortunate evolution. Indeed, it is no longer a question of generalized control and systematic employment. I welcome the work of our rapporteur, who has allowed us to remove some of the most problematic points, such as Interpol's TDAWN, which allows some countries to catch up with their opponents on the run, as we have seen recently in the case of Saudis. However, we reject risk indicators that mix security, irregular immigration and health risk. Hello the principle of purpose! We refuse the integration of long-stay visas, which are outside the eu's jurisdiction. Hello subsidiarity! We are outraged by the fingerprinting of children and especially by its reduction from 12 to 6 years, regardless of the reasons put forward. Hello proportionality! We say no to this text, as to the whole 'Borders' package. We reject the logic of the whole safe, of all recorded at exorbitant costs. A project for which money flows!

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, we are discussing the new Visa Information System here in the plenary session of the European Parliament. What it's all about. In order to allow the connection of border guards — from the external borders of the Member States of the European Union — with the consulates of the Member States around the world so that information can be provided in real time to Schengen visa applicants who may pose security risks — through biometric comparisons fingerprints, identification and verification systems. In such a way as to welcom this initiative which responds to security challenges in the European Union and, in particular, enables interconnection through new technologies and the interoperability of data relating to visa applicants and threats to the security of Member States.  From the Socialist Group we have provided guarantees of respect for the principles of the Lisbon Treaty of proportionality and necessity while guaranteeing and respecting the rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the General Data Protection Regulation.  But the important thing is that it is not exclusively in terms of security that we are moving forward in the European Union, but at the same time that a comprehensive system is offered to asylum and refuge seekers and to the administration of the European Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, I welcome the efforts to make visa applications and verifications more efficient, as well as the inclusion of long—stay visas and residence permits in the new regulation. However, as a member of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats, I am concerned about the data processing and the impact it will have on privacy. The connection of the Visa Information System with other databases, through interoperability architecture, poses a risk of unlawful data transfer and data leaks. Yes, by making information on visas more complete we can achieve better risk assessment but, at the same time, we are exposing sensitive data to major risks. I believe that we must first make full use of the Visa Information System’s potential before we link it to other systems. Moreover, no European company is currently able to administer interoperability of information systems. So, shall we delegate this task to a Chinese or an Indian company? In such a case, I’m afraid our data security would be seriously jeopardised and we would achieve the opposite of what we want.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the visa information system really needs a number of improvements and I think that the measures taken in this direction really can meet the needs. However, Mr Avramopoule, let me raise an issue with you, because I fear that in a moment those who come by air from Greece to Belgium will need a visa. I had denounced the unacceptable phenomenon of quarantine imposed on German airports, but also at Brussels airport, and I had received a reply to this question from you on 23 November that you had found it to meet the standards.  I am telling you, then, that on 19 February and 5 March this quarantine system was repeated again and there, in one case, supposedly police officers appeared, in the other case, supposedly customs officers showed up. Both I and Mr Papadimoulis, who were on the same flight, and other MEPs, have had the unfavourable luck - unfortunate if you will - of being subjected to a passport check. Is that legal? Can this process continue at Brussels Airport? We want an answer, Commissioner. Concrete measures should be taken. We will soon need visas from Greece and Brussels. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, this is a new, hugely ambitious, hugely expensive system for controlling people entering the EU, a visa scheme which will be in common use across the EU, disregarding the fact that different countries may have different requirements as to who enters their country – so a visa could be for a different place or perhaps for a different person. But it’s not just that. One of the things that has been pointed out was that this is about combating terrorism, yet most terrorism appears now to be carried out by so-called home-grown terrorists, of the second or third generation of people who’ve been here. The system is intended to control the number of people coming in, yet already we’ve had millions of people coming to the EU, many of them actually invited in. They’re already here. This appears to be a high-tech, high-cost exercise in shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome the fact that within the space of just one year we have managed to reach an agreement with the Council on eu-LISA, SIS, ETIAS and interoperability regulations. The Visa Information System (VIS), together with ETIAS and the entry-exit system, will form part of a single platform for third-country nationals visiting the European Union. The VIS proposal will close the information gap on long-stay document holders, as well as a number of security gaps on both short and long-stay travellers. It is therefore extremely important that the systems are synchronised to the largest extent possible. I strongly believe that the Visa Information System should be swiftly agreed in the next legislature. I regret that this could not have already been done by now, but I hope we can start dialogues by the end of September. We all remain committed here to delivering a Europe that protects and makes our citizens feel safe and secure. That is why I warmly encourage you to support the important elements of this legislation tomorrow in the vote, allowing us to close the existing security gaps and continue working towards building a safer Union for all our citizens. Let me now reply to my friend Mr Marias in Greek. Αγαπητέ κύριε Μαριά, σήμερα συζητούμε εδώ ένα πάρα πολύ σημαντικό θέμα. Θα μου επιτρέψετε να σας πω ότι η ερώτησή σας δεν έχει καμία σχέση με αυτό το θέμα. Επειδή όμως, συμμερίζομαι την ευαισθησία σας, θα ήθελα να σας παρακαλέσω να μου στείλετε μία γραπτή ερώτηση. Θα φροντίσω να κάνω τις απαραίτητες ενέργειες να πληροφορηθώ και να σας απαντήσω.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for their contributions to the European People’s Party (EPP) and to myself. To keep the scope of the system is crucial. Without it, this reform loses much of its value. We will not be serving European citizens well if we take that out. As citizens’ representatives, we have the obligation to defend their best interests and we are accountable before them for the votes that we cast in this House. It is true and evident that every opinion is legitimate, but rest assured, those who think that golden visas should not be subject to greater scrutiny and those who do not want to better protect children will have to explain their actions to their voters. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their very constructive spirit. I also want to extend my gratitude to your staff, the Secretary of this House and the services of the European Commission. You have all been essential to this outcome.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 13 March 2019. Written declarations (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – As rapporteur for opinion in the Committee on Budgets for the dossier regarding the Visa Information System, I salute the need to improve EU security through strengthened visa procedures and residence permit applications. The Visa Information System has been established by the Council to serve as the technology solution to exchange visa data between Member States. It provides visa-issuing authorities with key information on applicants for short-stay Schengen visas.  However, in 2016, the Commission outlined the need for the EU to strengthen and improve its IT systems, data architecture and information exchange in the area of border management, law enforcement and counter-terrorism and emphasised the need to improve the interoperability of IT systems. It also identified the need to address information gaps on third-country nationals holding a long-stay visa. Nevertheless, I would also like to express my concern that we should firstly focus on strengthening the current Schengen area and its external borders. While Romania and Bulgaria have partial access to the Visa Information System in the Schengen area, the two states have to join Schengen as full members as soon as possible, which I am confident will bring a positive contribution to the overall security of the EU.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Mrs May's report. Miriam Dalli, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Asylum and Migration Fund (COM(2018)0471 - C8-0271/2018 - 2018/0248(COD)) (A8-0106/2019).

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Mr. Rapporteur, i.e. – Sur President, Kummisarju, collegi, uppermettuli billi nibda nirrrazzja lix-Shadow Rapporteurs tal-Group kollha għall-kontribut tagħhom. Ninsabu fl-istess kamra fejn f'diversi dibattiti tkellimna dwar il-valuri Ewropej, dwar il-prin大ipju tas-solidarjetà u dwar kemm huma prezzjużi l-ħajjiet tan-nies. U f'din il-kamra kemm-il darba sħaqna fuq il-ħtieġa li bħala rappreżentanti ta-ittadini Ewropej, il-prijorità tagħna tkun dik li nissalvagwardjaw l-interessi tagħhom, li nkunu lesti li nieħdu deħiżjonijiet li forsi mhumiex daqstant popolari. Għal żmien twil, il-kwistjoni tal-immigrazzjoni tħalliet taħt taħt ta-tapit, forsi bit-tama li tissolva waħedha. I kienx il-każ dakinhar u mhuwiex il-każ illum. Minflok, din l-attitudni wasslet biex aktar nies iħossuhom 'il bogħod mill-Unjoni Ewropea u sfortunatament jintilfu aktar ħajjiet. U qed inħallsu għaliha billi l-istituzzjonijiet Ewropej qed ikollhom jaqdfu ħafna biex jerġgħu jirbħu lura l-fiduħja ta大-ħittadini. Huwa fatt li l-Unjoni Ewropea bdiet u kompliet tieħu passi u miżuri differenti biex tindirizza l-immigrazzjoni minn diversi aspetti, iżda filwaqt li l-Parlament Ewropew kompla miexi 'l quddiem biex nilħqu Sistema Komuni Ewropea għall-Asil li tqassam il-piż bejn l-Istati Membri, hemm proposti kruħli li jinsabu mwaħħla-Kunsill Ewewrop-millxxejja he' wħud-Istati Membri. Li jġibni għall-fond li għandna quddiemna llum. Fond ta' aktar minn 10 biljun euro biex l-Unjoni Ewropea tkun tista' tuża dawn il-flus mal-Istati Membri stess. Issa hawn min jargumenta, u se jkun hawn min jargumenta llejla, li l-kwistjoni tal-immigrazzjoni għandha tiġi indirizzata 'l barra mill-fruntieri tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Ir-realtà llum il-ġurnata, iżda, hi li għandna ħafna pajjiżi tal-Unjoni Ewropea li għandhom bżonn is-sostenn finanzjarju biex jindirizzaw il-problemi li qed jiffa大大jaw illum stess. U nagħmlu dan jekk verament nemmnu li rridu nimplimentaw politika li effettivament twassal għall-ġarr tar-responsabilità u s-solidarjetà. Jiena ġejja minn Malta, pajjiż fejn i大-大ittadini tagħna jafu u jifhmu xi jfisser li tkun fuq il-fruntiera. Bħala pajjiż salvajna l-ħajjiet, ilqajna l-persuni, ġarrejna r-responsabilità u wettaqna s-solidarjetà bil-fatti. U bħalna hemm pajjiżi oħra tal-Unjoni Ewropea li qegħdin fuq il-fruntiera u ma jdawrux wi大大hom in-naħa l-oħra. It's a great time to be able to do that. Għalhekk kien ta' sodisfazzjoni għalija li l-Kumitat approva u għamel mill-prin大ipju tas-solidarjetà, prin大ipju fundamentali li jirregola dan il-fond. Fl-ibliet u l-irħula tagħna naraw il-ħidma li tkun għaddejja mill-awtoritajiet nazzjonali, reġjonali u lokali flimkien mas-so大jetà ívili u organizzazzjonijiet mhux governattivi biex l-immigrazzjoni irregolari ma tkunx ta' piż fuq il-komunitajietjiet tagħna. U nifhmu fuq kollox l-appoġġ li hemm bżonn fil-każijiet fejn ikun hemm tfal waħedhom. Hemm bżonn li din il-ħidma tkun sostnuta u għalhekk nilqa' wkoll id-de-de-żjoni tal-Kumitat li jaġppoġja dan. Għalhekk ukoll l-importanza li t-titlu tal-fond jirreferi għall-integrazzjoni bl-għan li nirrikonoxxu u nsostnu l-importanza ta' so大jetajiet u komunitajiet aktar magħquda. Għandna 10,4 biljun euro li l-għan prinħipali tagħhom huwa li nagħtu l-għajnuna meħtieġa lill-pajjiżi tal-Unjoni Ewropea, spe大jalment dawk l-aktar affettwati. U biex nagħmlu dan irridu nimplimentaw il-politika Ewropea fuq l-asil u l-immigrazzjoni. Ifisser ukoll li għandna nagħmlu l-aħjar użu possibbli minn dawn il-fondi. Wara kollox dan huwa l-uniku strument intern li għandna biex jindirizza l-kwistjoni tal-immigrazzjoni fost il-pajjiżi tal-Unjoni Ewropea. U biex nindirizzaw il-kwistjoni tal-immigrazzjoni irregolari hemm bżonn ħidma li hija ffukata kemm fi ħdan il-pajjiżi iżda wkoll f'pajjiżi terzi. Imma dan l-istrument finanzjarju għandu jkun komplementat ma' strumenti diġà eżistenti li jindirizzaw pajjiżi terzi u mhux nippretendu li dan l-istrument finanzjarju se jagħmel tajjeb għal dak li ma jsirx b'fondi oħra. Dan il-fond huwa mibni fuq numru ta' pilastri fosthom is-CEAS, l-immigrazzjoni legali, l-integrazzjoni u s-solidarjetà. Għalhekk li fir-rapport hemm inkluż persentaġġi minimi għal hawk wieħed minn dawn l-għanijiet. Dawn huma persentaġi minimi li assolutament i jnaqqrux mill-flessibilità imma jenfasizzaw il-fatt li kull objettiv għandu rwol importanti biex l-ebda pajjiż ma jitalla għal rieħu. Irridu na大大ertaw ruħna li kull pajjiż jagħmel il-parti tiegħu f'din il-katina ta' solidarjetà u responsabilità. Wara kollox jekk id-diskors li ilna ngħidu fl-aħħar ħames snin dwar is-solidarjetà nemmnu fih, allura rridu narawh jitwettaq bil-fatti.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes the speedy work of Parliament in preparing the reports on the three important files that we are going to debate tonight and specifically on the new Asylum and Migration Fund. Many of the issues I will underline are of a horizontal nature and concern all three funds. I would like to stress that I hope the Council will also soon adopt its negotiating mandate.  Migration and security continue to be among the main concerns of our citizens today. We need enough resources to support our actions in these areas in line with our political priorities and in complementarity with all EU funds. In the current period assistance has been provided to approximately one million asylum applicants. Furthermore, integration support has been provided to 3.4 million third—country nationals. None of this could have been achieved without the support of the Union’s budget.  Things can change and evolve and our funding has to be flexible, simplified and adaptable. Therefore, we propose a reinforcement of the overall budget for migration, border management and security of more than EUR 36 billion for the period 2021—2027, out of which EUR 10.4 billion for the Asylum and Migration Fund. This reflects the political importance that the Commission attaches to better managing migration, borders and security challenges. I know that this view is also shared by Parliament.  The Asylum and Migration Fund specifically will provide support for strengthening the Common European Asylum System, legal migration to the Member States and provide integration support for third-country nationals. Within these objectives it will provide incentives for integration measures at local and regional level, such as language courses and civic orientation courses, and it will support resettlement and solidarity with Member States. The Fund will also help to counter irregular migration through returns of persons that do not, or no longer, have the right to stay in the Union.  However, in order to succeed, in addition to more budget we also need to ensure flexibility for our funds. We need financing instruments that will be able to support EU policies and priorities as they develop until 2027, Financing instruments that will be able to support our Member States when they are in need. I cannot emphasise flexibility enough. This is why flexibility is built into all three funds that we will be discussing tonight through the thematic facility and the mid—term review, allowing us to allocate 50% of the funding, based on evolving needs and EU priorities at the point in time. At the same time, there will be enough upfront funding – 50% – to Member States to support actions quickly and allow them to plan long—term investment.  We have also proposed to simplify the implementation. The management of the funds will be simplified by using a single rulebook for the implementation of shared management funds. We have also built in synergies. We have worked to deliver a coherent and complementary approach to the migration and security objectives of the Union in different EU funds: areas such as integration of third-country nationals, anti—radicalisation measures, cooperation with the partner countries, to name a few. While the Commission at this stage reserves its position, we must underline that Parliament proposes a number of important obstacles to the flexible use of the future funds that the Commission cannot accept. Minimum spending percentages are an obstacle to flexibility. Member States have different needs and experience different levels of pressure. They should be able to channel EU funding where it is most needed.  In addition, this proposal would make the funds even less flexible than in the current period and would add an administrative and monetary burden. By the same token, building strong partnerships with countries of origin and transit has been a key feature of the European Union’s migration policy from day one. Close cooperation with our partners is key to be able to respond to these challenges. I want to explicitly stress the following: setting a maximum limit for external actions and allowing cooperation only in exceptional cases will not only impact the flexibility of the Fund, but also the achievement of the migration and security objectives of the Union. Moreover, we have proposed a very high conditionality of 30% of absorption for Member States to benefit from additional funding at the mid—term and we have introduced rigidities in the thematic facility, including to implement it through delegated acts that is not legally possible. It is more important than ever that we get it right and design our instruments to withstand the test of time.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would particularly like to thank the rapporteur, Miriam Dalli, for the work she has done on a very important dossier, as well as my colleagues in the Committee on Development, with whom we have tried to ensure that the new external dimension of the Fund takes account of the possible impact on third countries and that it does not overlap improperly with the instruments for development cooperation. , which must remain geared towards eradicating poverty without conditionality on return and readmission.  The increase in the funds available to strengthen the common European asylum system is good news: adequate resources are needed to ensure good reception, integration and legal avenues at European level. It is important that the instrument is not used to encourage returns, which cannot happen without an adequate impact assessment on the country of origin that also considers its absorption capacities.  Therefore, the proposal adopted in the Committee on European Free Market already appears to be a great improvement on the Commission's text, including in the title and among the criteria the integration and construction of legal and safe access routes.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the new AMIF Fund, with a budget of over EUR 10 billion over the next 7 years, must be a starting point for finally creating a common asylum and integration policy based on the value of solidarity between the Member States. Migratory flows are, as we know, a global phenomenon that needs a unanimous response at European level. AMIF funds will have to continue to finance integration projects at local level, especially the best, such as the SPRAR model in Italy, which Minister Salvini is cancelling with an absurd decree that is only bringing insecurity. Emptying and closing reception centres, clearing buildings, would this be security according to the Italian Government and according to Minister Salvini? Does this mean finding a long-term solution to the migration issue?  Of course not, Commissioner, because the populist forces that live on the right of this House and in this Chamber and which are in government in Italy want to leave the issue of immigrants open and unresolved in order to be able to campaign permanently. That is why they did not want to resolve the Dublin issue, so they are allied with the Kaczyńskis, with the Orbán, with the Kurzs in Europe. Look at this House, Mr President: not even a representative of Italy, not even a representative of the majority of our country, and it is the country that would need most to be here to discuss these issues. Thank you again, Commissioner, thank you once again for the work you are doing, and thank you to Mrs Dalli.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the migration crisis has been one of the deepest crises in the history of the EU. If one thing has become clear in recent years, it is that we need to strengthen our European response and the new Asylum and Migration Fund will play an important role in that. I thank Commissioner Avramopoulos for proposing that this fund be tripled. It is something the EPP has asked for and I’m very happy that the Commission delivered. However, to deliver real results, we don’t only need sufficient resources; we also need flexibility to adjust to the challenges in front of us and we need balance between the objectives served by this fund. I understand a little bit the frustration of the Commissioner in his speech because the flexibility and the balance that was there in the original proposal seems to have become a bit lost along the way in this House. The text in front of us focuses on legal migration and integration while minimising any attention on returns and fighting illegal migration, for instance, by introducing mandatory spending requirements for all the fund objectives, except for fighting illegal migration and ensuring returns. Moreover – and the Commissioner said this – if we want to have a real, effective and holistic approach to migration, we need to cooperate with countries outside the EU: countries of origin and countries of transit. That is absolutely crucial. Yet, the amendments in front of us in the European Parliament will make it nearly impossible to cooperate with third countries on these issues. I am disappointed that a majority in this House seems to think that fighting illegal migration, ensuring the return of illegally staying third-country nationals and cooperating with other countries is not important. For the EPP, it is important. All the objectives of the fund are important, that’s why we have tabled amendments for the vote tomorrow – to make this a more realistic fund, and we would like to call on all colleagues who share that realistic view to support us in the vote tomorrow.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work. The success of the European Union's management of migratory flows is also based on effective reception and integration policies. Policies which are implemented jointly and severally in full compliance with the provisions of Article 80 of the Treaty.  For this reason, we have restored the voice of integration within this Fund, convinced that only through holistic management of the migration phenomenon will it be possible to meet the priorities set by the Commission in the European agenda on migration and reiterated by the European Parliament resolution in April 2016.  The common asylum system must also be reformed more fairly and effectively by strengthening the protection of vulnerable asylum seekers, such as children and women, by supporting integration strategies and more effective policies on legal immigration, by creating safe and legal access routes. With the greater flexibility we have given to this Fund, we expect the various governments of the European Union to direct their funding towards the Union's priorities and actions with significant added value for the union as a whole. By creating a policy of solidarity in fact.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: On the other: The ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The fall of the EU will not be due to a financial crisis, environmental degradation or war. The fall of the EU will be the lack of action to stop the influx of economic and illegal migrants. By tripling the appropriations for the Asylum and Migration Fund, thereby creating more incentives for fortune seekers to get to our Member States, offering more legal routes and more generous conditions, we are opening up the way to increase migration to the EU.  We are talking about the importance of integration into this fund, without even mentioning assimilation. We in Sweden have spent for decades spending enormous sums of taxpayers' money on ineffective projects to try to integrate the huge number of migrants who have arrived in my country. Some integration projects that have been invested in new arrivals are priority in the labour and housing market, special diets, separate bathing times for women and men and that some schools have stopped with some Swedish traditions because it can be perceived as negative.  As I proposed in the LIBE Committee, the fund's money should be halved, and 85% will be spent on creating measures that drastically reduce migration to the EU and also ensure that those who stay within the EU's borders illegally are taken into account and return to their home countries as soon as possible. Those who have the right to stay should be as soon as possible assimilated into our society and take the custom where they come.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, my thanks to the rapporteur. I would like in particular to thank her for supporting our initiative to include funds for local authorities and communities, because that’s where we see the action happening, where European citizens gather together to help people in need. This is really great. This is the Europe we really need to see and it’s correct to put the money there. On the other hand, though, it’s an illusion to think that other countries are going to solve our problems: that we create closed centres somewhere in Egypt or I don’t know where and that we put the problem away. This would violate human rights and it would also go totally against European Union values. I believe we should not put money into violating what we ourselves stand for; what this Union was founded on. Instead, the European Union needs human rights and it needs solidarity, so let’s make sure that the Fund can indeed be used for integration, for supporting people in need and those people who are already active on the ground all over Europe.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the scale of life lost in the Mediterranean is nothing short of abhorrent. EU migration policies have essentially authorised the death of thousands of refugees at sea. The EU has washed its hands of its responsibility for this humanitarian crisis. The Libyan coast guards are still dragging vulnerable refugees from unseaworthy rafts. Refugees are still being thrown into detention centres to rot. Refugees are still being starved, beaten, deprived of water, forced to live in abhorrent squalor and some are even murdered. The scale of this crisis has been fed by EU asylum policy, which is facilitating torture. Shame on the European People’s Party (EPP) and the far right who argue to use the large-scale amount of funding to force vulnerable people into unsafe countries under the guise of flexibility and balance. We need a sustainable solution based on the principles of dignity, safety and fundamental rights. No human being is illegal.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, on Wednesday, 6 March, Frans Timmermans, our esteemed colleague, said that Europe is no longer experiencing the migration crisis we lived through in 2015. This is backed up by UN statistics that show an 89% reduction in Mediterranean crossings from 2015 to 2018. Good news, eh! And then, all of a sudden, here we are with a EUR 10 billion package to deal with asylum and migration – asylum and migration that the great Mr Timmermans says is no longer a big deal. And what’s the money going to be spent on, then? Well, it includes bribe payments to third countries to set up camps to keep people in. It includes money to pay countries within the EU to settle migrants in their countries, and it includes a generally vague amount which I think is just generally for political use and which isn’t particularly specified, but – hey ho! – it’s only EUR 10 billion of taxpayers’ money. What this actually amounts to is an organisation that has decided it can’t stop mass immigration and, what’s more, it actually thinks it’s a rather good idea. Therefore, we’re going to make sure that everyone, in the spirit of solidarity – that lovely word we hear so often – gets to take their share and gets paid to take people in, regardless of what the people in those countries might have thought. Because let’s not forget, your great horror in this place is the awful populists; these terrible people who actually listen to what their electorate say. You’ve got European elections coming up and, to my great concern and sadness after events in Westminster tonight, it would appear there’s a very strong chance that the UK may take part in those. Do you seriously think that measures like these will go unnoticed? You had a problem with people across the rest of the EU gathering in their anti-EU feelings, you had a problem that at least a third of the votes in that election were probably going to go to anti-establishment forces. Well, I can tell you that if the UK is forced down the route of another EU election and we have these kinds of issues to deal with, you’re going to have the really enjoyable prospect of 25, 30 or 35 little Nigel Farages running loose in this Parliament. I’m sure you’ll be looking forward to that. If you’re going to go down this route, I strongly suggest that you advise your colleagues to get the Brexit bill sorted fast, otherwise we’re going to be here to haunt you and it’s going to be very unpleasant.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, by creating this new version of the Asylum and Migration Fund, the European Union is still locked into its crazy migration policy. The proposed project is catastrophic. It aims to spend more than 10 billion euros to organise the relocation of migrants and the opening of legal immigration routes. It also aims to encourage, I quote, 'intercultural and inter-religious dialogue between host societies and migrants', while we should instead fight Islamic radicalisation and defend our European values, in particular the dignity of women. Finally, it aims to continue the massive funding of NGOs that organize the migration submersion, such as Open Society, of billionaire George Soros, when instead it should be combated without weakness. Once again, you want to betray European civilization. We will alert the people of Europe to prevent you from doing so.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the Asylum and Migration Fund must be a flexible instrument to adapt to future challenges as well as to the different needs of the Member States, while being sufficiency to deal with new contingencies. The Fund needs to be fully integrated into the Union's acquis for migration, guaranteed through the 2015 European Agenda on Migration, and coordinated with the different proposals in the migration and asylum package and with emergency trust funds for Africa and Libya. The Union should support Member States in their actions and measures to alleviate migration pressures, as well as to carry out their legal obligations. But these also need to ensure that people arriving in Europe have adequate reception and assistance and access to equitable, legal and effective asylum procedures. This is a joint commitment. The ten and four hundred million proposed by the Commission for this Fund should also be used to intensify joint work with countries of origin and transit, so that people who are forced to leave their homes do not fall into criminal hands. Last December's Council conclusions applauded work in the fight against traffickers in external border control and cooperation with countries of origin and transit. However, efforts remain insufficient to end this tragedy. For this reason, this instrument must be approved and strengthened.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, we are coming to the end of this mandate of the European Parliament, sadly characterized, dramatically, by the ill-called refugee crisis, which has actually been a crisis of trust between the Member States and, above all, of political will to comply with european law which has been adopted by this European Parliament. This European Parliament has done its job and is also doing so by supporting this remarkable report by our colleague, Mrs Dalli, which is committed to a European Asylum and Migration Fund which, endowed with no less than EUR 10.4 billion for the next multiannual financial framework 2021-2027, seeks to provide a response that is consistent with the resolutions we have adopted to give an integral dimension - holistically we call it - to the problem of asylum and shelter , but above all that it requires Member States to have a minimum percentage of compliance with European law in order to make it effective and to be able to access the realisation of those funds, and to truly carry out the principle of solidarity, which is not a wishful thinking, but a binding mandate under European law.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Migration and Asylum Fund is one of the most important funds in the field of home affairs because of the support it provides to Member States to tackle migration and refugee intake. I welcome the significant increase in the budget proposed by the European Commission. It is proof that the topic of migration will remain on the agenda and that no country will be left alone to cope with the ongoing migratory pressures. As a representative of a country on the frontline of the migration wave of recent years, it is extremely important to me that part of the fund's funds are used to bring illegal migrants back to their countries of origin. It is unacceptable that less than 40% of people who do not have the right to reside in the European Union should be sent back. This percentage should be significantly increased. The European Union cannot and should not be a salvation for all who want to live here for purely economic reasons.  Anyone who is not a refugee or a legal migrant should be sent back to the country from which they came and the Fund should support return activities.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Solidarity and responsibility sharing are the basis of a common European asylum policy. And although the number of refugees has steadily declined in recent months, asylum remains a major challenge for the European Union and its Member States. In this situation, it is particularly important to ensure financial support from the Union. However, in addition to helping Member States, it is essential to support the most important institutions of the Common European Asylum Policy. In this context, it is particularly regrettable that the Council has not been able to reach an agreement on the establishment of a European Asylum Agency over the years. This is solely the responsibility of the Council. At the same time, it is welcome that the Fund will have an important task of integration within the framework of the Common European Asylum Policy, since there is no real security without integration. Walls and fences won't bring us security.

name: Notis MARIAS
