text: Madam President, the Asylum and Migration Fund absolutely must and can play an important role. At a time when there are huge refugee and migration flows in the European Union. And, first and foremost, it must support the first host countries, the countries that really suffer the great migration and refugee flows, where the people are really fighting and supporting their countries' efforts to stand up and at the same time accommodate the unfortunate refugees. But, of course, we also have too many illegal immigrants who are currently flooding the Aegean islands and I think it is rightly stated in the report that a great deal of emphasis should be placed on returns, because we need to look at this issue decisively, especially for the Aegean islands, especially for Greece, where we have thousands of illegal immigrants, who are not entitled to international protection and they really have to go back to the countries from which they came.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, improving the financial aspects of the EU’s migration policy is essential and, therefore, I welcome the progress that this proposal brings. My colleague, Ms Miriam Dalli, the rapporteur, has put a strong emphasis on the importance of allowing local authorities to play a central role in European migration policy. Her focus on the importance of human rights and, in particular, human dignity is essential. The EU and its Member States have mostly adopted a shameful attitude towards refugees and migrants and it’s crucial that we shift away from this tendency.  I’m particularly worried about the pressure put on many people to voluntarily return to their country of origin. When organising voluntary returns, authorities should make sure that potential returnees have genuinely and freely agreed to this return, and this is not always the case today. All across the EU, citizens and grassroots organisations have been taking responsibility for humanitarian relief and integration regarding migrants and refugees, and I have often spoken in this Chamber about Care for Calais and other organisations that help refugees and migrants living on the streets.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Julie WARD
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the EU budget is far more than an accounting exercise. We all know that. It is a clear and concrete expression of EU political priorities. The Commission remains fully committed to continue working with you and the Council to start the negotiations on the important files as soon as possible. I look forward to continuing the negotiations.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank colleagues for their contribution. The Commissioner is right in insisting that this is a fund that should help Member States when they are most in need, and this is precisely the position of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE). Allow me to say that a minimum percentage of spending on the main objectives of the EU’s migration policy is not an obstacle at all. It channels funding to the objectives that this Commission has until now put forward as priorities. Supporting flexibility does not exclude ensuring a minimum level of funding for the objectives of the Fund. On another point, putting a cap on external funding simply ensures that this funding instrument is used for what it was originally aimed for, that is, an internal funding instrument for migration. We need to support frontline Member States. Actions in third countries are funded by other external funding instruments and no one should expect this Fund to compensate for other funds that might not deliver.  Let me turn finally to the PPE statement about returns. Member States currently spend 42% of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) on returns and this without any minimum percentage requirement. Returns remain an objective of the Fund. It has not been removed and Member States will certainly find it. We need to ensure it is not the only objective of this Fund; not to mention the statement that this Fund is not against fighting abuse. I’m still trying to find out where this emanates from. Thanks to everyone. We look forward to tomorrow’s vote and thank you for this discussion.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 13 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – It is outrageous that the pro-immigration majority in the EP is dedication to importing migrants, rather than trying to stop migration. Parliament's position allocates a significant part of the resources solely to the development of legal migration channels, the integration of migrants and the implementation of 'solidarity between Member States'. A Member State which does not wish to resettle migrants on its territory will lose a significant part of the EU funds it is due under the proposal that has just been adopted. Although the Commission maintains that there will be no resettlement quotas, the proposal sets a significant amount for this purpose. It is outrageous that the pro-immigration majority in the European Parliament allows only 5% of the Fund to help locally and eliminate the root causes. In the meantime, it would award 10,000 euros to member states for each migrant resettled, thereby encouraging the resettlement of migrants to our continent. The Commission's proposal to use EU funds confirms that the institution's real intention, despite all its denials, is to facilitate immigration by using money to encourage migrant resettlement. The hungarian pro-immigration opposition also tends to deny the distribution by quota. On the contrary, the text adopted today clearly states that the Fund will also reimburs the costs of relocating migrants under the Dublin Regulation.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the report by Tanja Fajon, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a financial assistance instrument for border management and visa policy (COM(2018)0473 – C8-0272/2018 – 2018/0249(COD)) (A8-0089/2019).

name: Tanja FAJON
text: I'm not going to be – Madam President, I will use my six minutes at the beginning and I will speak in Slovenia. The European Union has faced a number of challenges in recent years, which have greatly raised citizens' confidence in European policies. The rise of populism and nationalism is the result of European governments being unable to agree on an effective European migration policy. The pneuding of migrants and refugees, the lack of European solidarity and common solutions, the far-right policy is increasingly being used by lies and intimidation to pick political points. This is increasingly bringing discord and mistrust between citizens and states, and puts the future of Schengen and the Union in general at stake. It is enough to look at neighbouring Austria and the other 5 other schengen areas. These, despite a number of additional measures to protect the external borders and the significant reduction in the number of fugitives on European soil, have been unjustified and illegally prolonging internal border controls for more than three years. Today, it is difficult for Slovenians to explain why they are being examined by the authorities in the Karavanka or on the border between Austria and Germany. Whether we will succeed in preserving Schengen as a place of freedom of movement and without borders within the Union, which is a symbol of European integration, depends, above all, on the political wisdom and responsibility of our leaders today. But it seems to me that this wisdom and responsibility is not enough. Of course, we also need sufficient and effective financial resources for the Union's secure external borders, which are a prerequisite. I am pleased that we are debating today a proposal to spend more than €9 billion on borders and visas in the next seven years for borders and visas. That's five times more than it's ever been. That's a lot of money if we use it sensibly. Such financial instruments are extremely important for European citizens, as They translate European policies into concrete measures. And so even the most direct Europeans feel Europe. In this context, I particularly welcome the fact that at least €70 million for various measures will also be available to my country, Slovenia, which manages one of the busiest land borders, especially in the summer months. The financial instrument will provide support for Member States' actions and has two key pillars. The first is integrated border management, including land, air and sea border control, including human search and rescue at sea; preventing illegal crossings; combating cross-border crime and developing and implementing border information systems for the control of passengers and goods. On the other hand, the financial instrument will support Member States in implementing the common visa policy. Of the total financial envelope, 60 % of the funding will go to national programmes to Member States and 40 % for actions directly financed by the Union. The instrument thus provides financial support for the implementation of policies based on solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities between Member States and for strengthening mutual trust. We have also managed to ensure in the negotiations, which I am particularly pleased that at least 20% of the funds will go to visa policy and to facilitate the crossing of borders to well-intentioned travellers who pose no threat to the Union or to the Member States. Schengen, or travelling without border checks and long waiting times, is one of the Union's greatest successes and most tangible achievements for both citizens and businesses. Schengen is also one of the most important means by which European citizens can exercise their fundamental freedoms of free movement, and the internal market can thrive and evolve. We have also managed to greatly strengthen the provisions on respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. For example, the implementation of an increasing number of smart information technologies and systems at borders has greatly increased the risk of privacy violations and the need for integrated protection and protection of personal data has been increased. And we did it. Similarly, we have strengthened the provisions which always oblige Member States to respect international and European law when implementing measures, in particular the principle of non-return. However, with regard to border management, including in so-called hotspots or hot spots, we have managed to improve the provision on respect for the right to international protection and, in particular, the right to the protection of vulnerable groups, such as children. The Border and Visa Fund, which we are talking about this evening, is one of the key instruments aimed at supporting the implementation of policies within the Union. We in parliament therefore insist, as rapporteur, that the allocations will not be used to finance programmes in third countries over the next seven years. European border management is in no way linked to the establishment of detention centres or disembarkation of migrants in third countries or to the transfer of european border management to third countries. And finally, this. In order to increase transparency, we propose greater involvement of civil society and local and regional authorities in the preparation of national programmes. For greater democratic control, however, the european Parliament's role in spending money is greater. I hope that your colleagues will be able to accept this report tomorrow.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have already underlined, in our first debate, certain issues concerning all three funds, such as the need for flexibility, and synergies with all the other funds, and I am looking forward to the Council soon adopting its negotiating mandate. EU funding is paramount for creating and sustaining strong external borders. Already, four years into the current Multiannual Financial Framework, EU funding has helped train almost 9 000 border guards. Funding from the EU budget has, furthermore, supported frontline Member States managing major migratory pressure at the EU external borders. Such efforts need to be sustained and strengthened with a view to increased migratory challenges and unforeseen events at the Union’s borders. Synergies with Union action in other fields also need to be reinforced in order to maximise impact on the ground. The Commission’s response to the future challenges has been clear. We have proposed establishing a new, separate fund for integrated border management and further strengthening the European Border and Coastguard Agency with a standing corps. The new border fund will, on the one hand, help Member States to carry out customs controls by financing necessary equipment. On the other hand, through the Border Management and Visa Instrument, more than EUR 8 billion will be devoted to strengthening the EU external borders, supporting the common visa policy and helping Member States to develop new large-scale IT systems and upgrade existing ones in line with the new requirements. This represents a nearly three-fold increase, compared with the current borders instrument. Furthermore, the Commission has proposed to improve its response capacity by allowing funds to be deployed swiftly where there are major synergies. The increased flexibility of the instrument will help adapt the allocation of funding to developments on the ground, such as disproportionate pressure at the European Union’s external borders. A robust and coherent approach to border management can be achieved by improving cooperation with customs authorities, and this funding instrument will help realise that. Cooperation with third countries is another important pillar of strong border management. Allowing our border guards to work together with their counterparts in third countries, in a close and interoperable manner, will help reduce irregular migration and the loss of lives at sea. To achieve that, the Border Management and Visa Instrument has a strengthened external dimension while ensuring complementarity with action supported through external funding instruments. As I said before, capping funding for external action and allowing cooperation with third countries only in exceptional cases will hamper the Union’s ability to act when it is most needed. I’m looking forward to hearing your views at this late point in the evening.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Madam President, first I thank the rapporteur, Ms Fajon, for her good work on this proposal. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I supported this proposed regulation and asked for a greater role for Parliament in its management. We have requested that Parliament be consulted on financial decisions and reporting on this instrument. The instrument aims to safeguard freedom of movement but with particular emphasis on strong and efficient border management. In this respect, I welcome the increase in funding for this instrument, with a focus, among others things, on quality of spending as well as better monitoring of the evaluation framework. I could add that it is imperative that this fund complements the Union’s other external financial instruments and instruments with an external dimension. Compliance with fundamental rights and with the legal instruments of the European Union is also essential.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, first of all, I am pleased that the Commission has a very good and consistent proposal with regard to the future Frontex – I still call it that, because this is the shortest and simplest version to express it.  I believe that it has taken the European external border management a long time before the Member States have also been prepared to engage in a strengthened approach, and in order to be able to implement this reinforced and improved approach now, in order to ensure european external border protection and all security issues, we in the Committee on Budgets naturally want to do everything we can to ensure that the financial resources for the future and, in particular, are already earmarked for the next year and the year after, and also in the framework of the next year. under the Multiannual Financial Framework. I look forward to the legal basis being in place so that we can guarantee what we actually do together, namely to work together to ensure security and border management.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking Mrs Fajon for the excellent cooperation we have had and stressthat the management of our external borders remains and will continue to be a key point for the European Union, whether through its security component or visa policy. That is why, planning the next decade, this fund could not fail to mirror what we have learned from the most recent past.  Firstly, more money: in managing borders, Member States remain the main actors, which is why, together with the strengthening of the European Border and Coastal Agency, we multiply by five available funds; there are about ten billion that will help protect our borders while promoting legal entry into the territory. Secondly, more flexibility: the recent past has shown that we need greater solidarity and faster in emergency situations; the Union cannot be held hostage by agreements at the moment to assist embattled Member States; that is why we propose greater flexibility in the management of the fund, in exceptional and urgent cases. Thirdly, greater justice: on our own initiative, so-called cohesion countries, such as Portugal, will have funding of 85 % instead of 75 %; but also more justice in the allocation, as a clear incentive is introduced to those projects aimed at giving consequence to the problems found by the Schengen evaluation mechanism. Finally, I have often said in this House that there are no measures that can solve all the problems at once. What we must and can do is set priorities and work to improve. This is another decisive step towards the protection of our borders. Let's keep working.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. We know that populist governments constantly question and deny it, yet one of the most important elements of the European asylum system is ensuring the protection of the external borders. And in this debate, it is precisely how we can provide the financial framework for this. It is clear that Member States alone are not always able to cope with asylum challenges. This is why it is also necessary for the UNION to provide financial support to certain Member States. At the same time, it must be made very clear: asylum could not be externalised, it could not be charged to third countries. This fund is not intended for this purpose. The common European asylum policy must indeed be European. Border protection should not mean deporting as many refugees as possible, nor should we keep them in camps in third countries. Rather, the purpose of this fund is to help protect European borders, taking into account human rights.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: for the ECR Group. Madam President! The terrible terrorist attacks and mass immigration of recent years – illegal mass immigration – in the hundreds of thousands to the EU have shown that the promise made when Schengen was created that effective external border controls had not been realised when it was introduced. The Commission is now trying to rectify this, and we in the ECR Group support the Commission in the initiatives that have been taken to ensure effective external border control. That is why we are also sorry that the majority of the European Parliament has taken this, as well as other elements of the package brought forward by the Commission, in a different direction, focusing overwhelmingly on the crucial aspect of security when it comes to external border controls and on to other considerations. In the ECR Group, we simply cannot tacitly see that the European Parliament repeatedly emphasises the safety of citizens when it comes to effective control at the external borders. We therefore hope that the Commission and the Council will be able to make up for the mess that the European Parliament has made with this report and bring the proposal back to its original form.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, thank you to our rapporteur, who has put a lot of energy into making these funds acceptable, let us say, less worse. However, the FGIF, the Fund for Integrated Border Management, is no more or less the financial instrument of fortress Europe that we denounce. To carry out this safe logic, there is always funds available. A budget multiplied fivefold, or 9.3 billion euros, to which must be added the 12 billion Frontex, or about 2% of the EU budget. This money must be used to finance information systems, computerised record-findings, only those already approved by Parliament and the Council- it is comforting; equipment and infrastructure, including drones; the famous LIOs, the liaison officers, sent to assist third countries in matters of immigration, especially irregular, of course - this is worrying - additional aid to Frontex, in addition to the $12 billion; and, novelty, aid to any third country, previously reserved for neighbouring countries, and therefore the outsourcing of borders, even if it remains limited, and I welcome that. Finally, it should be noted that 60% of the fund will be returned to the States. It is therefore legitimate to ask where European policy is.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, at this session of the European Parliament we are effectively promoting and supporting the European Asylum and Migration Fund and the European Internal Security Fund. And we also support this initiative to establish, as part of the European Union's Integrated External Border Management Fund, the financial support instrument for border management and visas. Because it's about reinforcing security, yes. And to do so while preserving the most precious asset of European construction, the most valued by European citizens, which is undoubtedly the free movement of people. The Fund multiplies by no less than five amounts currently available in the next Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027. It benefits European citizens to know that there will be a strengthening of effective solidarity in the comprehensive management of the Union's external borders and in ensuring the free movement of people, but we stress again that it is not fair that so much emphasis has been placed on strengthening the security of the Union's external borders when the Council has dragged its feet , has been so reluctant and so resilient to any progress in terms of comprehensive understanding of the phenomenon of migration and refugee aid, where the moral stature of European construction is actually measured.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Schengen area is one of the main achievements and one of the most concrete achievements on the road to European integration. Proper functioning of the area without external borders must go hand in hand with a high level of security. This requires the implementation of common measures on the crossing of internal borders, controls at external borders and a common visa policy. Thanks also to this instrument, the Union is taking a step towards a common and integrated management of the external borders, while protecting the free movement of persons within its areas, while fully respecting the Union's acquis and international obligations. A firm point for us is the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms. The instrument must be implemented with full respect for rights, in particular by ensuring respect for the principles of non-refoulement, transparency and non-discrimination and the right to apply for international protection.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, with reference to the motion, I too would like to point out that the issue of hot spots is crucial and that, of course, we are all aware of that. We know that at the moment Moria has crossed its boundaries, in Lesvos, as well as the hot spot in Samos. This situation cannot continue and all this is happening even though, of course, a lot of money has been given on the part of the European Union, which is why it is certain that there must be a management check, because the party, unfortunately, continues.  From now on, I would also like to raise the issue, Mr Avramopoule, of guarding the borders in Epirus, on the Greek-Albanian border, because frontex is present at the moment. Nevertheless, unfortunately, the illegal entry of criminals on the Albanian side continues, they have literally ravaged the villages, and I think that here we must have a security intensity, there must be thermal cameras and, of course, there must also be cooperation with the customs authorities, because customs fraud is also occurring.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this interesting, though rather late, debate on the future of financial support for border management. Facilitating legitimate travel while ensuring the integrity and security of the Schengen area is at the core of our citizens’ concerns, and that makes this one of the European Union’s main priorities. We now have to demonstrate our determination to act on that priority by securing sufficient funding for this policy area and by creating a funding instrument that can deliver on it. I look forward, of course, to continuing to work with you on that.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 13 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The open area inside the European Union without borders and the free movement of persons and goods are among the greatest tangible successes of the European Community. The European Union must face the growing problems of migration, which has resulted in a reduction in the level of security in the Member States. Increased controls at the EU's internal borders are an example of a decline in mutual trust, which is not the case with the idea of a united Europe. One solution to this problem is the harmonisation and integration of external border management and the common visa policy of states. However, it should be borne in mind that the vast majority of people crossing the EU border are not a threat to internal security, but only tourists arriving in Europe in good faith. The resources allocated to the protection of the external borders and to visa programmes should be divided transparently and fairly in order to facilitate legal travel for persons arriving from third countries.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the report (COM(2018)0472 – C8-0267/2018 – 2018/0250(COD)) (A8-0115/2019) by Monika Hohlmeier, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, now that we have reached the last item on the agenda to deal with internal security and the new fund just before midnight, I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs, all of whom have stayed in this Chamber with me, including the Commissioner, and who are showing good perseverance in dealing with the ISF here too.  I believe that the ISF is becoming increasingly important, given that we and the Member States are increasingly coming to the conclusion, both because of the threat of international terrorism and because of the issues of combating serious international and organised crime, that we need to work more together, that we need to cooperate more effectively, that we need to exchange information as best we can, that we need to coordinate with each other and that, accordingly, we must also be prepared for all requirements in a technically modernised manner.  In order to meet all the challenges here, the Commission has presented the new regulation accordingly, and I consider it to be a very good basis for discussion with the Member States. As a Parliament, we have tried, by a large majority, to focus on the priorities, in particular the intensification of the exchange of information between and within law enforcement authorities, as well as with third countries and international organisations. In particular, we have also focused on cross-border actions between EU law enforcement authorities on serious and organised crime with a cross-border dimension, strengthening the capacity to combat and prevent crime, including terrorism and cybercrime, in particular in cooperation between the authorities, civil society partners and private partners in the Member States, and have also set certain thresholds for this.  We note with some dismay that it always takes quite a while for the Member States to start using the funds and to deal with the respective programmes first. I believe that the citizens of Europe expect us, given the scale of the challenge, to devote ourselves intensively and collectively to the security wishes and the need for security that people feel, and not to keep failing at national borders, that certain information does not flow, that certain data are not entered or that we are not always up to date with the information.  That is why we have also ventured a little into something that may seem unusual, namely that we also want the information to be exchanged with the intelligence services, because we see that, in the field of serious international crime and terrorism, it is necessary to obtain adequate information from the intelligence services and with our European competent agencies. , in this case Europol in particular, to be able to network and analyse information in a meaningful way. And if, for example, we also want to develop Europol, then it is also necessary for the Member States to be prepared to actually exchange information.  However, we would also like to make it clear that we only want to accept the involvement of the private sector – and the restriction has been adopted here by a very large majority – that the private sector is not misused for the performance of public tasks, but only where it is absolutely necessary, with the private sector, for example in the area of cybersecurity or also there. , where it is possible to seek cooperation because of the fact that, for example, banks or, in large-scale events, are partly to do with private individuals. But a replacement for public tasks or the performance of public tasks should not be provided by appropriate private organizations, but still by public security authorities. It is also necessary to cooperate with third countries and with relevant international organisations, because international crime can only be combated if we also cooperate with third countries.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes Parliament’s speedy work in preparing the report on the Internal Security Fund (ISF). Thank you for your introduction, Ms Hohlmeier. I have already underlined, in the debate we have just had, certain issues that concern all three funds, such as the need for flexibility and synergies with all the other funds. As I said, I hope too that the Council will soon adopt its negotiating mandate. I will now set out some issues that more specifically concern the Internal Security Fund. Over recent years, security threats have intensified and diversified. They are increasingly cross—border in nature, meaning that Member States can no longer act alone. While protecting citizens is a national competence, the European Union plays a vital role in supporting Member States’ efforts. Security will remain a defining issue for the European Union in the years to come and Europe’s citizens rightly expect their Union and national governments to deliver security in a fast-changing and uncertain world. We need sufficient resources to support our actions in the area of internal security, in line with our political priorities and in complementarity with other EU funds. Therefore, we propose to reinforce the budget for security, increasing it from EUR 1 billion in the current period to EUR 2.5 billion in the next period. This reflects the political importance the Commission attaches to addressing security challenges more effectively. However, things can change and evolve. Therefore – and I believe this view is shared by Parliament – it is of the utmost importance that our funding is flexible, simplified and adaptable to changing needs. How will the ISF better support new and emerging challenges? It will focus on three new objectives: increasing the exchange of information, intensifying cross—border joint operations and strengthening capabilities to combat and prevent crime. It will be more flexible, through the thematic facility and the mid—term review, allowing us to allocate funds on the basis on evolving needs and EU priorities at that point in time. Last but not least, security is a cross-cutting issue, touching upon several policy areas and involving a number of different EU funds. It is more important than ever that we get it right and design our fund to withstand the test of time.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Monika Hohlmeier, for the work she has done with us.  Security threats in Europe have intensified and diversified in recent years. The challenges facing the European Union can no longer be left to the competence of the Member States alone. On the contrary, we need a strong and coordinated response at Union level and adequate resources to prevent and combat this constantly evolving sector.  But how do you ensure an adequate level of security? Certainly through law enforcement measures, especially aimed at preventing and combating terrorism, serious and organised crime crimes and cybercrime, as well as providing assistance and protection to victims of crime. But law enforcement measures are not enough. A high level of security is also ensured through preventive, coordination and cooperation measures. Thanks to the contributions of this Fund, Member States will be able to combat violent extremism, including radicalisation, intolerance and discrimination, in particular through increased cooperation between public authorities and civil society in all Member States.  A firm point for us is respect for fundamental rights and human dignity. This Fund must be implemented in full respect of the rights and principles enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights and international obligations. It is for this reason that we have included among the activities eligible for funding the education and training of law enforcement staff on fundamental rights, including measures to detect and avoid any form of racism.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Cross-border problems such as terrorism and serious crime cannot be solved by the Member States alone. As a result, financial and technical support from the EU is welcome. The safety fund was therefore set up. Among other things, it regulates the integration of various EU databases and the purchase of technical equipment.  I support the call to double the budget precisely because the security threat in Europe has increased enormously in recent years. We think that these money will also be used specifically to combat child abuse and hacking. That operations such as vigilant guardian, in which our soldiers on the streets protect civilians, could also be eligible for financial support under this budget line as well.  But Parliament wants the budget to be suspended in a Member State if problems with the rule of law are identified there. This aspect is problematic, because the legal elaboration of the separate bill to protect the Union's budget is not watertight.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on this dossier. We Greens are basically in favour of greater cooperation on internal security, and the text now being voted on contains some good compromises, including a kind of Erasmus programme for police forces and also anti-racism training programmes for law enforcement agencies. Nevertheless, we shall be voting against the report for the following reasons: firstly, the Fund is intended to promote intelligence cooperation, and neither Parliament nor the Court of Auditors has any control over this. Five per cent of the funds requested by Member States must go towards such intelligence cooperation. Secondly, the Fund, as planned, could also support military operations within the EU. We also consider this to be highly problematic. Last but not least, it is important for me to mention that the term 'itinerant crime' is used in the report. This phrase is a stigmatising term often used to criminalise ethnic minorities.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for It is no secret, I think, that the Internal Security Fund is not one of our favorites, even though there are some improvements that we really appreciate. What does not suit us is the drastic increase of one and a half times in relation to this fund. The second is the blending operations, where private financing should also be used – as the rapporteur said a few times a moment ago – but this is not clear enough to us and where we are really concerned. But the third point is actually the most important: the fund is also intended to promote intelligence services, to develop – as they say – a common intelligence culture, exchange of best practices, knowledge, experts, best practice in the truest sense of the word. Let me be quite honest: I know, at least in the German area, i.e. with us, actually no best practice from any secret service, only cover-up or failure, bad luck and breakdowns, as we say. Intelligence agencies are probably part of the problem rather than solving it, and we are too sorry for the money.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This report and this regulation – as for the terms of this Parliament – is not the worst at all, but it lacks a few things. I have some serious reservations: firstly, the death penalty. Until you get rid of outdated superstitions about this opposition to the death penalty, you are not able to win against terrorists, we are not able to win a war where they can kill us and we cannot. We are not able to provide citizens with security against this and all this money, all these improvements, will be money thrown down the drain without it, without the death penalty. Second point: Article 12. There is already a commitment by states to cooperate with EU agencies, whether it is funded by the Union at any given time or not. Well, here the principle of subsidiarity ends, its violation begins. And the third point: Article 21 calls for the visibility of the Union's action. The Union has consistently taken this route, and it is giving loudly, it wants to give its logo every time it gives money for something. However, I am calling for the EU logo to be a sign of all the products with which we pay the EU budget.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the Internal Security Fund must focus on combating organised crime, and above all cross-border crime. It's something we have to watch out for. I would like to propose that there should be cooperation, in addition, between Greece and Bulgaria, because cross-border crime has developed very much, Mr Avraboule. Apart from the fact that we have too many illegal immigrants coming from Turkey, Bulgaria and then to Greece, we now also have coils of criminals and thugs, who literally flee the centre of Thessaloniki with robberies, thefts and then return to Bulgaria. This issue needs to be addressed. It's dominant right now.  On the other hand, as has been said, the Internal Security Fund should not be a financier of intelligence cooperation, nor should we not have a kind of privatisation of internal security. These are points to watch out for.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this interesting, if short, debate on the future of our financial support for EU security policy. I took note of all your comments, including the last points from Mr Marias, and I am looking forward to the Council mandate too, so that we can start our trilogue. Thank you very much, and sleep tight – though not here.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Today, women have the last word, again. In other words, I can, so to speak, say the final word at midnight. Very brief reply to colleagues: first of all, I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs once again. Because there were really a lot of good and also creative ideas, and I think we also had a very good atmosphere in the conversations with each other, where we tried to understand each other and together to deliver a good concept here. Firstly, with regard to the intelligence services, it would be a clear mistake to believe that we are promoting intelligence services per se – that is not even permissible under the Treaty. Rather, we want cooperation with the European agency Europol. In the field of terrorism, we see very clearly that information from the field of intelligence must first be analysed and evaluated precisely and then checked to what extent it is useful and usable for the relevant investigations within the police competence. And that they are, we have seen in Germany, for example, in the so-called ricin case, which would not have been uncovered without intelligence activities. This is just one example among many. So we do not want to monitor and control the secret services – whatever, that is Member State competence, that is not our responsibility – but we want to promote an orderly and transparent form of cooperation, and I think that is sensible and effective. Secondly, military operations in the EU are specifically limited to the tasks. This means that if, for example, in France or Belgium, military units – in France, for example, after the Bataclan – have also helped to ensure internal security, then this is eligible. Military operations of a different kind do not belong to the isF's range of tasks. The tasks are very clearly defined, and they cannot be extended anywhere outside of competence. We have excluded these questions from home in the catalogue of exceptions. Finally, if we in this House – Madam President, forgive me, I have to say the sentence – ask us to reconsider the issue of the death penalty, then I must honestly say that it turns my stomach. We have the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and we will not respond with the same methods by which the terrorists and the serious criminals are trying to fight us, but we want to respond to the rule of law and respond with the rule of law and with our laws, and accordingly leave it to the courts to issue the penalties and then also deal with these people under the rule of law.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 12 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. – The challenges to the Internal Security of the European Union have increased significantly in recent years: I am thinking of changing and complex threats such as global terrorist networks, new forms of organised crime or cybercrime; all phenomena of a cross-border and cross-sectoral nature and which no Member State can deal with alone. With this in mind, increasing the budget of the Internal Security Fund (FSI) is an important financial means through which the EU can support cooperation and coordination between member states' law enforcement authorities. As the Report of the Special Committee on Terrorism has shown, the exchange of information must be strengthened through greater use of joint law enforcement operations between Member States (I am thinking of joint investigation teams) but also by investing in the appropriate training of staff and facilitating the exchange of best practices. With a view to a long-term counter to the phenomenon of terrorism, it is also essential to extend the scope of the Fund to measures aimed at preventing violent extremism, for example through interventions in prisons and in the digital sphere. I will conclude by emphasising that the military forces responsible for internal security, such as the Carabinieri, should also be able to benefit from the support of the Fund because they deal with and prevent various types of threats to the Union's security on a daily basis.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. – In recent years, the security threats facing Europe have intensified and diversified, taking the form of terrorist attacks, new types of organised crime and cybercrime. All these internal security challenges and complex external threats cannot be addressed by Member States individually and without EU financial and technical support. As such, this proposal, welcome, seeks to establish an Internal Security Fund for the period 2021-2027 for a Union of 27 Member States. The Internal Security Fund was set up with the aim of facilitating cross-border cooperation and exchanges of information between law enforcement officials in the Member States and other relevant authorities. The Fund aims to enhance cross-border operational cooperation in the prevention, detection and investigation of cross-border crime acts and to support efforts to strengthen the capacities needed to prevent these forms of crime, including terrorism, in particular through increased cooperation between public authorities, civil society and private partners in all Member States. The proposal includes restrictions on funding of third countries and eliminates military funding and the possibility of purchasing weapons with EU funds in emergency situations.
